Description: PROJECT TITLE: BIG GAME MIGRATION MAPPING - DEVELOPING METHODS FOR ATYPICAL MIGRANTSPROJECT PERIOD: AUGUST 15, 2023, THROUGH, SEPTEMBER 30, 2025PROJECT ABSTRACT: ACROSS THE GLOBE, UNGULATES (HOOVED MAMMALS) MIGRATE TO ACCESS SEASONALLY AVAILABLE FORAGE AND AVOID HARSH WEATHER. DESPITE THE IMPORTANCE OF UNGULATE MIGRATION FOR MANY ECOSYSTEMS, THE TRADITIONAL MIGRATION CORRIDORS USED BY POPULATIONS AROUND THE WORLD FACE UNPRECEDENTED CHANGE FROM THE EXPANDING FOOTPRINT OF HUMAN DEVELOPMENT. TO CONSERVE UNGULATE MIGRATION IN THE FACE OF RAPID ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE AND ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCE, AN IMPORTANT FIRST STEP IS MAPPING THE MIGRATION CORRIDORS. THE RECIPIENT WILL DEVELOP METHODS TO MAP KEY MOVEMENT CORRIDORS FOR SPECIES THAT EXHIBIT  ATYPICAL MIGRATIONS  (I.E., WIDE-RANGING BUT LESS PREDICTABLE MOVEMENT PATTERNS).  THE TAXONOMIC FOCUS OF THIS EFFORT WILL BE PRONGHORN AND ELK.  THIS WORK IS PART OF THE IMPLEMENTATION OF SECRETARIAL ORDER 3362, WHICH CALLED ON THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) TO ASSIST WESTERN STATES IN MAPPING UNGULATE MIGRATION CORRIDORS AND DEVELOP NEW MAPPING TOOLS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -  -COMPILE GPS TRACKING DATASETS OF ATYPICAL MIGRANTS. THE GEOGRAPHIC FOCUS OF THIS COMPILATION EFFORT WILL BE THE 11 PUBLIC LAND STATES IN THE WEST. THE TAXONOMIC FOCUS OF THIS DATA COMPILATION EFFORT WILL BE PRONGHORN, ELK AND POSSIBLY OTHER SPECIES DEPENDING ON NEED.-USE EXISTING METHODS (E.G., CONTINUOUS TIME MOVEMENT MODEL  CTMM , BBMM) TO MAP MOVEMENT CORRIDORS FOR ATYPICAL MIGRANTS TO ESTABLISH A BASELINE. -BEGIN TESTING EMERGING METHODS (E.G., LIKELIHOOD-BASED CONNECTIVITY MODELS) AND, IF NEEDED, DEVELOP NEW METHODS TO MAP MOVEMENT CORRIDORS AND KEY LANDSCAPE LINKAGES.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -DELIVERABLES FOR THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE:1)SUMMARY INFORMATION AND META DATA FOR THE DATA SET USED IN THE ANALYSIS.2)MAP FILES OF MOVEMENT CORRIDOR INFORMATION AS APPROPRIATE FOR STORAGE ON USGS SCIENCEBASE. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -STATE AND FEDERAL NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS IN THE WESTERN USA. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -  N A

PROJECT TITLE: CANDY DARTER STATUS ASSESSMENT OF THE LOWER GAULEY RIVERPROJECT PERIOD: AUGUST 24, 2023, THROUGH AUGUST 23, 2024PROJECT ABSTRACT: PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY TEMPLATE FOR WV RWO 82 INCLUDE A PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION AWARD PURPOSE (AVOID ACRONYMS OR FEDERAL OR AGENCY-SPECIFIC TERMINOLOGY) - THE CANDY DARTER, AN ENDANGERED FISH THAT ASSOCIATES WITH COOL WATER TEMPERATURES, OCCURS WITHIN THE NEW RIVER DRAINAGE, INCLUDING AREAS OF THE WATERSHED MANAGED BY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO MONITOR SEASONAL WATER TEMPERATURES AND DETERMINE IF CANDY DARTER POPULATIONS ARE PRESENT IN SECTIONS OF THE GAULEY RIVER NATIONAL RECREATION AREA, WEST VIRGINIA. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -  ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE (1) CANDY DARTER POPULATION ASSESSMENTS USING METHODS OF ELECTROFISHING OR UNDERWATER OBSERVATION (SNORKELING), AND (2) DEPLOYMENT OF SUBMERGED LOGGERS TO OBTAIN WATER TEMPERATURE DATA WITHIN THE GAULEY RIVER NATIONAL RECREATION AREA, WEST VIRGINIA. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE (1) DATA ON THE PRESENCE ABSENCE OF CANDY DARTERS IN SECTIONS OF THE GAULEY RIVER NATIONAL RECREATION AREA, WEST VIRGINIA, AND (2) A DATABASE OF SEASONAL WATER TEMPERATURES FROM THE GAULEY RIVER AND TRIBUTARIES WITHIN THE BOUNDARIES OF THE GAULEY RIVER NATIONAL RECREATION AREA. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE (1) VERIFICATION OF CANDY DARTER PRESENCE, AND (2) DOCUMENTED WATER TEMPERATURE VARIATION ACROSS SEASONS AND SECTIONS OF THE GAULEY RIVER NATIONAL RECREATION AREA, BOTH OF WHICH COULD INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -NATIONAL PARK SERVICEWEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES SPECIFIED.

PROJECT TITLE: TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR NORTHWEST CLIMATE SCIENCE STATE OF KNOWLEDGEPROJECT PERIOD: AUGUST 09, 2023, THROUGH JUNE 30, 2024PROJECT ABSTRACT: THE AWARD PURPOSE IS TO HELP PROJECT COOPERATORS PRODUCE A STATE OF KNOWLEDGE CLIMATE SYNTHESIS DOCUMENT THAT OUTLINES CURRENT CLIMATE CHANGE KNOWLEDGE IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION. THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL HIGHLIGHT RECENT SCIENTIFIC ADVANCES, PROVIDE KEY RESEARCH AND DATA REFERENCES, BE QUICK AND EASY TO NAVIGATE AND USE, AND HELP LINK SCIENTIFIC ADVANCES TO MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -  THE OREGON COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT (OR CRU) WILL ASSIST WITH THE PRODUCTION OF THIS SYNTHESIS DOCUMENT. SPECIFICALLY, THE OR CRU WILL PRODUCE: A 57-PAGE ECOSYSTEM OVERVIEW SUMMARY REPORT OF CLIMATE CHANGE EFFECTS, A 2-PAGE ECOREGION SUMMARY OF CLIMATE CHANGE EFFECTS IN FACT SHEET, AND A LIST OF KEY REFERENCES AND DATA SOURCES, ESPECIALLY SPATIAL DATA. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -THE FOLLOWING REPORTS AND DELIVERABLES WILL BE PRODUCED AND SHARED WITH PROJECT COOPERATORS: 1) AT LEAST ONE ECOSYSTEM OVERVIEW SUMMARY REPORT OF CLIMATE CHANGE EFFECTS, 2) AT LEAST ONE ECOREGION SUMMARY OF CLIMATE CHANGE EFFECTS, AND 3) A LIST OF KEY REFERENCES AND DATA SOURCES TO BE INCORPORATED INTO A STATE OF KNOWLEDGE CLIMATE SYNTHESIS DOCUMENT FOR THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION. THIS WORK WILL HELP PROJECT COOPERATORS AND THEIR PARTNER AGENCIES TO LINK SCIENTIFIC ADVANCES TO CLIMATE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -EXPECTED END USERS INCLUDE THE NORTHWEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTER AND AGENCIES SUCH AS THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, U.S. FOREST SERVICE, NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, AND STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENTS. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD N A

PROJECT TITLE: TOXICITY OF DIFFERENT LIFE STAGES OF CAHABA RIVER MUDSNAILS TO POTASSIUM, CHLORIDE, AND NICKELPROJECT PERIOD: 08 08 2023 - 09 30 2026PROJECT ABSTRACT: FRESHWATER SNAILS ARE PRESUMABLY SENSITIVE TO CHANGES IN WATER QUALITY, BUT THERE IS A TREMENDOUS DATA GAP IN SENSITIVITY AMONG SPECIES EVEN IN CLOSELY RELATED GROUPS. UNFORTUNATELY, THE RESEARCH FOCUS HAS TENDED TO BE ON INVASIVE SNAILS, AND GENERALLY LACKS EVEN BASIC INFORMATION ON HOW NATIVE SNAILS MAY RESPOND TO CHANGES IN WATER QUALITY. IN PARTICULAR, WITHIN A DIVERSE GROUP OF FRESHWATER SNAILS KNOWN AS MUDSNAILS, LITTLE IS KNOWN AND THERE ARE NO DOCUMENTED PROTOCOLS FOR CONDUCTING BASIC TOXICITY TESTS. TO COMPLICATE MATTERS, MUDSNAILS ARE ABLE TO CLOSE THEIR OPERCULUM ALLOWING THEM TO ESCAPE SOME EXPOSURE TO TOXIC SUBSTANCES FOR SOME PERIOD OF TIME. SUBSEQUENTLY, AN UNDERSTANDING OF HOW NARROWER-RANGE ENDEMIC SPECIES SUCH AS MUDSNAILS RESPOND TO DIFFERENT TOXINS AT DIFFERENT LIFE STAGES WOULD BE USEFUL FOR DEVELOPING IMPROVED CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND ASSESSING THREATS. THE RESULTING DATA WILL BE SUMMARIZED IN TABLES AND SYNTHESIZED IN A MANUSCRIPT. PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DIFFERENCES IN TOXICITY OF SPECIES AND LIFE STAGES WITHIN MUDSNAILS (GILL BREATHING SNAILS).SPECIFIC STUDY OBJECTIVES ARE:1. ESTABLISH A PROTOCOL FOR TOXICOLOGY TESTING OF CONTAMINANTS USING MUDSNAIL  AND2. DETERMINE THE INFLUENCE OF ORGANISM LIFE STAGES (I.E., TIME SINCE HATCHING) OF ELIMIA ANNETTAE, LEPTOXIS AMPLA, AND SOMATOGYRUS SP. ON THE TOXICITY OF POTASSIUM, CHLORIDE, AND NICKEL. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE A TABLE SUMMARY OF THE RESULTS, AND A MANUSCRIPT DRAFT. THE RESULTS ARE INTENDED TO HELP USFWS COMPLETE SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS. THESE DATA SHOULD PROVIDE HELPFUL INSIGHT INTO THE SENSITIVITY OF THESE SPECIES IN COMPARISON TO MORE BROADLY DISTRIBUTED SPECIES. MOREOVER, THESE DATA SHOULD BE USEFUL FOR ASSESSING CURRENT AND FUTURE THREATS TO THE SPECIES WITHIN THE CAHABA RIVER. FROM A BROADER PERSPECTIVE, THIS WORK SHOULD BE AN IMPORTANT STEP IN DEVELOPING METHODS THAT ARE NEEDED FOR GILL-BREATHING SNAILS.

PROJECT TITLE: PROJECTING THE DISTRIBUTION OF AQUATIC SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED THROUGHOUT THE MID-ATLANTIC REGIONPROJECT PERIOD:08 01 2023 - 07 31 2026PROJECT ABSTRACT: PROJECT WILL PREDICT IMPACTS OF CLIMATE AND LAND USE CHANGE ON AQUATIC REGIONAL SPECIES OF CONSERVATION NEED) THROUGHOUT MARYLAND, PENNSYLVANIA, VIRGINIA, AND WEST VIRGINIA.  OBJECTIVE IS TO UNDERSTAND AND PLAN FOR CHANGES IN DISTRIBUTION OF AQUATIC SPECIES IN THE MID-ATLANTIC REGION AS A CONSEQUENCE OF CLIMATE AND LAND USE CHANGE. PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A DECISION-MAKING FRAMEWORK TO (A) FACILITATE SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONAL SHIFTS, (B) MINIMIZE THREATS, (C) IDENTIFY AREAS WHERE CONSERVATION FOR A GIVEN BIOTIC GROUP WILL BE MORE LESS NEEDED AND SUCCESSFUL, AND (D) REDUCE UNCERTAINTY THROUGH GEOGRAPHICALLY FOCUSED INCREMENTAL MONITORING AND REVISION. RECIPIENT WILL WORK WITH STATE AND FEDERAL COOPERATORS TO IDENTIFY HIGH PRIORITY SPECIES AND OBTAIN DATA ON KNOWN DISTRIBUTIONS. USING KNOWN OCCURRENCE RECORDS AND ASSOCIATED CLIMATE, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND LAND-USE DATA, RECIPIENT WILL MODEL CURRENT DISTRIBUTIONS OF HIGH PRIORITY SPECIES. USING PROJECTIONS OF CLIMATE, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND LAND USE DATA, RECIPIENT WILL THEN PREDICT FUTURE DISTRIBUTIONS OF SELECTED SPECIES AND COMPARE FUTURE PROJECTED SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS TO PROBABLE FUTURE SCENARIOS (I.E., URBANIZATION AND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT SCENARIOS) TO IDENTIFY SPECIES THAT MAY REQUIRE GREATER (OR LESSER) CONSERVATION ATTENTION OVER TIME. THE PRIMARY PRODUCTS ARE MAPS OF CURRENT AND PROJECTED SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS, AS WELL AS A CUSTOMIZABLE WEB-BASED TOOL TO ALLOW MANAGERS TO VIEW PROJECTED DISTRIBUTIONS OF SELECTED SPECIES AT USER-SPECIFIED TIME INTERVALS, CLIMATE CHANGE AND LAND-USE SCENARIOS, AND GEOGRAPHIC EXTENT. FOR EXAMPLE, USERS WILL BE ABLE TO PRODUCE CUSTOM PREDICTIONS OF SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS ASSOCIATED WITH PLACEMENT OR REMOVAL OF BARRIERS TO PROVIDE TEMPORAL GOALS FOR SPECIFIC REMOVALS TO FACILITATE SPECIES DISPERSALS. THE RESULTS  THUS CAN BE INTEGRATED INTO LONG-TERM CONSERVATION DECISION-MAKING AND PLANNING THAT WILL HELP PLANNING FOR CHANGES IN THE DISTRIBUTION OF RSGCN, STATE SPECIFIC SGCN, AND FEDERALLY LISTED (AND AT-RISK) SPECIES RELATED TO STRESSORS (E.G., CLIMATE CHANGE AND CHANGES IN LAND COVER LAND USE). THIS PROJECT WILL WORK WITH AN ADVISORY TEAM COMPOSED OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM MID-ATLANTIC STATE, FEDERAL, AND NGO AGENCIES ENGAGED IN AQUATIC RESOURCE CONSERVATION. PROJECT GOAL IS TO IDENTIFY SURROGATE AQUATIC SPECIES FROM LISTS OF REGIONAL AND STATE SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED AND FEDERAL AT-RISK SPECIES TO MODEL THEIR DISTRIBUTIONS RELATIVE TO CURRENT CLIMATE AND LAND COVER DATA. RECIPIENT WILL THEN PROJECT FUTURE DISTRIBUTIONS BASED ON COMPARABLE PROJECTED ENVIRONMENTAL DATA. RECIPIENT WILL ASSESS WHETHER FUTURE PROJECTED SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS MAY BE IMPACTED BY PROBABLE FUTURE SCENARIOS IDENTIFIED IN COLLABORATION WITH THE PARTNER ADVISORY TEAM (I.E., URBANIZATION AND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT SCENARIOS). BY OVERLAYING PROJECTED SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS WITH DIFFERENT LAND USE CLIMATE SCENARIOS RECIPIENT WILL IDENTIFY SPECIES THAT MAY REQUIRE GREATER (OR LESSER) CONSERVATION ATTENTION OVER TIME.  EMPHASIS WILL BE GIVEN TO WORKING CLOSELY WITH THE PARTNERS ON AN ITERATIVE BASIS TO ENSURE SCENARIOS AND STRATEGIES ALIGN WITH MANAGEMENT NEEDS AND WILL BE APPLICABLE TO (STATE AND FEDERAL) SPECIES RECOVERY PLANNING EFFORTS (I.E. USFWS SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS, 5-YEAR REVIEWS, AND RECOVERY PLANS). THE PRIMARY PRODUCTS WILL BE MAPS OF CURRENT AND PROJECTED SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS. IMPORTANTLY, RECIPIENT WILL ALSO DEVELOP A FULLY CUSTOMIZABLE WEB-BASED VIEWER THAT WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO CUSTOMIZE PROJECTED DISTRIBUTIONS OF SELECTED SPECIES AT USER-SPECIFIED TIME INTERVALS, CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS, AND GEOGRAPHIC EXTENT.

PROJECT TITLE: CHARACTERIZATION OF GREAT LAKES LAKE WHITEFISH POPULATION GENETIC STRUCTUREPROJECT PERIOD: JULY 24, 2023 THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30, 2023PROJECT ABSTRACT:BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION REQUIRES BASELINE KNOWLEDGE OF CURRENT DIVERSITY PATTERNS. LAKE WHITEFISH HAVE EXPERIENCED ABUNDANCE DECLINES THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES IN RESPONSE TO INVASIVE SPECIES AND HISTORIC OVERHARVEST. THE SPECIES CURRENTLY SUPPORTS ECONOMICALLY AND CULTURALLY IMPORTANT FISHERIES, MAKING IT A TARGET OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS TO ENSURE SUSTAINABILITY OF HARVESTS. RECENT RESEARCH HAS RESULTED IN DEVELOPMENT OF GENETIC TOOLS USEFUL FOR THE CHARACTERIZATION OF LAKE WHITEFISH DIVERSITY  HOWEVER, THESE TOOLS WERE DEVELOPED USING LAKE MICHIGAN LAKE WHITEFISH POPULATIONS AND THEIR APPLICABILITY TO OTHER AREAS OF THE GREAT LAKES IS UNKNOWN. THEREFORE, RECIPIENT WILL BE ASSESSING THE UTILITY OF TWO GENOME-SCALE GENOTYPING TOOLS ON LAKE WHITEFISH POPULATIONS FROM LAKE SUPERIOR, LAKE HURON, LAKE ERIE, AND LAKE ONTARIO. RESULTS WILL IDENTIFY THE PRESENCE OF ANY BIAS RESULTING FROM THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE GENOTYPING TOOLS ON ONLY LAKE MICHIGAN POPULATIONS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - RECIPIENT WILL GENOTYPE LAKE WHITEFISH FROM 18 SPAWNING AGGREGATIONS LOCATED IN LAKE SUPERIOR, LAKE HURON, LAKE ERIE, AND LAKE ONTARIO. THREE HUNDRED AND FOURTEEN INDIVIDUALS WILL BE GENOTYPED AT 476 SINGLE NUCLEOTIDE POLYMORPHISM (SNP) LOCI USING A GENOTYPING-IN-THOUSANDS PANEL AND 358 WILL BE GENOTYPED AT 100,000 SNP LOCI USING A RAD CAPTURE PANEL. RECIPIENT WILL QUANTIFY GENETIC STRUCTURE AMONG SPAWNING AGGREGATIONS BY QUANTIFYING INTERPOPULATION VARIATION IN ALLELE FREQUENCIES (FST), PERFORMING MAXIMUM-LIKELIHOOD CLUSTERING ANALYSES, AND PERFORMING MULTIVARIATE STATISTICAL ANALYSES. ASCERTAINMENT BIAS OF THE GENOTYPING-IN-THOUSANDS LOCI WILL BE EVALUATED THROUGH COMPARISONS WITH THE LARGER RAD CAPTURE GENOTYPING PANEL. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -AT LEAST ONE MANUSCRIPT AND ONE CONFERENCE PRESENTATION WILL RESULT FROM THIS RESEARCH. THESE DELIVERABLES WILL DESCRIBE CONTEMPORARY LAKE WHITEFISH POPULATION STRUCTURE THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES -GREAT LAKES FISHERIES MANAGERS WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS RESEARCH AS IT WILL PROVIDE CRITICAL BASELINE BIODIVERSITY INFORMATION THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO LAKE WHITEFISH FROM THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES BEING ABLE TO BE ASSIGNED TO THEIR STOCK OR POPULATION OF ORIGIN. GIVEN IMPROVED MANAGEMENT TOOLS, COMMERCIAL AND TRIBAL FISHERS WILL ALSO BENEFIT FROM THE ENABLING OF AN IMPROVED INFORMATION SOURCE FOR FISHERIES MANAGEMENT. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -NONE

PROJECT TITLE: LAKE MEMPHREMAGOG BROWN BULLHEAD MELANOMA STUDY PLAN EASTERN ECOLOGICAL SCIENCE CENTER AND WEST VIRGINIA CRU RESEARCH COLLABORATION FOR HISTOPATHOLOGY AND GENOMICSPROJECT PERIOD: 07 27 2023 - 09 30 2026PROJECT ABSTRACT: BROWN BULLHEAD WILL BE COLLECTED AT 7 SITES WITHIN LAKE MEMPHREMAGOG IN VERMONT. TWENTY INDIVIDUALS, 200 MM AND ABOVE, INCLUDING BOTH NORMAL-APPEARING AND INDIVIDUALS WITH MELANOMAS WILL BE COLLECTED AT EACH SITE. FISH WILL BE EUTHANIZED, A BLOOD SAMPLE COLLECTED, FISH WEIGHED AND MEASURED. A COMPLETE NECROPSY WILL BE CONDUCTED, DOCUMENTING ALL EXTERNAL AND INTERNAL ABNORMALITIES, COLLECTING SMALL PIECES OF NORMAL AND ABNORMAL SKIN SAMPLES FOR SUBSEQUENT GENE EXPRESSION ANALYSES (PRESERVED IN RNALATER). PIECES OF LIVER WILL ALSO BE PRESERVED FOR GENE EXPRESSION. PIECES OF ALL ORGANS WILL BE COLLECTED FOR HISTOPATHOLOGY AND PRESERVED IN Z-FIX. LABORATORY ANALYSES WILL INCLUDE PREPARATION OF HISTOPATHOLOGY SLIDES OF TISSUES PRESERVED IN Z-FIX FROM ALL FISH COLLECTED. TISSUES ARE ROUTINELY PROCESSED, EMBEDDED INTO PARAFFIN, SECTIONED AT 5 M, AND STAINED WITH HEMATOXYLIN AND EOSIN FOR PATHOLOGICAL EVALUATION OF ALL TISSUES. ALL ORGANS WILL BE EXAMINED FOR INDICATORS OF CONTAMINANT EXPOSURE, PRESENCE OF INFECTIOUS AGENTS, INFLAMMATION, PRENEOPLASTIC AND NEOPLASTIC CHANGES.TISSUES PRESERVED IN RNALATER WILL BE EXTRACTED AND UTILIZING NANOSTRING MULTIPLEX TECHNOLOGY WITH THE NCOUNTER MAX TRANSCRIPT ABUNDANCE OF 50-60 GENES IDENTIFIED IN PHASE 1 WILL BE QUANTIFIED. THESE WILL INCLUDE GENES ASSOCIATED WITH VARIOUS CHEMICAL EXPOSURES, CELL PROLIFERATION, IMMUNITY AND INFLAMMATION, AS WELL AS POTENTIAL TUMOR SUPPRESSOR GENES AND ONCOGENES (JEAN ET AL. 2001  LOGAN ET AL. 2003  PATTON ET AL. 2006  WANG ET AL. 2009) AND SEQUENCES OF THE RECENTLY IDENTIFIED ADOMAVIRUS. RESULTS FROM THESE ANALYSES WILL BE SHARED WITH THE VT CRU AND UTILIZED IN REPORTS AND JOURNAL ARTICLESRESEARCH RESULTS WILL BE PUBLISHED AS MS THESIS AND MANUSCRIPTS PUBLISHED IN PEER-REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS. RESULTS WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO USGS SCIENCE SUMMARIES, FACT SHEETS AND OTHER PRODUCTS DIRECTED AT RESOURCE MANAGERS.

PROJECT TITLE: YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL RANGE-WIDE ASSESSMENT AND CONSERVATIONPROJECT PERIOD: 07 25 2023  04 30 2026PROJECT ABSTRACT: THE YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL, LAMPSILIS CARIOSA, IS A FRESHWATER MUSSEL THAT IS LOCALLY DESIGNATED ASENDANGERED, THREATENED, OR A SPECIAL STATUS IN EIGHT U.S. STATES AND TWO CANADIAN PROVINCES. ASWITH MANY FRESHWATER MUSSEL SPECIES, YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL MONITORING, ASSESSMENT, ANDCONSERVATION PLANNING OCCURS PRIMARILY WITHIN LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS, WITH LITTLE INTERACTION OUTSIDEGEOGRAPHIC BOUNDARIES. ADDITIONALLY, CONTEMPORARY YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL SURVEYS ARE LIMITED ANDNOT STANDARDIZED, MAKING IT DIFFICULT TO ASSESS ITS RANGE-WIDE DISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION STATUS.TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS, THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH A YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL WORKING GROUP OF STATE,FEDERAL, ACADEMIC, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL PARTNERS TO INCREASE RANGE-WIDE COOPERATION, RESEARCH,AND STRATEGIC PLANNING OF CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION EFFORTS. RESEARCH WILL BE CONDUCTED AT THEMASSACHUSETTS AND MAINE COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNITS, AND INCLUDE EXISTINGDATA COMPILATION AND MULTI-SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELLING, FINE-SCALE HABITAT ASSESSMENTS IN LARGERIVERS, AND HOST FISH ASSESSMENT. ULTIMATELY, THE PROJECT AIMS TO INFORM AND GUIDE CONSERVATIONAND RESTORATION PLANNING FOR YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -ACTIVITIES INCLUDE:1) ASSESSING LANDSCAPE-SCALE THREATS AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL RESTORATION SITES FOR YELLOWLAMPMUSSEL ACROSS ITS RANGE USING A MULTI-SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODEL2) ASSESSING THE SUITABILITY OF STRIPED BASS (MORONE SAXATILIS) AS HOST FISH FOR YELLOWLAMPMUSSEL WITH FIELD COLLECTIONS AND LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS3) ASSESSING HABITAT FOR YLM AND POTENTIAL LOCATIONS FOR YLM SURVEYS AND RESTORATION USINGSIDE-SCAN SONAR IN THREE RIVERS4) ESTABLISHING AN INTERAGENCY YLM WORKING GROUP COMPRISED OF MUSSEL EXPERTS AND MANAGERS DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -RESULTS OF THE RESEARCH WILL BE SHARED IN SCIENTIFIC, PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL MANUSCRIPTS ANDASSOCIATED DATA RELEASES. RECIPIENT WILL ALSO DEVELOP A WEBSITE AND CREATE A GOOGLE DRIVE FOR SHARINGINFORMATION AMONG PARTNERS. THIS RESEARCH ADDRESSES AGENCY AND DEPARTMENT PRIORITIES FORPROACTIVE, SCIENCE-BASED CONSERVATION OF YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL PRIOR TO LISTING DECISIONS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES -U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICESTATE AGENCIES WITHIN THE SPECIES RANGE (ATLANTIC COAST: GEORGIA TO MAINE)FISHERIES AND OCEANS CANADA SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -THE ACTIVITIES WILL BE PERFORMED BY THE MASSACHUSETTS AND MAINE COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFERESEARCH UNITS. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 28 23-12 31 23PROJECT TITLE: GRIZZLY BEAR CONSERVATION IN THE US NORTHERN ROCKIESAWARD PURPOSE - IN THE CONTERMINOUS UNITED STATES, AN ESTIMATED 50,000 GRIZZLY BEARS WERE LIKELY PRESENT 200 YEARS AGO (USFWS, 2022). THE ARRIVAL OF EUROPEANS BROUGHT HEAVY PERSECUTION, HABITAT LOSS, AND RAPID DECLINE. NUMEROUS RESEARCH NEEDS REMAIN FOR CONSERVATION OF GRIZZLY BEARS IN THE CONTERMINOUS US. IN PARTICULAR, RESEARCH IS NEEDED TO UNDERSTAND HOW GRIZZLY BEARS SELECT ANTHROPOGENIC FOOD RESOURCES AND RESPOND TO ROADS AND NONMOTORIZED RECREATION. FOR EXAMPLE, GRIZZLY BEARS APPEAR TO BE ATTRACTED TO GRAIN BIN SITES, WHICH ARE NUMEROUS ON THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN FRONT IN THE NCDE, BUT IT IS UNCLEAR HOW THEY CHOOSE WHICH GRAIN BINS TO DEPREDATE AND HOW MORE PROACTIVE MEASURES COULD BE IMPLEMENTED TO AVOID THESE CONFLICTS. SIMILARLY, IT IS GENERALLY THOUGHT THAT GRIZZLY BEARS AVOID ROADS AND SITES OF HEAVY NONMOTORIZED RECREATION, BUT DETAILED UNDERSTANDING OF BEHAVIORAL RESPONSES AND LONG-TERM IMPACTS ARE LACKING.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -  THIS STUDY WILL IDENTIFY AND ANSWER A RESEARCH QUESTION THAT ADDRESSES A TOPIC OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED FOR GRIZZLY BEARS IN THE US NORTHERN ROCKIES. THE RESEARCH QUESTION WILL ALSO BE ONE THAT IS SUITABLE FOR A 2-YEAR MS PROJECT. THIS IS LIKELY TO FOCUS ON HOW GRIZZLY BEARS USE GRAIN BINS ON THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN FRONT, HOW THEY RESPOND TO ROADS, OR THE EFFECTS OF NONMOTORIZED RECREATION. THE PI WILL IDENTIFY WHICH OF THESE QUESTIONS TO PURSUE THROUGH CONTINUED CONSULTATION WITH COLLABORATORS AT STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES PRIOR TO SELECTING A GRADUATE STUDENT FOR THE PROJECT AND INITIATING THE RESEARCH. THE SELECTED STUDENT WILL CARRY OUT ANALYSES TO ANSWER THE IDENTIFIED RESEARCH QUESTION.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -THE STUDENT WILL PRODUCE ANNUAL REPORTS, A THESIS, AND AT LEAST ONE PUBLICATION IN A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL. THEY WILL ALSO COMPLETE PRESENTATIONS FOR THE UNIVERSITY, PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES, AND COLLABORATORS, PLUS OTHER OPPORTUNITIES AS THEY ARISE. MODELS AND CODE WILL LIKEWISE BE PROVIDED TO COLLABORATORS. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -GRIZZLY BEAR CONSERVATION, STAKEHOLDERS THAT CARE ABOUT THIS TOPIC, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO BENEFIT FROM AN INTACT ECOSYSTEM. OTHER BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE PLANTS AND ANIMALS FOR WHOM GRIZZLY BEARS PRESENT AN EFFECTIVE UMBRELLA SPECIES. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 31 23-6 29 24PROJECT TITLE: HABITAT CONNECTIVITY FOR LARGE MAMMALS IN THE GREATER EVERGLADESAWARD PURPOSE - WILL QUANTIFY AND MAP HABITAT CONNECTIVITY FOR LARGE MAMMALS IN THE GREATER EVERGLADES ECOSYSTEM (GEE) TO DETERMINE EXISTING POTENTIAL CORRIDORS, HOW IMPORTANT THE EVERGLADES CURRENTLY IS FOR CONNECTIVITY IN THE REGION, AND HOW THESE ISSUES OVERLAP WITH THE FLORIDA WILDLIFE CORRIDOR. WILL FOCUS ON THE FLORIDA PANTHER AND BLACK BEAR, TWO SPECIES OF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT CONCERN. WORKING WITH STAKEHOLDERS, WE WILL PROVIDE AND EVALUATE SCENARIOS FOR INTERPRETING MANAGEMENT ACTIONS WITHIN THE GEE AIMED AT IMPROVING CONNECTIVITY. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -  WILL DEVELOP A GENERALIZED WORKFLOW FOR INTERPRETING HABITAT CONNECTIVITY FOR WILDLIFE THAT CAN INCORPORATE INFORMATION ON MOVEMENT, HABITAT SUITABILITY, AND DIFFERENT SOURCES OF POTENTIAL MORTALITY RISKS. PROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 23-7 31 28PROJECT TITLE: SURVIVAL AND HABITAT USE OF ATLANTIC SALMON IN LAKE CHAMPLAINAWARD PURPOSE -IN THIS PROJECT, WILL USE GENETIC MARK-RECAPTURE AND ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY TO TEST DIFFERENT HYPOTHESES RELATED TO THE EFFECTIVENESS OF ATLANTIC SALMON REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS IN THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN BASIN AND TO COLLECT DATA NECESSARY TO DEVELOP A LIFE-CYCLE MODEL THAT WILL BE USED TO GUIDE FUTURE RESTORATION ACTIONS IN THIS REGION. DESPITE ANNUALLY STOCKING APPROXIMATELY 240,000 ATLANTIC SALMON SMOLTS IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN, LIMITED RECRUITMENT FROM NATURAL REPRODUCTION HAS BEEN OBSERVED, WHICH IS ONE OF THE OBJECTIVES SET FORTH BY THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT COOPERATIVE. TO ADDRESS THIS ISSUE, THE LAKE CHAMPLAIN LANDLOCKED ATLANTIC SALMON RIVER-RUN PLAN RECOMMENDS DEVELOPING A LIFE CYCLE MODEL TO UNDERSTAND WHAT FACTORS ARE LIMITING THEIR RECRUITMENT IN DIFFERENT TRIBUTARIES AND TO SET QUANTITATIVE METRICS FOR RESTORATION OF HABITATS. TO DEVELOP THOSE MODELS, ESTIMATES OF OVERWINTER SURVIVAL IN LAKE CHAMPLAIN ARE NEEDED. THE USGS-VT COOP WILL USE GENETIC MARK-RECAPTURE TO ESTIMATE OVERWINTER SURVIVAL. ADDITIONALLY, WILL USE ACOUSTIC TELEMETRY TO OBSERVE JUVENILE SALMON HABITAT USE AND BETTER ESTIMATE CAPTURE PROBABILITY AT THE SPAWNING TRIBUTARIES FOR THE GENETIC MARK-RECAPTURE ANALYSIS. PROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 23-7 31 26PROJECT TITLE: QUANTIFYING PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES IN AQUATIC ENVIRONMENTSTHE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSED WORK IS TO UNDERSTAND THE POTENTIAL TRANSFER AND ACCUMULATION OF PER- AND POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES (PFAS) WITHIN AN AQUATIC FOOD WEB WITH AN ULTIMATE LINK TO HUMAN HEALTH THROUGH CONSUMPTION. THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON A RIVERINE FOOD WEB THAT HAS BEEN INVADED BY A PREDATORY FISH SPECIES TARGETED BY ANGLERS FOR SPORT. AS THE PREDATORY FISH (FLATHEAD CATFISH) IS A FOOD FISH, AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE POTENTIAL HUMAN HEALTH RISK THROUGH CONSUMPTION IS REQUIRED. IN ADDITION, THIS INVASIVE FISH SPECIES HAS THE POTENTIAL TO AFFECT HOW PFAS ACCUMULATE IN OTHER SPORT AND FOOD FISH. THEREFORE, UNDERSTANDING THE EFFECTS OF SPECIES INVASION ON PFAS ACCUMULATION IN OTHER POPULAR SPORTFISH IS IMPORTANT FOR INFORMING RISK ASSESSMENTS FOR FISH CONSUMPTION ADVISORIES. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, KEY COMPARTMENTS OF THE FOOD WEB WILL BE SAMPLED AT RIVERINE SITES WITH AND WITHOUT THE INVASIVE FISH SPECIES PRESENT. THIS APPROACH WILL PROVIDE THE ABILITY TO UNDERSTAND WHETHER THE INVASIVE FISH AFFECTS PFAS ACCUMULATION AND TRANSFER IN THE FOOD WEB. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS STUDY INCLUDE INFORMATION ON HOW PFAS MOVE THROUGH AQUATIC FOOD WEBS, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FISH SPECIES, THAT CAN BE DIRECTLY USED TO INFORM DECISIONS RELATED TO HUMAN HEALTH THROUGH FISH CONSUMPTION ADVISORIES AND FISHERIES MANAGEMENT. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE BROADER SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, WATER AND FISHERIES MANAGERS, AND THE PUBLIC BY CONTRIBUTING NEW INSIGHT ABOUT PFAS IN AQUATIC FOOD WEBS AND RECREATIONALLY IMPORTANT FISHES, INFORMATION ON THE MOLECULAR PATHWAYS INVOLVED IN THE RESPONSE OF WILD FISHES TO PFAS, AND BY INCREASING PUBLIC AWARENESS OF PFAS IN AQUATIC ENVIRONMENTS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 7 13 23-7 31 25PROJECT TITLE: EXTENDING THE UNDERSTANDING OF PUBLIC ACCEPTANCE AND PREFERENCES FOR CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION IN THE MID-WESTCLIMATE CHANGE HAS THE POTENTIAL TO CHANGE THE KINDS AND NUMBERS OF FISH AND WILDLIFE THAT ARE AVAILABLE FOR RECREATIONISTS SUCH AS HUNTERS, ANGLERS, AND BIRDWATCHERS.  WHILE HAVE SOME KNOWLEDGE ABOUT WHAT CHANGES MIGHT LOOK LIKE CONCERNING DIFFERENT FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES, VERY LITTLE INFORMATION IS KNOWN ABOUT HOW THE GENERAL PUBLIC, ANGLERS, HUNTERS, AND WILDLIFE WATCHERS MIGHT VIEW SUCH CHANGES IN THE AREAS THAT THEY RECREATE.  ALSO KNOW VERY LITTLE ABOUT SUCH USERS ATTITUDES TOWARD POTENTIAL MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AND STRATEGIES FOR ADAPTING TO POTENTIAL CLIMATE CHANGE THAT AFFECTS FISH AND WILDLIFE.  THIS STUDY WILL ANALYZE EXISTING DATA TO PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION ABOUT PUBLIC ACCEPTANCE AND PREFERENCE FOR CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES IN THE MIDWEST. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - WILL ANALYZE DATA COLLECTED FROM SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGICAL FRAMING EXPERIMENTS WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF WEB-BASED SOCIAL SURVEYS.  ANALYSES WILL ILLUMINATE THE ROLE OF PERCEPTIONS OF POTENTIAL BENEFITS IN THE ACCEPTANCE AND PREFERENCE FOR MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES.  THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS STUDY ARE TO:  1) USE EXISTING DATA AND THEORY-BASED, EXPERIMENTAL SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGICAL ANALYTICAL METHODS TO IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF THE STABILITY OF PUBLIC PREFERENCES FOR CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES  2) IDENTIFY THE KEY ANTECEDENTS AND CONSEQUENCES OF THE STRENGTH AND STABILITY OF THESE PREFERENCES FOR CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES 3) DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ENGAGING THE PUBLIC AND STAKEHOLDERS IN DEVELOPING CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -WILL DRAFT A MANUSCRIPT INTENDED FOR PEER-REVIEW PUBLICATION IN A LEADING SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL FOCUSED ON THE TOPIC OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT. WILL PROVIDE SUMMARY PRESENTATIONS TO FEDERAL AND STATE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES HIGHLIGHTING THE FINDINGS OF THE STUDY AS WELL AS MAKE AT LEAST ONE PRESENTATION AT A NATIONAL OR INTERNATIONAL SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  THE MANUSCRIPT WILL BENEFIT THE CLIMATE ADAPTATION SCIENCE CENTERS AND ITS PARTNER FEDERAL AND STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES.   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -N A

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 8 23-9 30 26PROJECT TITLE: CHEMICAL AND FUNCTIONAL CHARACTERIZATION OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE PRION INACTIVATION RESIDUES TOIMPROVE CARCASS DISPOSAL CHEMICAL AND FUNCTIONAL CHARACTERIZATION OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE PRION INACTIVATION RESIDUES TO IMPROVE CARCASS DISPOSAL PRIONS ARE EXTRAORDINARILY RESISTANT TO CHEMICAL AND PHYSICAL DEGRADATION, AND, AS SUCH, ARE EXTRAORDINARILY ENVIRONMENTALLY PERSISTENT. THIS CREATES AN ADDITIONAL PROBLEM - THE SAFE DISPOSAL OF PRION CONTAMINATED CARCASSES IS A FRAUGHT UNDERTAKING.  CURRENTLY, SEVERAL VIABLE OPTIONS EXIST FOR SUCH DISPOSAL, BUT THE MOST CONVENIENT, INCINERATION, HAS NOT BEEN VERIFIED AS EFFECTIVE WHEN USING MOBILE INCINERATORS. FURTHERMORE, THE DEGRADATION PRODUCTS OF PRIONS RESULTING FROM ANY OF THESE METHODS HAVE NOT BEEN EXTENSIVELY CHARACTERIZED. THE AIMS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO FILL BOTH OF THESE KNOWLEDGE GAPS. FIRST, WILL ASSESS THE EFFICACY OF INCINERATION AS A MEANS OF PRION DECONTAMINATION USING THE REAL-TIME QUAKING INDUCED CONVERSION (RT-QUIC) ASSAY. LABORATORY SCALE TRIALS (WITH EXTENSIVE CHARACTERIZATION OF BOTH ASH AND VAPOR PRODUCTS) WILL BE CONDUCTED INITIALLY, FOLLOWED BY INCINERATION OF FULL CARCASSES. FINALLY, WILL ASSESS THE BREAKDOWN PRODUCTS OF PRIONS USING CRYO-ELECTRON MICROSCOPY, LC-MS MS, AND ANTIBODY EPITOPE MAPPING. THIS WILL OFFER INSIGHT INTO THE ULTIMATE FATE OF PRIONS, AND IDENTIFY ANY INCOMPLETE OR NOXIOUS PRODUCTS RESULTING FROM CHEMICAL OR PHYSICAL DEGRADATION OF PRIONS BY ARTIFICIAL MEANS.

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 23-7 31 24PROJECT TITLE: INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OF SERICEA LESPEDEZA ON FORT RILEYSERICEA LESPEDEZA IS A PERENNIAL SHRUB LISTED AS A NOXIOUS WEED IN THE STATE OF KANSAS. INTENTIONAL ESTABLISHMENT FOR CONSERVATION PURPOSES PRIOR TO LISTING IS ASSOCIATED WITH DENSE SERICEA LESPEDEZA STANDS THAT DISPLACE NATIVE AND OR DESIRABLE SPECIES. SHIFTS IN PLANT SPECIES CAN ALSO HINDER LAND USE FOR A VARIETY OF ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING AGRICULTURE, CONSERVATION, RECREATION, AND TRAINING.CHEMICAL MANAGEMENT OF SERICEA LESPEDEZA TYPICALLY INCLUDES EARLY SUMMER APPLICATIONS OF TRICLOPYR (REMEDY, OTHERS) OR TRICLOPYR PLUS FLUROXYPYR (PASTUREGARD) OR EARLY FALL APPLICATIONS OF METSULFURON (ESCORT, OTHERS). SOME RESEARCH SUGGESTS THAT THE TIME OF PRESCRIBED BURNING CAN BE OPTIMIZED FOR SERICEA LESPEDEZA CONTROL  HOWEVER ADDITIONAL DATA ARE NEEDED TO FULLY UNDERSTAND THIS PRACTICE. IN ADDITION, THERE IS LIMITED PUBLISHED RESEARCH AND NO BROADLY ACCEPTED RECOMMENDATION FOR INCORPORATING BURNING AND HERBICIDES. THE INVASION OF SERICEA LESPEDEZA AT FT. RILEY HAS BEEN DOCUMENTED FOR A NUMBER OF YEARS. MANAGEMENT TACTICS HAVE INCLUDED BOTH HERBICIDE APPLICATIONS AND PRESCRIBED BURNING, WITH BURNING OCCURRING AT A RANGE OF TIMES THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. HOWEVER, ADDITIONAL WORK IS NEEDED TO IDENTIFY THE COMBINATION OF PRACTICES THAT WILL BEST MANAGE THE INVASION WITHOUT INTERFERING WITH LAND USE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES ARE (1) MONITOR THE RESPONSE OF SERICEA LESPEDEZA PLANTS AND SEEDS TO PRESCRIBED BURNS THROUGHOUT THE GROWING SEASON  (2) EVALUATE THE CONTROL BENEFITS OF TREATING SERICEA LESPEDEZA REGROWTH WITH SELECTED HERBICIDES  AND (3) EXAMINE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN EXISTING PLANT BIOMASS, SOIL TEMPERATURE, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AND SERICEA LESPEDEZA RESPONSE TO FIRE AND HERBICIDES.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES - PRELIMINARY REPORT OF FIRST YEAR FINDINGS JULY 2024.  AT LEAST 1 MANUSCRIPT WILL BE SUBMITTED TO A SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL  PRESENTATIONS AT PROFESSIONAL, AGENCY, AND OTHER MEETINGS  AND AVAILABLE INPUTS WHEN REQUESTED FOR CONSERVATION PLANNING AND POLICY DEVELOPMENT. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  FORT RILEY AND THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE WILL BE PROVIDED WITH AN ASSESSMENT THE POTENTIAL TO CONTROL SERICEA LESPEDEZA ON THE INSTALLATION, WHICH WILL INFORM CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO PREVENT CONTINUED INVASION.  THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND PARKS WILL GAIN INFORMATION ON CONTROL OF SERICEA IN THE FLINT HILLS OF KANSAS. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD  N A

PROJECT PERIOD: 8 1 23-7 31 25PROJECT TITLE: STATUS OF NATIVE BUMBLE BEES (BOMBUS SPP.) AT FORT RILEY MILITARY RESERVATION, KANSASALTERATION OF THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT AND UNSUSTAINABLE USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO SUPPORT INCREASING HUMAN POPULATION AND DEVELOPMENT IS THREATENING GLOBAL BIODIVERSITY AND PROVISIONING OF ECOLOGICAL GOODS AND SERVICES.  BUMBLEBEES (APIDAE: BOMBINI) ARE VITAL POLLINATORS FOR AGRICULTURAL AND WILD PLANTS WORLDWIDE.  POLLINATION SERVICES PROVIDED BY THE  250 SPECIES OF BUMBLEBEES IS PARTICULAR CRITICAL IN GRASSLANDS WHERE  60  OF PLANTS DEPEND ON INSECTS TO REPRODUCE.  IT HAS BEEN ESTIMATED THAT  25  OF NORTH AMERICAN BUMBLEBEE SPECIES ARE CONSIDERED AT RISK FOR EXTINCTION, WHICH BE AFFECTING PLANT COMMUNITY DYNAMICS IN GRASSLANDS (HTTPS:  WWW.XERCES.ORG ENDANGERED-SPECIES SPECIES-PROFILES BUMBLE-BEES).  BUMBLEBEES ARE THE PRIMARY POLLINATOR FOR WILDFLOWERS AND OTHER FORBS IN THE GREAT PLAINS, WHICH CONTRIBUTE MOST TO SPECIES RICHNESS AND DIVERSITY AND EXHIBIT THE GREATEST RESPONSES TO DISTURBANCE AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE IN THE BIOME. ABOUT ONE-THIRD OF GREAT PLAINS NATIVE BEE SPECIES ARE SPECIALISTS REGARDING THE FAMILY OF PLANTS THEY VISIT FOR POLLEN AND TWO-THIRDS ARE GENERALISTS. UNFORTUNATELY, LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE ECOLOGY, DIVERSITY, ABUNDANCE, AND LIFE HISTORIES OF BUMBLEBEES IN THE GREAT PLAINS, ESPECIALLY THE TALLGRASS PRAIRIE, WHICH IS CONSIDERED ONE OF THE MOST ENDANGERED ECOSYSTEMS IN WORLD ( 4  REMAINING INTACT TALLGRASS PRAIRIE).  THERE IS A LACK OF BEE RESEARCH IN NATIVE GRASSLAND, ESPECIALLY THE TALLGRASS PRAIRIE OF THE GREAT PLAINS.  FORT RILEY IS A 40,725 HA ARMY INSTALLATION IN THE NORTHERN FLINT HILLS OF KANSAS. FORT RILEY IS A 40,725 HA ARMY INSTALLATION IN THE NORTHERN FLINT HILLS OF KANSAS. THE GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO INVESTIGATE THE ECOLOGY OF NATIVE BEES ON FORT RILEY MILITARY INSTALLATION.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES ARE (1) ASSESS SPECIES RICHNESS, DIVERSITY, AND OCCURRENCE OF NATIVE BEES, (2) ESTIMATE ABUNDANCE AND DENSITY OF NATIVE BEE POPULATIONS, (3) RELATE FLORAL COLONY TYPE, AREA, AND LOCATION TO NATIVE BEE OCCURRENCE AND ABUNDANCE, AND (4) EVALUATE THE EFFECT OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON THE OCCURRENCE AND ABUNDANCE OF NATIVE BEES.    DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES - ANNUAL REPORTS 1 OCTOBER 2023, 2024  FINAL REPORT 31 DECEMBER 2025.  AT LEAST 2 MANUSCRIPTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS  ANNUAL PROFESSIONAL PRESENTATIONS AT PROFESSIONAL, AGENCY, AND OTHER MEETINGS  AND AVAILABLE INPUTS WHEN REQUEST FOR CONSERVATION PLANNING AND POLICY DEVELOPMENT.  THE RESULTS FROM THESE EFFORTS WILL BE PART OF AN EFFORT TO DEVELOP A RIGOROUS MONITORING PROGRAM FOR NATIVE BEES ON THE INSTALLATION. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  FORT RILEY AND THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE WILL BE PROVIDED WITH A COMPREHENSIVE ASSESSMENT OF BUMBLE BEE POPULATIONS ON THE INSTALLATION, WHICH WILL INFORM CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS SHOULD THE STATUS OF ANY BEE SPECIES CHANGE.  THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND PARKS WILL GAIN INFORMATION ON THE OCCURRENCE, STATUS, AND DENSITY OF BUMBLE BEES IN THE FLINT HILLS OF KANSAS. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD  N A

PROJECT PERIOD: 6 22 23-7 31 28PROJECT TITLE: EFFECTS OF WOODY ENCROACHMENT AND MANAGEMENT ON GRASSLAND BIRDS IN NEBRASKA S SANDHILLS AWARD PURPOSE - LOSS OF GRASSLAND HABITAT TO WOODY ENCROACHMENT IS WIDESPREAD AND ONGOING IN THE SANDHILLS. MANY GRASSLAND-OBLIGATE BIRD SPECIES APPEAR TO NOT USE ENCROACHED AREAS, ALTHOUGH EXACT TOLERANCE LEVELS ARE NOT KNOWN. LONG- AND SHORT-TERM EFFECTS OF WOODY ENCROACHMENT REMOVAL AND CONTROL HAVE NOT YET BEEN DETERMINED. MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN BREEDING BIRDS AND WOODY ENCROACHMENT CAN HELP OUR PARTNERSHIP BE MORE EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE WHEN TAKING ACTIONS INTENDED TO BENEFIT DECLINING SPECIES. THE PROPOSED STUDY WILL HELP PARTNERS IN CONSERVATION BETTER PRIORITIZE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO MAXIMIZE THE BENEFITS TO PRIORITY BREEDING BIRDS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS TO COUNT BIRDS DETECTED THROUGH SIGHT AND SOUND BETWEEN MARCH 20APRIL 30 FOR PRAIRIE GROUSE AND MAY 27JULY 7 FOR SONGBIRDS FOLLOWING THE USGS BREEDING BIRD SURVEY. A LINE TRANSECT WILL BE DESIGNATED AT EACH SITE WITH POINT-COUNT LOCATIONS 200 M APART. FIELD-BASED VEGETATION CHARACTERISTICS (E.G., LITTER DEPTH, AND GRASS HEIGHT AND DENSITY) WILL BE ASSESSED AT EACH POINT-COUNT LOCATION. TREES AND SHRUBS WITHIN 100 M OF THE POINT-COUNT LOCATION WILL BE COUNTED.  WILL USE DATA FROM ALL BIRD SPECIES FOR THE ANALYSES, AS RARE OR UNCOMMON SPECIES MAY BE SENSITIVE TO HABITAT CHANGES, THOUGH WILL FOCUS ON PRIORITY SPECIES (DICKCISSEL, EASTERN MEADOWLARK, GRASSHOPPER SPARROW, GREATER PRAIRIE-CHICKEN, SHARP-TAILED GROUSE, AND WESTERN MEADOWLARK) FOR EVALUATIONS OF SPECIES RESPONSE TO ERC EXPANSION AND TREATMENT. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -PHD STUDENT DISSERTATION AND FINAL REPORT (JULY 2028)DATA WILL BE PUBLISHED ON USGS DATA REPOSITORY  SCIENCEBASE, .CVS FORMAT.DATA GENERATED BY THIS PROJECT CAN BE TRANSLATED INTO GEOSPATIAL DECISION SUPPORT TOOLS TO HELP MANAGERS TARGET AREAS FOR TREATMENT THAT MAXIMIZE BENEFITS FOR GRASSLAND BIRDS. PROJECT TITLE: ENVIRONMENTAL DNA SURVEILLANCE OF MUSSEL COMMUNITIES IN THE HATCHIE RIVER, TENNESSEEPROJECT PERIOD: JULY 18, 2023, THROUGH SEPTEMBER 30, 2024 PROJECT ABSTRACT: RECIPIENT PROPOSES A THREE-YEAR PROJECT TO UPDATE FRESHWATER MUSSEL DISTRIBUTIONS IN THE HATCHIE RIVER AND MEASURE AND MODEL THE PHYSICAL HABITAT OF THE RIVER IN REGARD TO ITS SUITABILITY FOR FRESHWATER MUSSELS. FRESHWATER MUSSELS ARE ONE OF THE MOST IMPERILED FAUNAL GROUPS, AND APPROXIMATELY 70  OF NORTH AMERICAN MUSSEL SPECIES ARE ENDANGERED, THREATENED, OR OF SPECIAL CONCERN.  WITHIN RECENT DECADES, RESTORATION EFFORTS HAVE ATTEMPTED TO RESTORE STREAM AND FLOODPLAIN FUNCTION TO A MORE NATURAL STATE AND PROVIDE FUNCTIONAL LIFT TO MANY STREAM SYSTEMS.  RECIPIENT WILL COMPILE HISTORICAL FRESHWATER MUSSEL RECORDS FROM THE HATCHIE RIVER DRAINAGE FROM VARIOUS ENTITIES.  RECIPIENT ANTICIPATES THAT HISTORICAL AND FIELD-COLLECTED MUSSEL DATA WILL HIGHLIGHT THE LOCATION, RICHNESS, AND RELATIVE DENSITY OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE HATCHIE RIVER.   SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1. UPDATE THE DISTRIBUTION OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE HATCHIE RIVER DRAINAGE THROUGH FIELD SURVEYS. 2. DESCRIBE HYDROLOGIC AND GEOMORPHIC CHARACTERISTICS ASSOCIATED WITH MUSSEL CONCENTRATIONS THROUGH PHYSICAL HABITAT MEASUREMENTS AND MODELING USING AERIAL IMAGERY AND REMOTELY SENSED DATA. 3. INVESTIGATE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN MUSSEL PRESENCE AND METRICS USED TO DETERMINE THE SUCCESSFULNESS OF RESTORATION ACTIVITIES IN WT. 4. DETERMINE IF RESTORATION ACTIVITIES IN WT (E.G., FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY) ARE ASSOCIATED WITH THE REMAINING CLUSTERS OF FRESHWATER MUSSEL ASSEMBLAGES IN THE HATCHIE RIVER.    DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES RECIPIENT ANTICIPATES THAT HISTORICAL AND FIELD-COLLECTED MUSSEL DATA WILL HIGHLIGHT THE LOCATION, RICHNESS, AND RELATIVE DENSITY OF FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE HATCHIE RIVER.  TYPICALLY, FRESHWATER MUSSELS OCCUR IN DISTINCT AGGREGATIONS, ALLOWING SIMULTANEOUS COLLECTION OF MULTIPLE SPECIES OVER A RANGE OF SIZES IN MUSSEL BEDS THROUGH TIME-VISUAL SURVEYS OF CHANNELS AND GRAVEL BARS. LOCATIONS OF HIGHER MUSSEL DENSITIES CAN BE ATTRIBUTED WITH DATA CORRESPONDING TO HYDROGEOMORPHIC CHARACTERISTICS OF THE HATCHIE RIVER. DELIVERABLES REPORTING  COLLECTED DATA WILL BE COMPILED AND SHARED WITH WTRBA ANNUALLY. EACH YEARS DATA WILL BE AGGREGATED WITH PAST DATA FOR EACH SUBSEQUENT ANNUAL REPORT.  OUTREACH  FINDINGS WILL BE SHARED AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES WITH EMPHASIS ON THE RELEVANT AUDIENCE BUT FOCUSING ON NATIVE MUSSEL SURVEYS AND IDENTIFYING HABITAT.  PUBLICATION  CONTRIBUTORS WILL COLLABORATE TO PUBLISH RESULTS IN AT LEAST ONE PROFESSIONAL PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL.   INTENDED BENEFICIARIES -U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE (FISH PASSAGE AND AQUATIC CONNECTIVITY)  TENNESSEE WILDLIFE RESOURCES AGENCY (TWRA NON-GAME SPECIES) US ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (PINEY CREEK CAP 206)  THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (AUSTIN FOUNDATION GRANT)  UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE INSTITUTE OF AGRICULTURE (LONE OAKS FARM)

PROJECT TITLE: YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL RANGE-WIDE ASSESSMENT AND CONSERVATIONPROJECT PERIOD: JUNE 08, 2023 THROUGH APRIL 30, 2026ABSTRACT -THE YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL, LAMPSILIS CARIOSA, IS A FRESHWATER MUSSEL THAT IS LOCALLY DESIGNATED AS ENDANGERED, THREATENED, OR A SPECIAL STATUS IN EIGHT U.S. STATES AND TWO CANADIAN PROVINCES. AS WITH MANY FRESHWATER MUSSEL SPECIES, YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL MONITORING, ASSESSMENT, AND CONSERVATION PLANNING OCCURS PRIMARILY WITHIN LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS, WITH LITTLE INTERACTION OUTSIDE GEOGRAPHIC BOUNDARIES. ADDITIONALLY, CONTEMPORARY YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL SURVEYS ARE LIMITED AND NOT STANDARDIZED, MAKING IT DIFFICULT TO ASSESS ITS RANGE-WIDE DISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION STATUS. TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS, THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH A YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL WORKING GROUP OF STATE, FEDERAL, ACADEMIC, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL PARTNERS TO INCREASE RANGE-WIDE COOPERATION, RESEARCH, AND STRATEGIC PLANNING OF CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION EFFORTS. RESEARCH WILL BE CONDUCTED AT THE MASSACHUSETTS AND MAINE COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNITS, AND INCLUDE EXISTING DATA COMPILATION AND MULTI-SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELLING, FINE-SCALE HABITAT ASSESSMENTS IN LARGE RIVERS, AND HOST FISH ASSESSMENT. ULTIMATELY, THE PROJECT AIMS TO INFORM AND GUIDE CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION PLANNING FOR YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -1) ASSESSING LANDSCAPE-SCALE THREATS AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL RESTORATION SITES FOR YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL ACROSS ITS RANGE USING A MULTI-SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODEL.2) ASSESSING THE SUITABILITY OF STRIPED B.ASS (MORONE SAXATILIS) AS HOST FISH FOR YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL WITH FIELD COLLECTIONS AND LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS3) ASSESSING HABITAT FOR YLM AND POTENTIAL LOCATIONS FOR YLM SURVEYS AND RESTORATION USING SIDE-SCAN SONAR IN THREE RIVERS.4) ESTABLISHING AN INTERAGENCY YLM WORKING GROUP COMPRISED OF MUSSEL EXPERTS AND MANAGERS   DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -RESULTS OF THE RESEARCH WILL BE SHARED IN SCIENTIFIC, PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL MANUSCRIPTS AND ASSOCIATED DATA RELEASES. RECIPIENT WILL ALSO DEVELOP A WEBSITE AND CREATE A GOOGLE DRIVE FOR SHARING INFORMATION AMONG PARTNERS. THIS RESEARCH ADDRESSES AGENCY AND DEPARTMENT PRIORITIES FOR PROACTIVE, SCIENCE-BASED CONSERVATION OF YELLOW LAMPMUSSEL PRIOR TO LISTING DECISIONS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES -U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICESTATE AGENCIES WITHIN THE SPECIES RANGE (ATLANTIC COAST: GEORGIA TO MAINE)FISHERIES AND OCEANS CANADA SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -THE ACTIVITIES WILL BE PERFORMED BY THE MASSACHUSETTS AND MAINE COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNITS. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS.

PROJECT TITLE: IDENTIFYING THE GENETIC MARKER FOR DIAMOND DARTER EDNA APPLICATIONS AND CONDUCTING AN EVALUATION OF ITS EFFECTIVENESSPROJECT PERIOD: 06 01 2023 - 12 31 2025THE DIAMOND DARTER, AN ENDANGERED FISH, WAS PREVIOUSLY KNOWN TO OCCUR IN A WIDE RANGE WITHIN THE OHIO RIVER WATERSHED, BUT THIS FISH IS CURRENTLY ONLY KNOWN TO EXIST IN THE ELK RIVER DRAINAGE, WEST VIRGINIA. THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO DEVELOP AN EDNA MARKER THAT WILL ALLOW FOR DOCUMENTING THE PRESENCE OF THIS FISH WITHIN RIVERS OF ITS RANGE THROUGH DNA ANALYSIS OF RIVER WATER SAMPLES.ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE (1) IDENTIFYING A GENETIC MARKER FOR DIAMOND DARTER EDNA APPLICATIONS, AND (2) CONDUCTING AN EVALUATION OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF EDNA FOR DETECTING DIAMOND DARTER PRESENCE.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE (1) EDNA GENETIC MARKERS FOR THE DIAMOND DARTER, AND (2) AN ASSESSMENT AND DOCUMENTATION OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE EDNA MARKERS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICEWEST VIRGINIA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCESTHERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES SPECIFIED.

PROJECT PERIOD: 5 4 23-9 30 26PROJECT TITLE: GENETIC CAUSES OF MELANOMAS IN LAKE MEMPHREMAGOG BROWN BULLHEADTHE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND IF THERE IS A LINK BETWEEN CONTAMINANTS AND GENETICS IN THE EXPRESSION OF LAKE MEMPHREMAGOG BROWN BULLHEAD INVASIVE MELANOMA. IN 2012, THE VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFE DEPARTMENT (VFWD) BEGAN TO RECEIVE REPORTS FROM ANGLERS OF AN ABNORMAL BLACK SKIN PIGMENTATION ON BROWN BULLHEAD AMEIURUS NEBULOSUS (BRB) IN LAKE MEMPHREMAGOG, WHICH IS A LARGE LAKE THAT SPANS THE BORDER BETWEEN VERMONT AND QUEBEC. POTENTIAL HYPOTHESES REGARDING THE RISK FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH THESE LESIONS INCLUDE EXPOSURE TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANTS, GENETICS, VIRUSES, AND INTERACTIONS OF THESE STRESSORS. A POTENTIAL SOURCE OF CONTAMINANTS IS A 128-ACRE LANDFILL AT THE SOUTHERN END OF THE LAKE THAT IS THE ONLY SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL FACILITY OPERATING IN VERMONT. HYPOTHESIZE THAT SOME OF THE BROWN BULLHEAD IN LAKE MEMPHREMAGOG ARE MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO INDUCTION OF MELANOMAS EITHER DUE TO SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION THROUGHOUT THE LAKE, GENETICS AND OR EXPOSURE DURING EARLY LIFE STAGES. WILL USE GENOMIC ANALYSIS TO UNDERSTAND THE CAUSES OF THE EXPRESSION OF THESE MELANOMAS IN BROWN BULLHEAD, WHICH COULD HELP US TO IDENTIFY THEIR SOURCE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - ELECTROFISHING TO COLLECT FISH AT MULTIPLE SITES IN LAKE MEMPHREMAGOGCOLLECTION OF WATER SAMPLES FOR WATER QUALITY ANALYSIS (E.G., POLYFLUOROALKYL SUBSTANCES AND PESTICIDES)GENOME SEQUENCING BIOINFORMATIC ANALYSIS OF GENE EXPRESSION OF DISEASED AND NON-DISEASED FISH DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORT FINAL REPORT ONE PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONEXPECT TO IDENTIFY WHETHER THE EXPRESSION OF THESE MELANOMAS IS RELATED TO BROWN BULLHEAD GENETICS AND IF THERE IS AN EPIGENETIC COMPONENT (I.E., GENE EXPRESSION BASED ON ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS). ARE ALSO TESTING WHETHER THERE IS A VIRAL CAUSE USING HISTOPATHOLOGY IN ANOTHER RWO. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -VERMONT FISH AND WILDLIFERECREATIONAL ANGLERS ON LAKE MEMPHREMAGOGDONT UNDERMINE MEMPHREMAGOGS PURITY (DUMP)  ENVIRONMENTAL GROUP SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -JULIE DRAGONS LAB IN THE UVM DEPARTMENT OF MICROBIOLOGY AND MOLECULAR GENETICS WILL CONDUCT THE GENOMIC SEQUENCING.

PROJECT TITLE: IDENTIFYING REMAINING CRITICAL DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION GAPS AND DEVELOPING A FULL ANNUAL CYCLE POPULATION MODEL FOR CERULEAN WARBLERSPROJECT PERIOD: 05 01 2023 - 12 31 2025 PROJECT ABSTRACT: CERULEAN WARBLERS (SETOPHAGA CERULEA) HAVE EXHIBITED MULTI-DECADAL, RANGE-WIDE DECLINES IN ABUNDANCE, CAUSING CONCERN FOR THEIR LONG-TERM PERSISTENCE. THREATS TO THE SPECIES LIKELY OCCUR ACROSS THEIR ANNUAL CYCLE, FROM INADEQUATE LANDSCAPE-SCALE (FOREST COVER AND FRAGMENTATION) AND FINER-SCALE (E.G., LACK OF CANOPY HETEROGENEITY) FOREST STRUCTURE ON THEIR BREEDING GROUNDS TO REMOVAL OR DEGRADATION OF MID-ELEVATION FORESTED HABITAT ON WINTERING GROUNDS AND DEGRADATION LOSS OF STOPOVER HABITATS IN BETWEEN. AS A RESULT, AN ASSESSMENT OF THE SPECIES POPULATION DYNAMICS ACROSS THE FULL ANNUAL CYCLE (FAC) IS NECESSARY TO UNDERSTAND THE RELATIVE ROLE DIFFERENT TEMPORAL STAGES AND SPECIFIC LOCATIONS PLAY IN DETERMINING STATUS AND TREND, AND TO IDENTIFY REMAINING CRITICAL KNOWLEDGE GAPS FOR TARGETED SPECIES RESEARCH FOR CONSERVATION ACTION. IN THE PAST 20 YEARS, MUCH RESEARCH ON THE SPECIES HAS RESULTED IN ESTIMATES OF MANY POPULATION-SPECIFIC DEMOGRAPHIC RATES THAT COULD BE USED TO IDENTIFY LIMITING LIFE STAGES AND DECLINING POPULATIONS  HOWEVER, THIS WORK HAS NEVER BEEN SYNTHESIZED. FROM THIS PAST RESEARCH, RECIPIENT WILL BE ABLE TO CONSTRUCT BASIC FAC MODELS TO DETERMINE WHETHER SUFFICIENT DATA HAS BEEN GATHERED TO ACHIEVE THOSE AIMS. HOWEVER, SOME PARAMETERS IN THESE MODELS WILL BE LACKING IN EMPIRICAL DATA, BUT THROUGH THIS PROCESS RECIPIENT WILL BE ABLE TO BETTER IDENTIFY CRITICAL DATA GAPS AND SUBSEQUENTLY COLLECT INFORMATION TO CREATE A MORE RIGOROUS FAC MODEL. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -  RECIPIENT PROPOSES TO USE EXISTING DATASETS ON CERULEAN WARBLER DEMOGRAPHY, AS WELL AS NEWLY COLLECTED TARGETED MONITORING DATA TO ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES:1. USE MULTIPLE DATA SOURCES (EBIRD BREEDING BIRD SURVEY TRENDS, GEOGRAPHIC ISOLATION, MIGRATORY CONNECTIVITY, AND GENOMICS) TO DELIMIT BIOLOGICALLY DISTINCT POPULATIONS OF CERULEAN WARBLERS.2. DEVELOP THE STRUCTURE OF A SEX- AND AGE-EXPLICIT FAC POPULATION MODEL THAT WOULD ULTIMATELY IDENTIFY THE DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETER(S) DRIVING TRENDS WITHIN IDENTIFIED POPULATIONS.3. IDENTIFY POPULATION-SPECIFIC DATA GAPS IN CERULEAN WARBLER DEMOGRAPHIC RATES ACROSS THE FAC.4. FIT POPULATION MODELS (USING EXPERT OPINION TO FILL IN MISSING DATA WHERE NECESSARY) AND CONDUCT A SENSITIVITY ANALYSIS TO PRIORITIZE FUTURE DATA COLLECTION ON DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS THAT EXERT THE GREATEST INFLUENCE ON POPULATION GROWTH RATES.5. GAIN NEW INFORMATION ON HABITAT-DEPENDENT OVERWINTER SURVIVAL IN THE ANDES AND ON FEMALE ECOLOGY AND DEMOGRAPHY TO HELP FILL TWO KNOWN CRITICAL INFORMATION GAPS. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -DELIVERABLES INCLUDE:COMPILED DATABASE OF ALL GATHERED PUBLISHED DEMOGRAPHIC ESTIMATES AND DATASETSESTIMATES OF POPULATION-SPECIFIC TRENDS IN ABUNDANCE AND ADULT SURVIVAL FROM SIMPLE INTEGRATED POPULATION MODELLIST OF POPULATION-SPECIFIC FUTURE DATA COLLECTION PRIORITIESESTIMATES OF OVERWINTERING AND FEMALE BREEDING SURVIVALRECIPIENT EXPECTS THAT THIS PROJECT WILL LEAD TO BETTER TARGETS FOR DATA COLLECTION AND PLANS OF WHICH POPULATIONS AND LIFE STAGES TO TARGET FOR HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND OTHER CONSERVATION MEASURES. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD SUBRECIPIENTS WILL BE CONDUCTING FIELDWORK TO ESTIMATE SURVIVAL (OBJECTIVE 5).

PROJECT TITLE: JUVENILE SALMON GROWTH RESPONSE TO WATER TEMPERATURE AND THERMAL STRESSPROJECT PERIOD: JUNE 01, 2023 THROUGH DECEMBER 31, 2025PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY  INCLUDE A PLAIN LANGUAGE DESCRIPTION AWARD PURPOSE (AVOID ACRONYMS OR FEDERAL OR AGENCY-SPECIFIC TERMINOLOGY) - THE PURPOSE OF THIS RESEARCH IS TO UNDERSTAND HOW JUVENILE SALMON GROWTH IN FRESHWATER HABITATS IS INFLUENCED BY WATER TEMPERATURES AND THERMAL STRESS. THE SAMPLE COLLECTION FOR THIS PROJECT IS ON CHINOOK AND COHO SALMON (ONCORHYNCHUS TSHAWYTSCHA AND O. KISUTCH, RESPECTIVELY) IN AND AROUND THE DESHKA RIVER, A CULTURALLY, ECOLOGICALLY, AND ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT SALMON FISHERY IN SOUTH-CENTRAL ALASKA. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - THIS RESEARCH WILL BE THE THESIS PROJECT FOR A MASTERS STUDENT IN FISHERIES AT THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS. RESEARCH WILL FOCUS PRINCIPALLY ON EXISTING DATA FOR ANALYSIS. RECIPIENT WILL ESTIMATE RECENT GROWTH FROM JUVENILE SALMON OTOLITHS AND FEEDING SUCCESS FROM STOMACH FULLNESS FOR ANALYSIS WITH EXISTING WATER TEMPERATURE AND THERMAL STRESS DATA. RECENT DAILY GROWTH WILL BE ESTIMATED FROM OTOLITHS EXTRACTED FROM SUBSAMPLES OF JUVENILE CHINOOK AND COHO SALMON. RECIPIENT WILL ESTIMATE STOMACH FULLNESS FROM EACH INDIVIDUAL SUBSAMPLED FOR OTOLITHS TO CHARACTERIZE DIFFERENCES IN FOOD CONSUMPTION. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR A MASTERS STUDENT AT THE ALASKA COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT AND INSTITUTE OF ARCTIC BIOLOGY, UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS. THE STUDENT WILL BE ENROLLED IN A MS PROGRAM IN FISHERIES WITHIN THE COLLEGE OF FISHERIES AND OCEAN SCIENCES. THIS RESEARCH IS ANTICIPATED TO CULMINATE IN AT LEAST ONE SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATION AND MULTIPLE ORAL PRESENTATIONS. ORAL PRESENTATIONS WILL BE GIVEN AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS (E.G., ANNUAL MEETINGS OF THE ALASKA CHAPTER OF THE AMERICAN FISHERIES SOCIETY, NATIONAL AFS, OR OTHERS). DATASETS AND TOOLS GENERATED THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL BE HOUSED ON A PERSISTENT ONLINE DATA REPOSITORY SUCH AS USGS SCIENCEBASE. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT ARE EXPECTED TO BE FISHERIES RESEARCHERS AND MANAGERS FROM THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND PUBLIC FISHERS CONCERNED ABOUT THE EFFECTS OF THERMAL REGIMES AND CLIMATE CHANGE ON SALMON STOCKS. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -NONE SPECIFIED AT THIS TIME.

PROJECT TITLE: SALMON HABITAT AND SHORELINE VULNERABILITY TO RECREATIONAL BOAT WAKES IN BIG LAKE, ALASKAPROJECT PERIOD: 06 01 2023 THROUGH 12 31 2024   PROJECT ABSTRACT -THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO DETERMINE THE EFFECTS OF RECREATIONAL BOAT WAKES IN DEGRADING FRESHWATER HABITATS THAT ARE CRITICAL TO SALMON SPAWNING AND REARING, AND TO DEVELOP EFFECTIVE STRATEGIES TO MITIGATE THIS DEGRADATION, SPECIFICALLY IN BIG LAKE, ALASKA. THE WORK PROPOSED HERE REPRESENTS A FIRST STEP AT UNDERSTANDING AN ISSUE OF EMERGING CONCERN FOR PACIFIC SALMON HABITAT AND IN DEVELOPING A CAUSAL LINKAGE BETWEEN SEDIMENT EROSION, DEPOSITION FROM BOAT WAKES, AND, ULTIMATELY, SALMON SPAWNING SUCCESS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - RECIPIENT WILL ASSESS POTENTIAL BANK EROSION AND TURBIDITY AND SEDIMENTATION INCREASES DUE TO BOAT WAKE IN BIG LAKE, ALASKA. THE EXTENT OF SHORELINE EROSION WILL BE MEASURED USING BANK EROSION PINS. RECIPIENT WILL ALSO INSTALL CREST GAGES (GAGING WELL PIPES CONTAINING PULVERIZED CORK) AS A MEANS OF ASSESSING WAKE HEIGHT AND THEREFORE SHORELINE INUNDATION. RECIPIENT WILL INSTALL A NETWORK OF 48 SONDES THROUGHOUT BIG LAKE THAT ARE EQUIPPED TO MEASURE TURBIDITY TO QUANTIFY POTENTIAL SEDIMENTATION INCREASES ON SALMON SPAWNING HABITATS DUE TO BANK EROSION. RECIPIENT WILL DETERMINE THE EXTENT TO WHICH SEDIMENTATION FROM BANK EROSION IS AFFECTING SALMON SPAWNING BOTH BY EMPIRICALLY QUANTIFYING BED SEDIMENT CHARACTERISTICS USING A DREDGE SAMPLER AND BY MAPPING VISUAL OBSERVATIONS OF SALMON SPAWNING BEHAVIOR THROUGHOUT BIG LAKE. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR A MASTERS STUDENT OR TECHNICIAN AT THE ALASKA COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT AND INSTITUTE OF ARCTIC BIOLOGY, UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA FAIRBANKS. THE STUDENT WILL BE ENROLLED IN A MS PROGRAM IN BIOLOGY WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT OF BIOLOGY AND WILDLIFE OR A MS PROGRAM IN FISHERIES WITHIN THE COLLEGE OF FISHERIES AND OCEAN SCIENCES. RECIPIENT ANTICIPATES THIS RESEARCH WILL CULMINATE IN AT LEAST ONE SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATION AND MULTIPLE ORAL PRESENTATIONS. ORAL PRESENTATIONS WILL BE GIVEN AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS (E.G., ANNUAL MEETINGS OF THE ALASKA CHAPTER OF THE AMERICAN FISHERIES SOCIETY, THE SOCIETY FOR FRESHWATER SCIENCE, OR OTHERS). DATASETS AND TOOLS GENERATED THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL BE HOUSED ON A PERSISTENT ONLINE DATA REPOSITORY SUCH AS USGS SCIENCEBASE. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES -THE PRINCIPAL BENEFICIARIES OF THE RESEARCH CARRIED OUT UNDER THIS AWARD WILL BE MANAGERS AND RESEARCH PERSONNEL ASSOCIATED WITH THE COST-SHARE PROGRAM AND WITH MIXED-USE MANAGEMENT OF BIG LAKE AND SIMILAR AREAS, INCLUDING THE U.S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME. LOCAL LAND OWNERS WHO ARE CONCERNED ABOUT LAKE EROSION ARE ALSO EXPECTED TO BENEFIT FROM THE RESEARCH, AS ARE LAKE RECREATIONISTS. RESEARCHERS INVOLVED WITH LAKE WATER QUALITY, SUCH AS WITHIN THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION, ARE ALSO EXPECTED TO BENEFIT, AS WELL AS FISHERIES RESEARCHERS, MANAGERS, AND FISHERS INTERESTED IN SEDIMENTATION EFFECTS ON SALMON SPAWNING HABITAT. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD -NONE SPECIFIED AT THIS TIME.

PROJECT PERIOD: 4 17 23-3 29 26PROJECT TITLE: CONTAMINATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSTITUENTS WITH CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE PRIONSTHE OBJECTIVES OF OUR PROJECT ARE TO: 1) EXAMINE PRION INTENSITY IN SOILS AND ON PLANTS AT POTENTIAL RESERVOIR SITES AND HOW THESE CHANGE OVER TIME, AND 2) THE CAPACITY FOR PRION UPTAKE AND RETENTION IN PLANT TISSUE.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -  WILL BE COLLECTING SOILS AND PLANTS FROM PRION-CONTAMINATED SITES, AND ANALYZING THESE SAMPLES FOR THE PRESENCE OF PRIONS. IN ADDITION, A VARIETY OF SOILS WILL BE SPIKED WITH PRION-BEARING BIOMATTER, AND USED AS A SUBSTRATE FOR GROWING A VARIETY OF FOOD PLANTS. THESE PLANTS WILL BE SUBSEQUENTLY ANALYZED FOR THE PRESENCE OF PRIONS USING A VARIETY OF METHODS. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -NOVEL OUTCOMES FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: 1). ASSESSMENT OF THE RISK POSED BY WTD INTERACTION WITH PRION CONTAMINATED SCENT MARKING SITES, CWD INFECTED CARCASS SITES AND ANTHROPOGENIC CARCASS DUMP SITES, WHICH WILL INFORM POLICIES SUCH AS THOSE ASSOCIATED WITH CARCASS DISPOSAL AND 2.) A QUANTITATIVE ASSESSMENT OF THE POTENTIAL FOR PLANTS TO ASSIMILATE PRIONS AT ENVIRONMENTALLY RELEVANT CONCENTRATIONS. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -LANDOWNERS, AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS, AND STATE FEDERAL REGULATORY AGENCIES WILL ALL SEE BENEFIT FROM THE PROPOSED WORK. THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL GREATLY ENHANCE THE RISK ASSESSMENT PERSPECTIVES OF CWD CONTAMINATED LANDSCAPES, AND FURTHER ARTICULATE THE RISK POSED BY PRIONS AS RELATED TO FOODBORNE PRION UPTAKE.

PROJECT TITLE  EXPLORING THE EARLY LIFE HISTORY AND HABITAT CONNECTIVITY OF PKUIKUI (ACANTHURUS ACHILLES) AROUND HAWAII ISLAND PROJECT PERIOD  03 29 2023  09 30 2024IN HAWAII, HUNDREDS OF SPECIES ARE CAUGHT IN COMMERCIAL AND NON COMMERCIAL REEF FISHERIES, BUT RELATIVELY LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE BIOLOGY OF MOST OF THESE SPECIES AND THEIR RESPONSES TO EXPLOITATION. ONE SUCH SPECIES IS PKUIKUI, ALSO KNOWN AS THE ACHILLES TANG (ACANTHURUS ACHILLES), WHOSE NUMBERS HAVE RECENTLY AND MYSTERIOUSLY DECLINED IN WEST HAWAII ISLAND. THE STATE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AGENCY EXERCISED ITS ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT RULEMAKING AUTHORITY IN DECEMBER 2022 TO PLACE A 2 YEAR MORATORIUM ON ALL COMMERCIAL AND NON COMMERCIAL TAKE OF PKUIKUI IN WEST HAWAII ISLAND SO THAT THE BASIC BIOLOGY AND CAUSE OF THE COLLAPSE OF THIS FISHS POPULATION CAN BE EXPLORED. ONE SIGNIFICANT KNOWLEDGE GAP IN THIS SPECIES BIOLOGY THAT MAY PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN SHAPING THE PAST AND FUTURE TRAJECTORY OF ITS POPULATION IS ITS EARLY LIFE HISTORY. THEREFORE, THE PROPOSED WORK WILL INVESTIGATE THE LARVAL DISTRIBUTION, RECRUITMENT DYNAMICS, AND RELATIVE CONNECTIVITY OF JUVENILE AND ADULT HABITATS OF PKUIKUI. SCUBA SURVEYS IN EAST HAWAII ISLAND  WHERE PKUIKUI ARE MORE ABUNDANT THAN WEST HAWAII ISLAND  WILL EXPLORE HABITAT REQUIREMENTS AND BEHAVIORS OF NEW RECRUITS AND JUVENILES ACROSS A DEPTH GRADIENT AND ADJACENT TO SHALLOW, ADULT HABITAT. IN ADDITION, TARGETED LIGHT TRAPS AND PLANKTON TOWS WILL BE USED TO UNDERSTAND THE DISTRIBUTION OF LARVAL SURGEONFISHES (ACANTHURIDAE) AND PKUIKUI. THIS STUDYS RESULTS WILL DIRECTLY INFORM THE STATES ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THIS SPECIES, WHICH WILL NEED TO BE REVIEWED IN TWO YEARS, AND WILL SUPPORT A STRUCTURAL DECISION MAKING MODEL THAT IS IN DEVELOPMENT BY COOPERATIVE RESEARCH UNITS STAFF AND STATE RESOURCE MANAGERS.THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CRUCIAL INSIGHT INTO THE BASIC BIOLOGY OF A CULTURALLY IMPORTANT FOOD FISH IN HAWAII, THE PKUIKUI OR ACHILLES TANG (ACANTHURUS ACHILLES), WHOSE NUMBERS HAVE RECENTLY AND MYSTERIOUSLY DECLINED IN WEST HAWAII ISLAND. PROJECT SCIENTISTS WILL WORK DIRECTLY WITH STATE RESOURCE MANAGERS TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT MONITORING OF FISH LARVAE, RECRUITS, AND JUVENILES, WHICH ARE CRITICAL STAGES THAT MAY CONTRIBUTE TO THE DECLINE AND REBOUND OF THIS FISHS POPULATION. THE PROPOSED WORK WILL THUS INFORM THE STATES ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THIS SPECIES IN WEST HAWAII WITHIN THE FIRST TWO YEARS OF THE FISHERYS CLOSURE.PROJECT OUTCOMES WORKING DIRECTLY WITH STATE RESOURCE MANAGERS TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT MONITORING OF CRITICAL LIFE HISTORY STAGES OF A KEY SPECIES OF INTEREST CONCERN. INFORMING THE STATES ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THIS SPECIES IN WEST HAWAII WITHIN THE FIRST TWO YEARS OF THE FISHERYS CLOSURE. SUPPORTING THE STRUCTURAL DECISION MAKING MODEL FRAMEWORK THAT IS CURRENTLY UNDERWAY BY PETERSON, HCFRU, AND DAR. CONTRIBUTING TO OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE BASIC BIOLOGY AND LIFE HISTORY OF A CULTURALLY IMPORTANT FOOD FISH, ESPECIALLY BY LEVERAGING AN ONGOING HCFRU STUDY OF PKUIKUI (GRABOWSKI ET AL. IN PREP). GAIN BASELINE DATA REGARDING DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF LARVAL FISHES IN HILO BAY, INFORMATION THAT DOES NOT EXIST TO DATE BUT STANDS TO INFORM OUR UNDERSTANDING OF POPULATION CONNECTIVITY AND RECRUITMENT DYNAMICS OF DOZENS OF HAWAIIAN REEF FISHES.

PROJECT PERIOD  4 3 2023 12 31 2026PROJECT TITLE  MODELING RAPTOR POPULATION STATUS, TRENDS, AND TAKE RATESEVALUATING SUSTAINABLE TAKE RATES FOR RAPTOR SPECIES, PRIMARILY BALD AND GOLDEN EAGLES, IS NECESSARY TO INFORM INCIDENTAL TAKE PERMITS ISSUED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO PROPOSED AND EXISTING WIND ENERGY FACILITIES. THE TAKE RATES ARE INFORMED BY PREDICTIVE MODELS THAT INCORPORATE SPECIES VITAL RATES (E.G., SURVIVAL), ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS, AND ANTHROPOGENIC HAZARDS (E.G., WIND TURBINES). THE PREDICTIVE MODELS ARE DESIGNED TO ADDRESS FUTURE UNCERTAINTIES, SUCH AS EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON RAPTOR POPULATIONS, AS WELL AS ANTHROPOGENIC FACTORS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON DEVELOPING MODELS THAT INFORM INCIDENTAL TAKE PERMITS, AND ALSO IMPROVE THE MODELS THEMSELVES TO BETTER REFLECT PREDICTED CHANGES IN CLIMATE. LASTLY, GIVEN POTENTIAL UNCERTAINTIES IN FUTURE CONDITION, THE PROPOSED WORK WILL ALSO SEEK TO IDENTIFY RESEARCH PRIORITIES FOR AMERICAN KESTRELS, A SPECIES THAT HAS BEEN DECLINING FOR MULTIPLE DECADES, WITH NO APPARENT CAUSE. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED   1.PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR PROJECT SPECIFIC EAGLE RISK ASSESSMENTS FOR WIND ENERGY FACILITIES AND RAPTOR POPULATION ASSESSMENTS.2.PARTICIPATE IN DEVELOPMENT OF DECISION SUPPORT FRAMEWORKS FOR ESTIMATING ALLOWABLE RAPTOR TAKE LIMITS THAT ACCOUNTS FOR NON STATIONARITY IN CLIMATE AND LAND USE CONDITIONS.3.ASSIST IN DEVELOPING AN INTEGRATED POPULATION MODELING FRAMEWORK TO EXPLORE REGIONAL HYPOTHESES FOR AMERICAN KESTREL DECLINES.4.MAINTAIN A LONG TERM DEMOGRAPHIC STUDY TO ELUCIDATE THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTIONS OF MIGRANTS AND NON MIGRANTS TO RAPTOR POPULATION DYNAMICS IN A CHANGING CLIMATE. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  1.FURTHER DEVELOP A COLLISION RISK MODEL TO INFORM WIND ENERGY PERMITTING DECISIONS FOR RAPTOR SPECIES2.COMPLETE A DECISION SUPPORT FRAMEWORK FOR IDENTIFYING RESEARCH PRIORITIES TO ADDRESS AMERICAN KESTREL DECLINES3.FURTHER DEVELOP A SET OF INTEGRATED POPULATION MODELS FOR MULTIPLE RAPTOR SPECIES THAT INCORPORATE NONSTATIONARY EFFECTS OF CLIMATE. PROJECT PERIOD: 4 19 2023-12 30 2024PROJECT TITLE: SYNTHESIZING LONG-TERM DATA TO IDENTIFY DRIVERS OF OCCUPANCY AND ABUNDANCE OF FEDERALLY-THREATENED AND ENDEMIC DARTERS OF THE INTERIOR HIGHLANDSLEOPARD DARTERS (ETHEOSTOMA PANTERINA) ARE LISTED AS THREATENED BY THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND ARE A SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN IN OKLAHOMA AND ARKANSAS, THE ONLY STATES IN WHICH THIS SPECIES OCCURS. LONG-TERM MONITORING OF LEOPARD DARTERS ACROSS RIVERS OF THE LITTLE RIVER BASIN IN THE OUACHITA HIGHLANDS HAS BEEN CONDUCTED SINCE THE 1990S, BUT THERE HAS BEEN NO EFFORT TO QUANTITATIVELY ASSESS CHANGES IN OCCUPANCY OR ABUNDANCE OVER TIME. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO USE LONG-TERM MONITORING DATA TO ASSESS THE CURRENT STATUS OF LEOPARD DARTERS AND IDENTIFY DRIVERS OF ANY OBSERVED CHANGES IN OCCURRENCE OR ABUNDANCE OVER TIME. FURTHER, THIS STUDY WILL ALSO USE MONITORING DATA FOR OTHER COMMON DARTER SPECIES TO UNDERSTAND DRIVERS OF DARTER OCCUPANCY AND ABUNDANCE ACROSS THE LITTLE RIVER BASIN.   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) QUANTIFY TRENDS IN AND DRIVERS OF OCCUPANCY OF EACH DARTER SPECIES ACROSS THE STUDY AREA OVER TIME, 2) DEVELOP POPULATION MODELS TO QUANTIFY TRENDS IN ABUNDANCE OF EACH DARTER SPECIES AT PERMANENT SAMPLING SITES AND IDENTIFY ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS OF POPULATION CHANGE OVER TIME, AND 3) IDENTIFY FACTORS INFLUENCING DETECTION OF DARTER SPECIES TO INFORM FUTURE MONITORING EFFORT. THESE OBJECTIVES WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH ANALYSIS OF DATA COLLECTED AS PART OF A LONG-TERM MONITORING PROGRAM.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES - THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE SERVICE TO DIRECTLY UPDATE THE CURRENT STATUS OF THREATENED LEOPARD DARTER POPULATIONS ACROSS THE RANGE AND IDENTIFY DRIVERS OF POPULATION CHANGE FOR DARTER SPECIES WITHIN THE LITTLE RIVER BASIN. BY INCLUDING A GRADIENT OF RARE AND OR ENDEMIC TO MORE COMMON AND OR WIDESPREAD SPECIES, WILL BE ABLE TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW ENVIRONMENTAL DRIVERS INFLUENCE DIFFERENT DARTER SPECIES AND IDENTIFY ATTRIBUTES OF LIFE HISTORY AND POPULATION DYNAMICS THAT MAKE SOME SPECIES OR POPULATIONS MORE RESISTANT OR RESILIENT TO ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE IN THE REGION. RESULTS OF THIS STUDY ALSO WILL CONTRIBUTE TO LONG-TERM MONITORING PROTOCOLS IN THE STUDY AREA BY EXPLICITLY ANALYZING FACTORS INFLUENCING DETECTION PROBABILITY.  INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) - THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION, AND ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION BY PROVIDING A STATUS UPDATE AND INSIGHT INTO THE DRIVERS OF CHANGES IN LEOPARD DARTERS. PROJECT TITLE  ASSESSING PRESENCE AND IDENTIFYING ROOSTS OF THE WNS IMPACTED NORTHERN LONG EARED BAT (MYOTIS SEPTENTRIONALIS) IN SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA PROJECT PERIOD  03 28 2023   04 30 2024ABSTRACT  THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND WORK EXAMINING THE STATUS AND HABITAT USE OF THE THREATENED NORTHERN LONG EARED BAT (MYOTIS SEPTENTRIONALIS) IN THE APPALACHIAN PLATEAU (COALFIELDS) OF SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA, AND SECONDARILY GATHER SIMILAR INFORMATION FOR THE ENDANGERED INDIANA BAT (MYOTIS SODALIS) AND THE CANDIDATE LITTLE BROWN BAT (MYOTIS LUCIFUGUS) AND TRI COLOR BAT (PERIMYOTIS SUBFLAVUS). LARGELY, IN THE MOUNTAIN REGION OF VIRGINIA, NORTHERN LONG EARED BATS ARE CLOSE TO COMPLETE EXTIRPATION.  HOWEVER, SIMILAR TO COASTAL REGIONS, ANECDOTAL EVIDENCE SUGGESTS CONTINUING PRESENCE IN THE COALFIELDS.  NONETHELESS, LIMITED SURVEYS EFFORTS HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED IN SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA. SEVERAL COUNTIES IN SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA HAVE ACOUSTIC RECORDS FOR THE BAT AND HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO OFFER ALTERNATIVE WINTER ROOSTS (E.G., MINES) THAT MAY NOT CONTRIBUTE TO WNS INFECTION. WITH THE USE OF PREVIOUS AND CURRENT ACOUSTIC SURVEYS AND RECENTLY COMPLETED SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS THE RECIPIENT HAS CREATED FOR VIRGINIA  RECIPIENT PROPOSES TO IDENTIFY AND MIST NET AREAS IN SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA WITH HIGH POTENTIAL FOR THE PRESENCE OF NORTHERN LONG EARED BATS. LOCATING ADDITIONAL MATERNITY SITES AND OR HIBERNACULA WILL PROVIDE THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SREVICE AND THEIR CONSERVATION PARTNERS THE OPPORTUNITY TO MANAGE AND PROTECT ROOST SITES WITH THE OBJECTIVE OF INCREASING SURVIVORSHIP. FINDINGS WILL HAVE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT IMPLICATIONS FOR LAND MANAGERS AS WELL AS REGULATORS TASKED WITH PROTECTING SPECIES HIGHLY IMPACTED BY WNS SUCH AS THE NORTHERN LONG EARED BAT. BECAUSE OF THE LIKELIHOOD OF CAPTURING LITTLE BROWN, INDIANA AND TRI COLORED BATS, THESE SPECIES WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE PROJECTS MONITORING EFFORT AS A SECONDARY GOAL.  FOCAL STUDY AREAS WILL INCLUDE (BUT NOT LIMITED TO)  PORTIONS OF THE JEFFERSON NATIONAL FOREST, BREAKS OF THE INTERSTATE STATE PARK, HUNGRY MOTHER STATE PARK, CLINCH MOUNTAIN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY AND VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES COOPERATIVELY MANAGED COALFIELD LANDS. THE INTENDED DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK ARE THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND MULTIPLE OTHER FEDERAL STATE AGENCIES.  NO SUBRECIPIENT AWARDS ARE ANTICIPATED.

PROJECT TITLE  ADVANCING CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION STRATEGIES FOR HIGH ELEVATION AND ENDANGERED LOWLAND AMPHIBIAN SPECIES IN THE US CARIBBEAN.PROJECT PERIOD  01 01 2023   12 31 2025THE WELL KNOWN COQU FROGS, REPRESENTED BY 17 SPECIES IN THE GENUS ELEUTHERODACTYLUS IN PUERTO RICO, ARE THREATENED BY EXTREME HEAT AND DRYING, AND COASTAL SALTWATER INTRUSION. RECENT INVESTIGATIONS HAVE HELPED TO DETERMINE HOW GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE IS LIKELY TO AFFECT THE LOCAL CLIMATE OF THE US CARIBBEAN, AND HOW SENSITIVE DIFFERENT COQU SPECIES ARE TO LOCAL CLIMATE AND HABITAT CONDITIONS. THE RECIPIENT PROPOSES TO ADVANCE EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT ADAPTATION TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND RECOVERY IN THE US CARIBBEAN BY ADDRESSING TWO OBJECTIVES  1) MEASURING KEY MICRO CLIMATE VARIABLES ALONG MULTIPLE HABITAT AND CLIMATE GRADIENTS, ALLOWING FOR IDENTIFICATION OF RESILIENT CLIMATE HABITATS FOR AT RISK AND ENDANGERED AMPHIBIAN SPECIES  AND 2) EXPANDING PRIOR WORK TO DISTINGUISH BETWEEN THE INTERACTIVE EFFECTS OF MOISTURE AND TEMPERATURE ON ELEUTHERODACTYLUS OCCURRENCE AND ABUNDANCE. THE EXPECTED RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY INCLUDE AN ISLAND WIDE EVALUATION OF POTENTIAL CLIMATE REFUGIA SITES FOR TEMPERATURE AND MOISTURE SENSITIVE ELEUTHERODACTYLUS SPECIES, AND CRITERIA FOR DECISION MAKERS TO DETERMINE WHEN AND WHERE THEY SHOULD ENGAGE IN IN SITU MANAGEMENT OR MANAGED TRANSLOCATIONS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  ESTABLISH A MONITORING STATION TO DETERMINE TEMPERATURE AND RELATIVE HUMIDITY TO DETERMINE THE CONDITIONS AMPHIBIANS ARE EXPOSED TO, AND RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THOSE CONDITIONS AND THE COARSER SCALE (2KM) OF CLIMATE PROJECTIONS.  LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS AND ACOUSTIC DATA WILL HELP DISTINGUISH THE EFFECTS OF TEMPERATURE AND HUMIDITY IN OCCURRENCE AND ABUNDANCE OF AMPHIBIANS.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES RECIPIENT EXPECTS A MINIMUM OF FIVE SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS ON  1) ISLAND WIDE EVALUATION OF POTENTIAL CLIMATE REFUGIA, 2) INFLUENCE OF TEMPERATURE VS RELATIVE HUMIDITY ON OCCURRENCE AND ABUNDANCE, 3) CHARACTERIZATION OF COASTAL HABITAT SUITABILITY FOR THE ENDANGERED COQUI LLANERO.  DATA RELEASES WILL BE COMPLETED AND WILL INCLUDE MAPS OF AREAS THAT ARE PREDICTED TO PROVIDE SUITABLE OR UNSUITABLE CONDITIONS FOR THE COQUI SPECIES OF INTEREST. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE SHARED WITH US FISH AND WILDLIFE ECOLOGICAL SERVICES AND PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES TO ADVANCE CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND RECOVERY.INTENDED BENEFICIARIES PUERTO RICO DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCESSOUTHEAST CLIMATE ADAPTATION STRATEGY (US CARIBBEAN CONSERVATION BLUEPRINT)US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ECOLOGICAL SERVICES

PROJECT PERIOD  2 24 23 3 31 26PROJECT TITLE DECISION SUPPORT FOR SUSTAINABLE RAPTOR TAKE LIMITS IN A CHANGING CLIMATECLIMATE CHANGE ALREADY AFFECTS RAPTOR POPULATIONS, THROUGH IMPACTS ON MIGRATION BIOLOGY AND VITAL RATES. HOWEVER, THE DECISION FRAMEWORK IN USE BY THE U.S. FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) TO ESTIMATE POPULATION TRENDS AND SET ALLOWABLE TAKE LIMITS FROM ANTHROPOGENIC ACTIVITIES IS STATIC WITH RESPECT TO CLIMATE. GIVEN THAT CLIMATE CHANGE IS ALREADY IMPACTING RAPTORS, ASSUMPTIONS OF STATIONARITY FOR VITAL RATES ARE INCREASINGLY UNREALISTIC AND CAST DOUBT ON PREDICTIONS OF FLYWAY SCALE ALLOWABLE TAKE DERIVED FROM EXISTING FRAMEWORKS. PROPOSE DEVELOPING A NEW DECISION SUPPORT TOOL THAT EXPLICITLY INCLUDES CLIMATE VARIABLES AS INPUTS TO POPULATION DYNAMIC MODELS TO ALLOW THE SERVICE TO SET ALLOWABLE TAKE LIMITS THAT ARE MORE BIOLOGICALLY REALISTIC OVER THE TIMEFRAME OF INTEREST. IN ADDITION TO BENEFITING THE SERVICE, ESTABLISHING TAKE LIMITS BASED ON A MORE COMPREHENSIVE SET OF CLIMATIC CONDITIONS WILL GUIDE OTHER STAKEHOLDERS (E.G., STATE NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES AND TRIBAL LEADERSHIP) IN MAKING MORE INFORMED DECISIONS REGARDING ALLOWABLE TAKE AND MITIGATION MEASURES TO OFFSET ANTHROPOGENIC TAKE WITHIN THEIR JURISDICTIONS. TO ENSURE TRANSFERABILITY OF DECISION TOOLS, HAVE INVITED REPRESENTATIVES FROM RELEVANT STAKEHOLDER GROUPS TO PARTICIPATE IN FRAMING THE DECISION PROBLEM, PARAMETERIZING MODELS, EVALUATING ALTERNATIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, AND PROVIDING FEEDBACK ON PROJECT DELIVERABLES. IN ADDITION TO WRITTEN AND ORAL PROJECT UPDATES, WILL DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN AN ONLINE DATA WAREHOUSE WHERE STAKEHOLDERS AND MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC CAN ACCESS ALL DATA, MODEL CODE, AND OUTPUT FROM THIS WORK. PROJECT TITLE   USGS PHASE I DEMOGRAPHY OF NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRRELS INSERT PROJECT PERIOD JANUARY 25, 2023   JULY 31, 2026PROJECT OBJECTIVES  FIRE SUPPRESSION HAS CAUSED A BUILD UP OF FUELS IN CONIFEROUS FORESTS IN THE WESTERN U.S. LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES MUST ENSURE THAT TREATMENT PRESCRIPTIONS TO REDUCE FUEL BUILD UP AND REDUCE FIRE RISK WILL NOT ADVERSELY AFFECT THE SPECIES PRESENT. RECIPIENT HAS IMPLEMENTED A FIELD EXPERIMENT TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF DIFFERENT FOREST RESTORATION ACTIONS REGARDING THEIR ABILITY TO RESTORE NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL HABITAT AND INCREASE POPULATION SIZE OF THIS THREATENED GROUND SQUIRREL. THE PROJECT ADDRESSES A PRIMARY RESEARCH NEED IDENTIFIED IN THE GROUND SQUIRREL S RECOVERY PLAN AND WILL HELP DETERMINE WHETHER SPECIFIC FOREST RESTORATION TREATMENTS CAN BE IMPLEMENTED TO PROVIDE ESSENTIAL HABITAT FOR THIS RARE SPECIES. NUMEROUS AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS HAVE WORKED TOGETHER FOR THE PAST 9 YEARS TO MEASURE DEMOGRAPHIC TRAITS OF NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRRELS ON PLOTS PRIOR TO RESTORATION TREATMENT (PRE TREATMENT), AND RECIPIENT RECENTLY BEGAN THE POST TREATMENT PHASE OF THE PROJECT AT SOME SITES  THREE EXPERIMENTAL TREATMENTS WERE IMPLEMENTED IN 2018 2021, AND THE REMAINING TWO EXPERIMENTAL TREATMENTS ARE PLANNED SOON (IN 2022 2023). THE NEXT FEW YEARS WILL PROVIDE POST TREATMENT DATA THAT WILL ALLOW THE TEAM OF SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTS OF THE RESTORATION ACTIONS. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE USFS AND OTHER LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES TO WRITE, PLAN, AND IMPLEMENT FOREST MANAGEMENT PRESCRIPTIONS WITHIN CONIFER FORESTS WITHOUT HARMING (AND POTENTIALLY HELPING) THE FEDERALLY LISTED NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL. THE RESULTS WILL PROVIDE THE INFORMATION NECESSARY SO THAT FOREST MANAGEMENT CAN PROCEED WHILE STILL ADHERING TO ESA. NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL ARE RANKED HIGH IN TERMS OF RECOVERY POTENTIAL (U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE 2003) BECAUSE RELATIVELY FEW CONSTRAINTS STAND IN THE WAY OF SPECIES RECOVERY AND HABITAT RESTORATION VIA FOREST TREATMENTS IS THOUGHT TO BE ALL THAT IS NEEDED. HENCE, THIS PROJECT MAY HELP IDENTIFY AN EFFECTIVE PRESCRIPTION THAT WILL SIMULTANEOUSLY REDUCE FUELS AND ALSO RECOVER AND DE LIST A FEDERALLY THREATENED SPECIES.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED TRAP AND MARK SQUIRRELS ON EXPERIMENTAL PLOTS.ATTACH RADIO TRANSMITTERS TO SUBSET OF SQUIRRELS AND FOLLOW TO IDENTIFY HIBERNACULA LOCATIONS.MAP PERIMETER OF SQUIRREL COLONIES AT EXPERIMENTAL PLOTS.MEASURE VEGETATION PARAMETERS ON EXPERIMENTAL PLOTS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES ANNUAL REPORT AND FINAL REPORT. EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE RELATIVE SUITABILITY OF FOREST RESTORATION PRACTICES FOR NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRRELS (I.E., THE SUITABILITY OF THINNING AND BURNING AS A METHOD TO RECOVER POPULATIONS).INTENDED BENEFICIARIES) U.S. FOREST SERVICE, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, STATE WILDLIFE AGENCY (IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME).

PROJECT PERIOD  1 20 23 8 31 23PROJECT TITLE DEVELOPING AN EVALUATION FRAMEWORK TO INFORM NATIONAL PARKS SERVICE COASTAL INFRASTRUCTURE INVESTMENT DECISIONSONGOING CLIMATE CHANGE, SEA LEVEL RISE, AND MORE POWERFUL STORM SYSTEMS WILL CAUSE INCREASING DAMAGE AND LOSS OF FACILITIES IN COASTAL UNITS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE OVER THE COMING DECADES. OVER TIME, SEA LEVEL RISE, STORMS, AND FUNDING LIMITS WILL DEFY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE S ABILITY TO MAINTAIN ALL EXISTING COASTAL PARK INFRASTRUCTURE IN SUITABLE CONDITIONS IN ALL LOCATIONS. SIMULTANEOUSLY, DECISIONS FOR INVESTMENTS TO MANAGE, ADAPT, OR TRIAGE INFRASTRUCTURE ACROSS NPS COASTAL PARK UNITS PRESENT UNIQUE CHALLENGES MUCH OF THE INFRASTRUCTURE IN THESE PARKS INCLUDES IRREPLACEABLE ELEMENTS OF THE NATION S CULTURAL HERITAGE (E.G. LIGHTHOUSES, FORTIFICATIONS), AND COASTAL PARKS PROVIDE IMPORTANT ECONOMIC DRIVERS FOR LOCAL COMMUNITIES. THE NPS LACKS A CONSISTENT AND TRANSPARENT ANALYTICAL PROCESS TO GUIDE LARGE, LONG TERM INVESTMENT PORTFOLIOS   THAT CONSIDER ONGOING AND PROJECTED SEA LEVEL RISE   FOR FACILITY PROTECTION, ADAPTATION AND SUSTAINABILITY MEASURES, RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION FOLLOWING STORM DAMAGE, OR OTHER OPTIONS SUCH AS DECOMMISSIONING AND REMOVAL. THE PROPOSED PRODUCT IS A TRANSPARENT ANALYTICAL FRAMEWORK AND PROCESS THAT IDENTIFIES AND INCORPORATES COMPREHENSIVE EVALUATION CRITERIA THAT CAN BE USED ACROSS ALL NATIONAL PARK SERVICE COASTAL PARK UNITS TO SUPPORT DECISIONS FOR CAPITAL INVESTMENTS IN INFRASTRUCTURE OF COASTAL NATIONAL PARK UNITS CONSIDERING THE PROJECTIONS OF SEA LEVEL RISE AND ASSOCIATED HAZARDS (E.G. STORMS, EROSION).  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  WORK WITH A NATIONAL PARK SERVICE STEERING GROUP TO REVIEW, REFINE AND DOCUMENT THE GOALS AND SCOPE OF THE EVALUATION FRAMEWORK.DEVELOP A CANDIDATE SET OF OBJECTIVES AND ASSOCIATED CRITERIA TO BE USED TO EVALUATE POTENTIAL INVESTMENTS.HOLD A WORKSHOP WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE STEERING GROUP AND A SELECT NUMBER OF PARK SUPERINTENDENTS TO BETTER CLARIFY AND DEFINE OBJECTIVES, AND EVALUATION APPROACHES AT THE PARK , REGIONAL , AND NPS WIDE LEVELS.DEVELOP AN EVALUATION PROCESS AND DECISION TOOL BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE WORKSHOP AND FOCUS GROUPS DISCUSSIONS.BETA TEST THE DECISION TOOL AND DECISION FRAMEWORK ON A SUBSET OF COASTAL PARK UNITS, AND CONTINUE TO REFINE THE DECISION TOOL AND EVALUATION BASED ON THE BETA TEST.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  PREPARE A DECISION FRAMEWORK BASED ON THE RESULTS OF THE BET TEST, AND DOCUMENT A PROCESS FOR BROAD APPLICATION OF THE FRAMEWORK ACROSS ALL COASTAL PARKS  DEVELOP OR MODIFY, IF APPROPRIATE, COMPUTER BASED TOOLS TO SUPPORT THE QUANTITATIVE ASPECTS OF THE EVALUATION FRAMEWORK.PREPARE A REPORT THAT OUTLINES AND DEFINES THE EVALUATION DECISION CRITERIA, THRESHOLDS, ASSUMPTION, THE PROCESS, AND FINAL DECISION FRAMEWORK. PREPARE A PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION DOCUMENTING THE WORK.  INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES)  NATIONAL PARK SERVICE   ALL COASTAL UNITS AND THE BUREAU INVESTMENT REVIEW BOARD  SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD THERE IS NO SUBRECIPIENT FOR THIS AWARD.

PROJECT PERIOD  1 17 23 12 31 17POJRECT TITLE ASSESSING POST STRANDING MOVEMENT, FEEDING, AND BEHAVIORAL PATTERNS OF FLORIDA MANATEES RELEASED ON SITE AND FROM REHABILITATIONFLORIDA MANATEES, A SUBSPECIES OF THE WEST INDIAN MANATEE, HAVE BECOME A PRIORITIZED SPECIES FOR SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH DUE TO THEIR CONSERVATION STATUS. MANY STUDIES HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED IN THE LAST DECADE BASED ON THE 2011 UNUSUAL MORTALITY EVENT (UME), WHERE NECROPSIES ON THE BULK OF RECOVERED CARCASSES REVEALED SIGNS OF INTESTINAL INFLAMMATION AND A DIETARY SHIFT FROM MAJORITY SEAGRASS TO MAJORITY MICROALGAE CONSUMPTION. DIETARY SHIFTS HAVE LED SCIENTISTS TO STUDY FORAGING BEHAVIOR IN A NEW LIGHT, AND TO EXAMINE THE CONNECTION BETWEEN SEASONAL MOVEMENT PATTERNS, SITE FIDELITY, AND THE IMPACT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES DUE TO HUMAN ACTIVITY. TRACKING WILD MANATEE MOVEMENT PATTERNS HAS ALLOWED SCIENTISTS TO COLLECT AND ANALYZE IMPORTANT RANGE AND DEMOGRAPHIC DATA INCLUDING AREAS USED FOR WINTER REFUGE, MATING SITES, AND FORAGING SITES. THIS RESEARCH STUDY WILL TRACK AND ASSESS THE MOVEMENT PATTERNS AND FEEDING BEHAVIORS OF FLORIDA MANATEES TRANSPORTED FROM REHABILITATION FACILITIES AND RELEASED IN CENTRAL FLORIDA, TO ANALYZE FORAGING BEHAVIOR, SURVIVAL RATES AND SITE FIDELITY TO THIS REGION. THE RESULTS OF THIS RESEARCH CAN IDENTIFY AND CONFIRM NATURAL  SAFE ZONES  FOR POST RELEASE MANATEES AND EVALUATE FORAGING BEHAVIOR AT LEAST ONE YEAR POST RELEASE AND ADDRESS THE EFFICACY OF REHABILITATION SITES AS A KEY COMPONENT IN THE LONG TERM SUCCESS AND SURVIVAL OF POST RELEASE MANATEES AND THE GENERAL POPULATION IN FLORIDA.KEYWORDS  MANATEE, UME, TRACKING, BEHAVIOR, REHABILITATION, REFUGIA
