PROJECT TITLE  CONTAMINATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSTITUENTS WITH CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE PRIONSPROJECT PERIOD 9 21 2022   8 31 2025CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE IS A CONTAGIOUS DISEASE THAT IS SPREADING IN POORLY UNDERSTOOD  WHILE DISEASE TRANSMISSION CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THE ENVIRONMENT AND BEHAVIOR HAVE BEEN SUGGESTED, DATA INDICATING TRANSMISSION ROUTES ARE SCANT  THIS PROJECT WILL MEASURE THE TECHNOLOGIES RECIPIENT WILL EVALUATE THE ABUNDANCE OF PRION CONTAMINATION IN SOILS AND ON PLANTS IN DEFINED AREAS WHERE THE INTERACTIONS WITH CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE AFFECTED DEER ARE BEING MONITORED SCENT MARKING ALTER PRION CONTAMINATION  LABORATORY STUDIES WILL SUPPLEMENT FIELD STUDIES AND WILL EXAMINE THE BINDING AND UPTAKE OF PRIONS BY DIFFERENT PLANTS AND THE PLANT PRION INTERFACE ONGOING SCIENTIFIC CHALLENGE  RECIPIENT WILL DELIVER NEW INFORMATION ON PRION QUANTIFICATION USING THE NOVEL MATRICES IN THE ENVIRONMENT  THE PROJECT WILL GENERATE ABUNDANT DATA, CONCERNING THE ENVIRONMENTAL DISTRIBUTION AND PERSISTENCE OF PRIONS AS WELL AS THE SHEDDING OF PRIONS INTO THE ENVIRONMENT BY DISEASED DEER NOVEL OUTCOMES FROM THIS PROJECT INCLUDE  1  ASSESSMENT OF THE RISK POSED BY DEER INTERACTION WITH PRION CONTAMINATED SCENT MARKING SITES, CWD INFECTED CARCASS SITES AND ANTHROPOGENIC CARCASS DUMP SITES, WHICH WILL INFORM POLICIES SUCH AS THOSE ASSOCIATED WITH CARCASS DISPOSAL AND 2  A QUANTITATIVE ASSESSMENT OF THE POTENTIAL FOR PLANTS TO ASSIMILATE PRIONS AT ENVIRONMENTALLY RELEVANT CONCENTRATIONS  PROJECT FINDING WILL BE DOCUMENTED IN PEER REVIEW PUBLICATIONS AND PROJECT PRESENTATIONS WILL BE MADE AT SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL BENEFIT NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGERS BY PROVIDING EVALUATION OF THE TRANSMISSION RISK ASSOCIATED WITH ENVIRONMENTS WHERE CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE IS ENDEMIC

PROJECT TITLE INVESTIGATING ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSMISSION OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASEPROJECT PERIOD 9 21 2022   08 31 2025CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE IS A FATAL DISEASE AFFECTING DEER SPECIES, WHICH HAS NEGATIVE EFFECTS ON AFFECTED POPULATIONS AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION  CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE IS CAUSED BY AN INFECTIOUS MISFOLDED PROTEIN, CALLED A PRION  THESE PRIONS CAN BE TRANSMITTED DIRECTLY, FROM AN INFECTED TO A SUSCEPTIBLE HOST THROUGH CLOSE CONTACT, OR INDIRECTLY, THROUGH HOST CONTACT WITH PRIONS IN THE ENVIRONMENT  LITTLE IS CURRENTLY KNOWN ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSMISSION PATHWAY, AND ITS IMPORTANCE IN DISEASE SPREAD IN DEER POPULATIONS  THIS PROJECT INVESTIGATES ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSMISSION OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE IN WHITE TAILED DEER  ODOCOILEUS VIRGINIANUS  IN SOUTHWESTERN WISCONSIN ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE FIRST OBJECTIVE IS TO EXAMINE PRION AMOUNTS FOUND IN SOILS AND ON PLANTS AT SUSPECTED PRION RESERVOIR SITES AND HOW THESE CHANGE OVER TIME  THE SECOND OBJECTIVE IS TO EVALUATE DEER BEHAVIOR AT POTENTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL RESERVOIRS TO ASSESS EXPOSURE RISKS THROUGH BOTH ENVIRONMENTAL RESERVOIRS AND SPECIFIC HOST BEHAVIORS DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMESRECIPIENT WILL DEVELOP FIELD AND LABORATORY DATASETS MANAGERS CAN USE TO ASSESS THE RISK OF INDIRECT TRANSMISSION OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE BASED ON LOCAL DEER MOVEMENTS AND RATES OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION IN DIFFERENT POTENTIAL PRION RESERVOIRS  RECIPIENT WILL ASSESS THE RISK POSED BY DEER INTERACTION WITH PRION CONTAMINATED SCENT MARKING SITES, CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE INFECTED CARCASS SITES AND ANTHROPOGENIC CARCASS DUMP SITES, WHICH WILL INFORM POLICIES SUCH AS THOSE ASSOCIATED WITH CARCASS DISPOSAL  THE PROJECT WILL GENERATE TWO NOVEL DATASETS, ONE ON PRION CONTAMINATION AT DIFFERENT POTENTIAL RESERVOIR SITES AND HOW THESE CHANGE OVER TIME, AND A SECOND ON DEER BEHAVIOR AND RISK AT POTENTIAL PRION RESERVOIR SITES  RECIPIENT WILL DISSEMINATE THEIR FINDINGS VIA SCIENTIFIC AND AGENCY PRESENTATIONS, PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS, AND TECHNICAL REPORTS INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, WITH FINDINGS ON ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSMISSION RISK CONDUCTED IN A HIGH PREVALENCE AREA WHERE THE DISEASE WAS FIRST DETECTED IN WISCONSIN  RESEARCH RESULTS WILL ALSO BENEFIT STAKEHOLDERS WORKING TO UNDERSTAND AND SLOW THE SPREAD OF CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE ACROSS NORTH AMERICA, INCLUDING FEDERAL, STATE AND TRIBAL AGENCIES IN AT RISK AREAS

PROJECT TITLE NATIONAL HORIZON SCAN OF TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC INVERTEBRATES IN THE ORGANISMS IN TRADE PATHWAYPROJECT PERIOD 9 20 2022   08 30 2024AQUATIC ALIEN INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE UNITED STATES HAVE NEGATIVELY IMPACTED BIODIVERSITY, AS WELL AS, COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES, AND PRESENT MANAGEMENT CHALLENGES THAT CONSUME SIGNIFICANT RESOURCES  HEREIN, AN ALIEN INVASIVE SPECIES FOLLOWS THE DEFINITION OF AN INTRODUCED, NONNATIVE ORGANISM  DISEASE, PARASITE, PLANT, OR ANIMAL  THAT BEGINS TO SPREAD OR EXPAND ITS RANGE FROM THE SITE OF ITS ORIGINAL INTRODUCTION AND THAT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO CAUSE HARM TO THE ENVIRONMENT, THE ECONOMY, OR TO HUMAN HEALTH  AIS CONSIDERED ARE NOT NATIVE TO NORTH AMERICA OR PACIFIC AND CARIBBEAN ISLANDS WITHIN THE LEGAL JURISDICTION OF THE UNITED STATES AND EXCLUDES SPECIES IMPORTED FOR RESEARCH, CONSERVATION, OR NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PURPOSES  PREVENTION OF THE ESTABLISHMENT OF ALIEN INVASIVE SPECIES IS THE MOST EFFECTIVE ACTION COMPARED WITH MANAGEMENT, MITIGATION, AND ERADICATION EFFORTS  IDENTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT OF A SPECIES  POTENTIAL FOR INVASION AND ESTABLISHMENT PRIOR TO THE EVENT IS AN IMPORTANT STEP IN PREVENTION  THE GENERAL FRAMEWORK FOR HORIZON SCANNING IS TO IDENTIFY A LIST OF POTENTIAL SPECIES AND PATHWAYS, SCORE THE INVASION RISK BASED ON A PRIORI DEFINED CRITERIA THROUGH EXPERT CONSULTATION, AND THROUGH A CONSENSUS PROCESS, OBTAIN A FINAL PRIORITY LIST OF SPECIES WITH THE HIGHEST POTENTIAL RISK OF INVASIVENESS HORIZON SCANNING CAN PROVIDE INFORMATION FOR U S  POLICY MAKERS REGARDING RISKS OF INVERTEBRATE AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO  1  DETERMINE OF POTENTIAL SPECIES WITH AN INVASIVE RISK THROUGH ANIMAL TRADE AND GATHERING OF RELEVANT LITERATURE, GOVERNMENT AND NONGOVERNMENTAL REPORTS, AND PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATA  2  CONSULT WITH RELEVANT EXPERTS IN AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL INVERTEBRATES AND ALIEN INVASIVE SPECIES ECOLOGY TO ASSESS LEVELS OF RISK  3  BUILD CONSENSUS ACROSS EXPERT GROUPS TO RANK THE POTENTIAL FOR IDENTIFIED SPECIES TO BECOME ALIEN INVASIVE SPECIES  THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT A WIDELY USED HORIZON SCAN FRAMEWORK  THIS CONSENSUS FRAMEWORK IS VERY AMENDABLE TO THE PROPOSED ASSESSMENT  IN THIS FRAMEWORK, THE HORIZON SCAN HAS THREE COMPONENTS  1  DETERMINATION OF POTENTIAL SPECIES WITH AN INVASIVE RISK THROUGH ANIMAL TRADE AND GATHERING OF RELEVANT LITERATURE, GOVERNMENT AND NONGOVERNMENTAL REPORTS, AND PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATA  2  PRELIMINARY CONSULTATION WITH RELEVANT EXPERTS IN AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL INVERTEBRATES AND ECOLOGY TO ASSESS LEVELS OF RISK  AND 3  CONSENSUS BUILDING ACROSS EXPERT GROUPS TO RANK THE POTENTIAL FOR IDENTIFIED SPECIES TO BECOME INVASIVE THE OUTCOME OF THIS WORK WILL BE DISSEMINATED THROUGH ORAL PRESENTATIONS, JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS, AND FINAL REPORT TO U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  DISSEMINATION OF DATA AND RESEARCH RESULTS WILL FOLLOW U S  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY GUIDELINES FOR DATA MANAGEMENT AND PEER REVIEW AND WILL BE DONE IN A COLLABORATIVE MANNER FOR MUTUAL BENEFIT  IN ADDITION TO COURSEWORK AND WRITING A PROPOSAL, THESIS, REPORTS, AND MANUSCRIPTS, PROJECT PLANNING AND MONITORING AND REGIONAL LEVEL MONITORING AND MODEL DATABASES TO INFORM THE CONCEPTUAL MODEL TASK 3  TO INCORPORATE DATA FROM PROJECT COLLABORATORS OUTSIDE OF LSU AGCENTER WHO WILL FROM THE DEEPWATER HORIZON SETTLEMENT, AND THUS BENEFIT ALL TRUSTEES, INCLUDING DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR AGENCIES, NOAA, AND STATE CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES AGENCIES

PROJECT TITLE  POPULATION GENETICS OF CAROLINA MADTOMPROJECT PERIOD 9 2 2022   5 29 2023THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND POPULATION GENETICS WORK FOR THE CAROLINA MADTOM NOTURUS FURIOSUS TO ASSIST WITH U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE CONSERVATION EFFORTS OF THIS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED SPECIES  ENDEMIC TO THE TAR AND NEUSE RIVER BASINS OF NORTH CAROLINA, IDENTIFICATION OF THE GENETIC DIVERSITY WITHIN AND AMONG THE REMAINING POPULATIONS IN THE TWO BASINS IS CRITICAL FOR PLANNING ACTIONS TO CONSERVE THE SPECIES, AS CAPTIVE PROPAGATION HAS COMMENCED AND REINTRODUCTION OR TRANSLOCATION EFFORTS MAY BE IMPLEMENTED  ASSESSMENT OF GENETIC VARIATION AND IDENTIFICATION OF POPULATION GENETIC STRUCTURE FOR THE CAROLINA MADTOM IS CRITICAL FOR INFORMING MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION DECISIONS GOING FORWARD FOR RECOVERY ACTIONS  THIS WORK WILL RESULT IN ROBUST ESTIMATION OF GENETIC VARIABILITY, EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE AND LEVEL OF INBREEDING WITHIN POPULATIONS, AND CHARACTERIZATION OF POPULATION GENETIC STRUCTURE AND HISTORICAL LEVELS OF MIGRATION AMONG POPULATIONS OF CAROLINA MADTOM  THE PROPOSED OBJECTIVES WILL ALSO FACILITATE FUTURE GENETIC RESEARCH ON THE SPECIES WITH NEW GENETICS PROTOCOLS FOR ENHANCED ACCURACY AND RESOLUTION OF RESULTS AND THEIR INTERPRETATION  THE INTENDED DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK ARE THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION, HOWEVER FINDINGS FROM THIS WILL ALSO BE RELEVANT TO A WIDER ARRAY OF STAKEHOLDERS THAT MANAGE AQUATIC RESOURCES IN EASTERN NORTH CAROLINA  NO SUBRECIPIENT AWARDS OTHER THAN COMMERCIAL LABORATORY SERVICES ARE ANTICIPATED

PROJECT TITLE SYNTHESIS OF FRESHWATER SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS AND HABITATS TO GUIDE CONSERVATION IN CENTRAL ALASKAN PUBLIC LANDSPROJECT PERIOD 09 2 2022   06 30 2027THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO ASSESS THE STATUS AND TRENDS OF FRESHWATER COMMUNITIES AND HABITATS IN STREAMS ON ALASKAN PUBLIC LANDS UTILIZING A LONG TERM WATER QUALITY DATASET  THESE DATA ORIGINATE FROM WITHIN CENTRAL ALASKA NATIONAL PARKS MANAGED BY THE U S  NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AS WELL AS OTHER LANDS IN THE REGION MANAGED BY THE U S  BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  RESEARCH UNDER THIS AWARD WILL BE GUIDED BY THE FOLLOWING QUESTIONS  TO WHAT EXTENT CAN SITES ACROSS ALASKAN PUBLIC LANDS BE CLASSIFIED MEANINGFULLY BASED ON A SUITE OF SHARED ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, AND DO THESE CLASSES, IN TURN, CONTAIN CLEARLY DEFINED ECOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES  HOW ARE SPECIES AND HABITAT DISTRIBUTIONS ALTERED ACROSS ALASKAN PUBLIC LANDS BASED ON HABITAT CONDITIONS AND EXPECTED ENVIRONMENTAL SHIFTS UNDER CLIMATE CHANGE OR HUMAN USE SUCH AS MINING, AND ARE CERTAIN ECOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES OR HABITATS AT PARTICULARLY HIGH RISK OF DECLINE ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CARRYING OUT A SYNTHETIC ANALYSIS OF THESE DATA TO EXPLORE CHANGES IN SPECIES DISTRIBUTIONS OVER TIME, TO CHARACTERIZE SPECIES CORRELATIONS WITH ENVIRONMENTAL  HABITAT  CONDITIONS, AND TO DETERMINE SPECIES AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESPONSES TO CLIMATE WARMING AND MINING OPERATIONS  ACTIVITIES UNDER THIS AWARD WILL BE PRINCIPALLY BASED ON ANALYSIS OF EXISTING DATA, WITH LITTLE TO NO NEW FIELDWORK OR DATA COLLECTION ANTICIPATED EXPECTED PRODUCTS INCLUDE ANNUAL PROGRESS MEMOS, A FINAL REPORT IN THE FORM OF PUBLICATION S  IN PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC JOURNALS, AND AS PRESENTATIONS AT LEAST ONE SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE AT THE STATE OR NATIONAL LEVEL THE PRINCIPAL BENEFICIARIES OF THE RESEARCH CARRIED OUT UNDER THIS AWARD WILL BE MANAGERS AND RESEARCH PERSONNEL ASSOCIATED WITH CENTRAL ALASKAN NATIONAL PARKS AND OTHER PUBLIC LANDS OVERSEEN BY THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  SECONDARY BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE OTHER STATE AND FEDERAL ENTITIES WITH AN INTEREST IN WATER QUALITY MONITORING WITHIN THE STATE OF ALASKA, PARTICULARLY THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME

PROJECT TITLE STRATEGIC CONFISCATION AND PLACEMENT OF ILLEGALLY COLLECTED TURTLES FOR MAXIMIZING CONSERVATION OUTCOMESPROJECT PERIOD  8 29 2022 THROUGH 7 15 2025DECISIONS ABOUT THE CONFISCATION AND DISPOSITION OF MULTIPLE SPECIES OF TURTLES ENCOUNTERED VIA MULTIPLE LEGAL AND EXTRA LEGAL TRADE ROUTES ARE COMPLEX BECAUSE OF UNCERTAINTY AND RISK  DECISION MAKERS WISH TO MAXIMIZE THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF TURTLE POPULATIONS IN THE WILD, WHICH ARE DECLINING  OR LOCALLY EXTIRPATED  IN PART BECAUSE OF ILLEGAL HARVEST, BUT ALSO BECAUSE OF OTHER THREATS SUCH AS CLIMATE CHANGE, URBANIZATION, AND DISEASE THIS ANALYSIS WILL BE COMPRISED OF 3 STEPS   1  OUTLINING A CONCEPTUAL MODEL TO IDENTIFY POINTS OF INTERVENTION AND DECISION MAKING AUTHORITY AT EACH POINT,  2  PARAMETERIZING A TUNABLE POPULATION VIABILITY ANALYSIS THAT CAN BE USED TO PREDICT THE OUTCOMES FOR POPULATIONS OF THE LINKED DECISIONS AND  3  EVALUATING A DECISION TREE TO INCORPORATE UNCERTAINTIES AND THE LINKED DECISIONS TO IDENTIFY OPTIMAL SOLUTIONS 1  A MODEL FOR THE LINKED DECISION FOR TURTLE CONFISCATION AND REPATRIATION, IDENTIFYING EACH AGENCY S CONTRIBUTION TO THE CONFISCATION DISPOSITION DECISION 2  IDENTIFICATION OF THE OPTIMAL DECISIONS FOR EACH POINT IN THE DECISION, GIVEN THE EXPECTED POPULATION OUTCOMES  MEASURED AS POPULATION VIABILITY , THE PROBABILITIES OF EVENTS, AND THE DECISION MAKER CONSTRAINTS

PROJECT TITLE  IMPLICATIONS OF STREAM FRAGMENTATION FOR CLIMATE CHANGE RESILIENCE OF NORTHERN PRAIRIE FISHES PROJECT PERIOD  08 15 2022   12 31 2025  AWARD PURPOSE  DRY STREAM REACHES ARE CHARACTERISTIC OF ALL BUT THE LARGEST PRAIRIE STREAMS  NATIVE FISHES ARE HIGHLY ADAPTED TO VARIABLE ENVIRONMENTS, USING REFUGE HABITATS TO RECOLONIZE AREAS AFTER SEASONAL DRYING  HOWEVER, DAMS AND OTHER BARRIERS CAN PREVENT RECOLONIZATION OF SEASONALLY DRY STREAM REACHES, HABITATS KNOWN TO BE CRITICAL SPAWNING AND REARING AREAS FOR MANY SPECIES  THIS PHENOMENON WILL LIKELY BECOME MORE COMMON AS CLIMATE CHANGE CAUSES INCREASINGLY SEVERE DROUGHTS AND LARGER REACHES OF STREAMS BECOME SEASONALLY DRY  THIS COULD LEAD TO LOCAL LOSS OF NATIVE PRAIRIE FISHES, AN AT RISK GROUP  FISHERIES MANAGERS IN WYOMING AND MONTANA HAVE LIMITED DATA ON CLIMATE IMPACTS TO PRAIRIE FISHES AND THEREFORE LITTLE WAY TO PRIORITIZE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS  OUR PROJECT AIMS TO PROVIDE LANDSCAPE LEVEL MAPS AND RESOURCES THAT WILL HELP MANAGERS PRIORITIZE WHERE AND FOR WHICH SPECIES MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ARE NEEDED  IN ADDITION, WE WILL CONDUCT ON THE GROUND ASSESSMENTS OF RESTORATION ACTIONS   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  TO DETERMINE WHERE WATER AND HABITAT CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION WILL BE MOST BENEFICIAL TO AT RISK PRAIRIE FISHES, WE WILL ASSESS WHICH SPECIES ARE MOST SENSITIVE TO DROUGHT AND EXPAND A NEWLY CREATED MODEL OF STREAMFLOW PERMANENCE TO MAP DROUGHT REFUGES FOR VULNERABLE SPECIES  WE WILL ALSO MONITOR STREAM RESTORATION CASE STUDIES TO DETERMINE IF PROCESS BASED RESTORATION TECHNIQUES CAN BE USED TO INCREASE STREAMFLOW PERMANENCE AND CONNECTIVITY  LASTLY, THIS WORK WILL BE LEVERAGED TO CREATE A SHORT, SPECIES SPECIFIC GUIDE TO CLIMATE ADAPTATION TECHNIQUES   DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  OUR RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE PRODUCTS THAT WILL HELP MANAGE FOR PROCESSES THAT CAN MAINTAIN RESILIENT FISH POPULATIONS IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE  WE WILL CREATE INTERACTIVE MAPS OF BARRIERS, DYNAMIC EXTENTS OF INTERMITTENT REACHES, AND POTENTIAL CLIMATE REFUGES WHICH WILL BE AVAILABLE TO VIEW ONLINE  OUTCOMES AND PRODUCTS WILL BE SHARED DIRECTLY WITH LOCAL AND REGIONAL COLLABORATORS, PRESENTED AT LOCAL, REGIONAL AND NATIONAL SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS, PUBLISHED IN PEER REVIEWED JOURNALS, AND MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE VIA SCIENCEBASE   INTENDED BENEFICIARIES  THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES PARTNERS ARE THE WYOMING GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT AND BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, BUT THE WORK WILL ALSO BE RELEVANT FOR FEDERAL AND STATE WATER RESOURCE MANAGERS AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS INTERESTED IN RESTORING PRAIRIE STREAMS FOR THE BENEFIT OF FISHES   SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD THIS WORK IS IN COLLABORATION WITH THE U S  GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WYOMING MONTANA WATER SCIENCE CENTER WHICH IS DEVELOPING THE MACHINE  LEARNING MODEL  PROSPER  BEING USED TO IDENTIFY DROUGHT REFUGES

PROJECT TITLE REDUCING HUMAN BEAR CONFLICT THROUGH RELATIONAL ORGANIZINGPROJECT PERIOD  AUGUST 29, 2022   JUNE 30, 2026THE RECIPIENT PROPOSES TO PURSUE A MULTI PHASE RESEARCH PROGRAM TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF RELATIONAL ORGANIZING CAMPAIGNS FOCUSED ON REDUCING BEAR ATTRACTANTS IN RESIDENTIAL SETTINGS IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES FOR PHASE 1, THE RECIPIENT WILL HOLD IN PERSON WORKSHOPS WITH FOUR COMMUNITIES TO ASSESS THE VIABILITY OF RELATIONAL ORGANIZING FOR REDUCING HUMAN BEAR CONFLICT IN THEIR TOWN  THEY WILL CONDUCT 2 HOUR WORKSHOPS IN 4 TOWNS, ONE EACH IN COLORADO, MONTANA, WYOMING, AND OREGON, FOR LOCAL RESIDENTS TO DISCUSS THEIR PAST ENGAGEMENT IN INDIVIDUAL ACTION TO REDUCE ATTRACTANTS FOR BEARS, THEIR FUTURE INTEREST IN RELATIONAL ORGANIZING ON THIS TOPIC, AND THEIR BELIEFS ABOUT WHAT POLICIES COULD SUPPORT NECESSARY BEHAVIOR CHANGE IN PHASE 2, THE RECIPIENTWILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS TO CONDUCT TWO LARGE SCALE SURVEYS  ONE OF AT LEAST 700 RESIDENTS IN THE TARGET COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE WESTERN UNITED STATES, TO BE RECRUITED THROUGH EXISTING EMAIL LISTS AND NETWORKS OF INTERESTED COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND THE SECOND OF 700 MEMBERS OF GENERAL PUBLIC IN THE FOCAL STATES, TO BE RECRUITED THROUGH AN ONLINE SURVEY PLATFORM SUCH AS PROLIFIC IN PHASE 3 THE RECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS WHO WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT A COMMUNITY LEADER PROGRAM IN ONE OR TWO FOCAL COMMUNITIES  RECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE EXPERT ADVICE FOR THEM TO RECRUIT PARTICIPANTS TO THIS PROGRAM THROUGH THE SURVEYS AND THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA AND EXISTING NETWORKS OF INTERESTED VOLUNTEERS  THE COMMUNITY LEADER PROGRAM WILL INVOLVE A SERIES OF ONLINE WORKSHOPS FOCUSED ON EMPOWERING VOLUNTEERS IN THE FOCAL TOWNS TO REACH OUT TO OTHERS IN THEIR COMMUNITY TO MOTIVATE PERSONAL ACTION TO REDUCE BEAR ATTRACTANTS RESEARCH OBJECTIVES INCLUDE 1  UNDERSTAND THE BARRIERS, MOTIVATIONS, AND OPPORTUNITIES INFLUENCING WHETHER RESIDENTS IN THE WESTERN UNITED STATES ENGAGE IN RELATIONAL ORGANIZING ON THE TOPIC OF SECURING ATTRACTANTS FOR BEARS THROUGH INDIVIDUAL VOLUNTARY BEHAVIOR CHANGE AND OR COLLECTIVE POLICY CHANGE 2  DESIGN, IMPLEMENT, AND EVALUATE A COMMUNITY LEADER PROGRAM IN COLLABORATION WITH PARTNERS IN ONE OR TWO FOCAL COMMUNITIES TO TRAIN AND ENCOURAGE LEADERS TO PARTICIPATE IN RELATIONAL ORGANIZING

PROJECT TITLE INVASIVE CARP POPULATION MODELING  ECOSYSTEM IMPACTS OF CONTROL METHODSPROJECT PERIOD  8 15 2022   12 31 2025AWARD PURPOSE   INVASIVE SPECIES CAN CAUSE NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON NATIVE SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS  OFTEN, INVASIVE SPECIES CANNOT BE ELIMINATED ONCE ESTABLISHED AND SO MOST MANAGEMENT SEEKS TO REDUCE OR CONTROL THE POPULATION OF THE INVASIVE SPECIES  INVASIVE CARPS IN NORTH AMERICAN RIVERS ARE MANAGED BY REMOVING INDIVIDUALS TO REDUCE POPULATION NUMBERS  HOWEVER, PARTICULAR INDIVIDUALS WITHIN THE INVASIVE CARP POPULATION MAY HAVE A GREATER NEGATIVE IMPACT ON NATIVE SPECIES THAN OTHERS  THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY IF PARTICULAR AGES OR SIZES OF INVASIVE CARP HAVE MORE OF AN IMPACT OF NATIVE SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS  THOSE INDIVIDUALS CAN THEN BE TARGETED FOR REMOVAL USING OFTEN LIMITED MANAGEMENT DOLLARS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED   AN MS STUDENT WILL BE HIRED WHO WILL PARAMETERIZE AN ECOPATH WITH ECOSIM MODEL FOR NORTH AMERICAN LARGE RIVERS  THE STUDENT WILL THEN RUN SIMULATIONS TO IDENTIFY IF A PARTICULAR SIZE OR AGE OF INVASIVE CARP HAS AN INCREASED ECOLOGICAL IMPACT DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   MODEL PARAMETERIZATION, CODE, AND SIMULATION RUNS WILL BE GIVEN A DOI AND MADE AVAILABLE THROUGH USGS SCIENCEBASE  OTHER EXPECTED PRODUCTS INCLUDE AT LEAST 2 CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS, A MS THESIS, AND AT LEAST ONE PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION  THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION TO MANAGERS REGARDING WHAT SIZE AND AGE OF INVASIVE CARPS HAVE THE GREATEST NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON NATIVE SPECIES AND ECOSYSTEMS  MANAGERS CAN THEN USE THIS INFORMATION TO ADJUST THEIR REMOVAL PROGRAMS TO TARGET PARTICULAR SIZES OR AGES OF INVASIVE CARP FOR REMOVAL INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES    STATE, FEDERAL, AND INTERNATIONAL FISHERIES MANAGERS SEEKING TO MINIMIZE THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE CARPS  INVASIVE CARPS HAVE BEEN FOUND IN OVER 70 COUNTRIES GLOBALLY  PROJECT WILL ALSO BE OF INTEREST TO ALL THOSE MANAGING INVASIVE SPECIES, REGARDLESS OF TAXA SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD  N A

USGS AMPHIBIAN RESEARCH AND MONITORING INITIATIVE  THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL LEVERAGE THIS STRONG HISTORY OF COLLABORATIVE WORK AND QUANTITATIVE EXPERTISE OF PENN STATE COLLABORATORS TO PROVIDE IMPORTANT INFORMATION FOR MANAGERS AND TRAINING FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS AND POST DOCTORAL RESEARCHERS  SPECIFIC WORK WILL FOCUS ON THREE AREAS OF NEED  1  ASSISTING WITH MODEL DEVELOPMENT AND ANALYSIS OF DATA FROM AN ONGOING NATIONAL AMPHIBIAN DISEASE STUDY  2  PROTOTYPING METHODS FOR DYNAMIC INTEGRATED DISTRIBUTION MODELS  AND 3  ASSISTING WITH DEVELOPMENT OF DECISION TOOLS FOR MANAGEMENT OF AN ENDANGERED AMPHIBIAN ON DOI LANDS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE PI, POST DOCS, GRADUATE STUDENTS, AND RESEARCH ASSOCIATES WILL PROVIDE ANALYTICAL SUPPORT TO THREE STUDIES OCCURRING IN COLLABORATION WITH THE USGS   ARMI  THESE INCLUDE 1  THE ANALYSIS OF A NATIONAL STUDY EXAMINING THE EFFECTS OF CHYTRID FUNGUS AND MERCURY ON SURVIVAL OF 23 POPULATIONS OF AMPHIBIANS WHERE MORE THAN 20,000 FROGS, TOADS, NEWTS, AND SALAMANDERS HAVE BEEN OBSERVED ACROSS A FIVE YEAR STUDY PERIOD, 2  DEVELOPING A DATA INTEGRATION FRAMEWORK FOR COMBINING SYSTEMATIC AND NON SYSTEMATIC DATA COLLECTION SCHEMES TO PREDICT THE DISTRIBUTION OF STREAMS SALAMANDERS IN EASTERN NORTH AMERICA, AND 3  DEVELOPING A FRAMEWORK FOR COMBINING TWO DECADES OF SURVEY DATA FOR AN ENDANGERED SPECIES TO CHARACTERIZE RANGE STATUS AND UNCERTAINTY DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE MANUSCRIPTS PRESENTING THE RESULTS OF EACH OF THE OBJECTIVES, ANALYTICAL FRAMEWORKS THAT CAN GUIDE FUTURE DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSES, CODE, AND MAPS AND OTHER TOOLS TO DISSEMINATE RESULTS OF THE ANALYSES INTENDED BENEFICIARIES   THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT RESEARCH EFFORTS OF USGS PARTNERS INCLUDING THE USGS   AMPHIBIAN RESEARCH AND MONITORING INITIATIVE AND DOI LAND MANAGEMENT PARTNERS INCLUDING THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

PROJECT TITLE QUANTIFYING KING RAIL HABITAT SUITABILITY IN THE MISSISSIPPI ALLUVIAL VALLEYPROJECT PERIOD  8 8 22 7 31 24KING RAILS  RALLUS ELEGANS  ARE A MIGRATORY SPECIES OF SECRETIVE MARSH BIRD  RAILS, BITTERNS, GREBES, GALLINULES  AND ARE LISTED AS ENDANGERED OR THREATENED IN 12 U S  STATES AS WELL AS CANADA  PICKENS AND MEANLEY 2018   REDUCED WETLAND HABITAT THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE HAS LED TO DECLINING KING RAIL POPULATIONS AND IS CURRENTLY THE MOST CRITICAL THREAT TO THEIR PERSISTENCE  PICKENS AND MEANLEY 2018   KING RAILS, LIKE ALL SECRETIVE MARSH BIRDS, ARE CHALLENGING TO STUDY BECAUSE OF THEIR CRYPTIC BEHAVIOR AND USE OF HABITAT THAT CAN BE DIFFICULT FOR RESEARCHERS TO ACCESS  BROAD SCALE SURVEYS LIKE THE BREEDING BIRD SURVEY TYPICALLY ARE INADEQUATE FOR MONITORING SECRETIVE MARSH BIRDS, INCLUDING KING RAIL  LAWLER AND O CONNER 2004   INDIVIDUAL STUDIES ON KING RAIL HABITAT USE HAVE PROVIDED SOME EMPIRICAL INFORMATION BUT HAVE BEEN DISJUNCT IN TIME AND SPACE  THUS, BASIC INFORMATION ON KING RAIL ECOLOGY IS LIMITED, INCLUDING KNOWLEDGE OF THEIR HABITAT REQUIREMENTS THROUGHOUT THE FULL ANNUAL LIFE CYCLE   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  OBJECTIVESSYNTHESIZE EXISTING LITERATURE AND EXPERT KNOWLEDGE ON KING RAIL HABITAT REQUIREMENTS TO DETERMINE HABITAT FACTORS IMPORTANT FOR THEIR DISTRIBUTION THROUGHOUT THE ANNUAL LIFE CYCLE DEVELOP A CONCEPTUAL MODEL FOR KING RAIL HABITAT RELATIONSHIPS THROUGHOUT THE FULL ANNUAL CYCLE USING A BAYESIAN BELIEF NETWORK APPROACH AND IDENTIFY UNCERTAINTIES ASSOCIATED WITH SPECIES HABITAT RELATIONSHIPS   DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  DELIVERABLES   THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE A LITERATURE REVIEW AND SYNTHESIS OF KING RAIL HABITAT REQUIREMENTS, MANAGEMENT NEEDS AND UNCERTAINTIES RELATED TO SPECIES HABITAT DISTRIBUTION MODELS AND A CONCEPTUAL MODEL OF KING RAIL HABITAT RELATIONSHIPS THROUGHOUT THE FULL ANNUAL CYCLE THAT INCLUDES PROBABILITY OF OCCURRENCE AND UNCERTAINTY ESTIMATES SURROUNDING OCCURRENCE  PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL HELP FOCUS KING RAIL CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN THIS REGION  PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL BE SUBMITTED AS A FINAL REPORT AND DATA FILES, AS WELL AS A MANUSCRIPT TO BE SUBMITTED TO A SCIENTIFIC JOURNAL TIMELINE FOR ACTIVITIES  ANTICIPATE COMPLETING THESE OBJECTIVES WILL TAKE A POST DOCTORAL RESEARCHER 12 MONTHS   INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES   US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, MO COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, MISSISSIPPI ALLUVIAL VALLEY

PROJECT TITLE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA DORIS DUKE CONSERVATION SCHOLARS PROGRAMPROJECT PERIOD  8 8 22 6 30 24AWARD PURPOSE  EVALUATION OF THE AMOUNT OF INSTREAM FLOW NEEDED FOR ARIZONA S FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS REQUIRES STUDYING THE AQUATIC NEEDS OF SPECIES DEPENDENT ON RIPARIAN AREAS  WHICH ACCORDING TO MANY STUDIES IS 80 90  OF ARIZONA S VERTEBRATES   THESE STUDIES CAN BE INVOLVED AND REQUIRE A PROFUSION OF DATA COLLECTION AT LOW FLOW PERIODS, WITH PERIOTIC MONITORING AT OTHER TIMES OF YEAR  HOWEVER, MANAGEMENT AGENCIES REQUIRE JUST SUCH DATA TO PROTECT A STREAM REACH FROM EXCESS DIVERSION THIS FUNDING IS FOR UNDERREPRESENTED IN THE CONSERVATION WORKFORCE WHO CHOOSE TO PURSUE STUDIES AND A CAREER IN CONSERVATION TO HELP CONDUCT THE FOLLOWING TASKS  ESTIMATE THE HABITAT SUITABILITY CRITERIA OF SELECT ARIZONA FISHES IN WILDERNESS STREAMS DURING LOW FLOW CONDITIONS  HELP ESTIMATE THE HABITAT SUITABILITY CRITERIA OF SELECT ARIZONA FISHES IN WILDERNESS STREAMS DURING OTHER TIMES OF YEAR  ASSIST IN OTHER STUDIES IN FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AS NEEDED  THIS FUNDING COVERS SOME TIME OF GRADUATE STUDENT MENTORS AND UNIVERSITY FACULTY ADVISOR SO DATA CAN BE COLLECTED ACCURATELY AND ACCORDING TO STUDY DESIGN ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED   WILL WORK WITH U S  FOREST SERVICE PERSONNEL TO RESEARCH IN STREAM FLOW NEEDS OF FISH LOCATED IN STREAMS OF THE WET BEAVER WILDERNESS, THE WEST CLEAR CREEK WILDERNESS AREA, THE SYCAMORE CANYON WILDERNESS AND THE WEST FORK OAK CREEK WILDERNESS  WILL FIRST IDENTIFY WHICH FISH ARE PRESENT IN THESE STREAMS  NEXT WILL IDENTIFY THE HABITAT USE OF FISHES IN THESE REACHES BY SNORKELING FROM DOWNSTREAM TO UPSTREAM TO AVOID FRIGHTENING FISH AND WILL MARK FISH LOCATIONS  NEXT, THE HABITAT AVAILABLE TO FISHES WILL BE MEASURED BY RANDOMLY SELECTING SITES IN THE SAME STREAM REACH TO MEASURE HABITAT  HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS TO BE MEASURED AT EACH TRANSECT POINT AND AT EACH WASHER POINT WILL INCLUDE WATER DEPTH, WATER VELOCITY, SUBSTRATE TYPE  USING MODIFIED WENTWORTH SCALE , OVERHEAD CANOPY PRESENCE, IN STREAM COVER PRESENCE AND COVERAGE, AND MACROHABITAT TYPE  I E , POOL, RUN, RIFFLE   DATA FROM OCCUPIED HABITAT WILL BE COMPARED TO DATA FROM AVAILABLE HABITAT SURVEYS TO DEVELOP RESOURCE SELECTION FUNCTIONS AND HABITAT SUITABILITY CRITERIA FOR THE EXISTING FISHES  OTHER SIMILAR NATURAL RESOURCES WORK MAY BE CONDUCTED IN ADDITION TO THESE TASKS  STUDENTS FROM THE DORIS DUKE SCHOLARS PROGRAM WILL BE TRAINED IN FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE BIOLOGY  THE FACULTY COORDINATOR WILL MANAGE THE PROGRAM, HELP MENTOR GRADUATE STUDENTS, AND HELP ENSURE THAT SCHOLARS AND GRADUATE STUDENTS ARE FULFILLING THEIR ROLES IN THE RESEARCH PROJECTS  EACH OF THE GRADUATE STUDENT MENTORS WILL GATHER AND ANALYZE DATA, MENTOR TWO DORIS DUKE CONSERVATION SCHOLARS, AND HELP THE DORIS DUKE CONSERVATION SCHOLARS DEVELOP THEIR RESEARCH POSTERS AND PREPARE FOR PRESENTATIONS AT REGIONAL AND NATIONAL FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE CONFERENCES DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   POSTERS PRESENTATIONS ON AN ASPECT OF THE RESEARCH BY EACH DORIS DUKE STUDENT PARTICIPANT  DATA GOING INTO THE FINAL REPORT TO THE U S  FOREST SERVICE INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES    US FOREST SERVICE, DORIS DUKE SCHOLARS PROGRAM, UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA

PROJECT TITLE BUILDING A MODELING FRAMEWORK FOR UNDERSTANDING AND PREDICTING DYNAMICS OF DISEASES IN WILDLIFE  WNS SURVEILLANCE AS A CASE STUDYPROJECT PERIOD  9 7 22 7 31 24AWARD PURPOSE   AREDEVELOPING A MODELING FRAMEWORK THAT CAN BE USED THROUGHOUT THE  LIFECYCLE  OF A DISEASE   FROM EMERGENCE TO ESTABLISHMENT   PROVIDING INITIAL PREDICTIONS WHEN DATA IS POOR AND UNCERTAINTY IS HIGH, THAT CAN BE UPDATED AS MORE INFORMATION IS COLLECTED AND THE DISEASE SPREADS  THIS MODELING FRAMEWORK CAN BE USED TO GUIDE A RANGE OF QUESTIONS AS THEY EVOLVE DURING DISEASE PROGRESSIONS, INCLUDING WHERE TO TARGET INITIAL AND ONGOING SURVEILLANCE EFFORTS, IDENTIFYING NEEDED RESEARCH  ECOLOGICAL OR EPIDEMIOLOGICAL DRIVERS , AND OPTIMIZING AND INFORMING MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES  IN THIS AWARD, WE ARE FOCUSING ON USING THE MODELING FRAMEWORK TO DEVELOP A WEIGHTED SURVEILLANCE CALCULATOR THAT CAN HELP INFORM SITE SPECIFIC SAMPLE DESIGN FOR WHITE NOSE SYNDROME SURVEILLANCE   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  WILL BE DEVELOPING A WEIGHTED SURVEILLANCE CALCULATOR FOR WHITE NOSE SYNDROME BASED ON NATIONAL SURVEILLANCE DATA COLLECTED FROM 2012 2022   DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  A WEB DEPLOYED APPLICATION, SIMILAR TO THE ONE ALREADY DEVELOPED FOR CWD  HTTPS   POPR CFC UMT EDU CWD  , AND AT LEAST ONE PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION   INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES   NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS AND BAT CONSERVATIONIST THAT ARE SURVEYING AND SAMPLING FOR WHITE NOSE SYNDROME

PROJECT TITLE INVESTIGATING THE ROLE OF HOST BEHAVIOR AND ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSMISSION IN CWD DYNAMICS PROJECTPROJECT PERIOD  9 7 22 6 30 25AWARD PURPOSE   THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO DEVELOP A MODELING FRAMEWORK THAT EXPLICITLY INCORPORATES HOST SOCIAL BEHAVIOR AND MOVEMENT WITH CWD PRION RETENTION, TRANSPORT, AND INFECTION POTENTIAL IN COMPLEX LANDSCAPES WHEN ESTIMATING AND PREDICTING CWD DYNAMICS   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED   WILL FOCUS ON MODEL DEVELOPMENT THAT WILL HAVE GENERAL APPLICATION TO VARIOUS WILDLIFE SYSTEMS WHERE ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSMISSION PLAYS AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN THE TRANSMISSION PROCESSES  SPECIFICALLY, WILL DEVELOP A DETERMINISTIC MODEL SCAFFOLD, EMBEDDED IN A STATISTICAL FRAMEWORK, TO INTEGRATE HETEROGENEITIES IN SOCIAL BEHAVIOR AND MOVEMENT WITH PATHOGEN RETENTION, TRANSPORT, AND INFECTION POTENTIAL IN COMPLEX LANDSCAPES  WILL BASE ON OUR DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION OF THIS FRAMEWORK ON CWD IN THE MIDWESTERN UNITED STATES BUT INTEND TO STRUCTURE OUR MODEL DEVELOPMENT FOR EASY EXTENSION TO OTHER SYSTEMS  THE WORK IS PART OF A LARGER PROJECT IN COLLABORATION WITH THE WICRU, THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE HEALTH CENTER AND THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN  THE COLLABORATORS WILL BE PROVIDING THE FIELD AND LABORATORY DATA THAT WILL BE USED TO PARAMETERIZE OUR MODELS   DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   WE EXPECT THAT THE FINAL PRODUCT FROM THIS WORK WILL BE A GENERALIZABLE MODELING FRAMEWORK THAT WILL ALLOW TO EXAMINE THE IMPACTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSMISSION ON CWD DYNAMICS  WILL ALSO MAKE THE UNDERLYING CODE ACCESSIBLE VIA TUTORIAL DOCUMENTS OR WITHIN A COMPUTER PACKAGE  LASTLY, E INTEND TO HAVE RESULTS PRESENTED IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL AND DISSEMINATED TO CWD MANAGERS BROADLY THROUGH PRESENTATIONS AT RELEVANT CONFERENCES INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES    THE DIRECT BENEFICIARY WILL BE USGS BIOTHREATS PROGRAM, STATE AGENCIES MANAGING CWD INCLUDING MONTANA FISH WILDLIFE AND PARKS, BUT ALSO THE GREATER WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY BECAUSE THE PRODUCTS AND METHODS ARE INTENDED TO GENERALIZE TO OTHER DISEASE SYSTEMS THAT INCLUDE ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSMISSION PROCESSES

PROJECT TITLE STATISTICAL MODEL DEVELOPMENT TO INFORM DISEASE MANAGEMENT IN MONTANA PROJECT STARTUPPROJECT PERIOD  9 7 22 6 30 27AWARD PURPOSE   THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE STATISTICAL EXPERTISE TO SUPPORT MODEL DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION OF QUANTITATIVE TOOLS FOR EXAMINING THE BEHAVIOR OF WILDLIFE DISEASE SYSTEMS INCLUDING RESPONSES TO CURRENT OR PROPOSED MANAGEMENT ACTIONS  THE MODELS WILL THEN BE USED TO INFORM WILDLIFE HEALTH MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BY MONTANA FISH WILDLIFE AND PARKS   ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED   WILL FOCUS ON STATISTICAL MODEL DEVELOPMENT THAT WILL HAVE GENERAL APPLICATION TO VARIOUS WILDLIFE SYSTEMS SUCH AS BIGHORN SHEEP RESPIRATORY DISEASE, CHRONIC WASTING DISEASE, ETC  SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL BE EXAMINING HOW TO MEASURE THE IMPACTS OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON SYSTEM PROCESSES AND INCORPORATING DISEASE IMPACTS INTO INTEGRATED POPULATION MODELS  THESE MODELS WILL THEN BE USED TO PROJECT FUTURE POPULATION DYNAMICS AND INFORM AGENCY ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PLANNING AND EVALUATION EFFORTS   DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL BE A MODELING FRAMEWORK THAT CAN BE TAILORED TO SPECIFIC SYSTEMS CAN BE APPLIED THE STATE WILDLIFE AGENCY TO ASSESS THE EFFICACY OF DISEASE MITIGATION EFFORTS AS WELL AS POTENTIAL POPULATION IMPACTS ON THE HEALTH AND DYNAMICS ON A WILDLIFE POPULATION OF INTEREST   INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES    THE DIRECT BENEFICIARY WILL BE MONTANA FISH WILDLIFE AND PARKS, BUT ALSO THE GREATER WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT COMMUNITY BECAUSE THE PRODUCTS AND METHODS ARE INTENDED TO GENERALIZE TO OTHER SYSTEMS

PROJECT TITLE:ASSESSING THREATS TO CRITICAL SEABIRD FORAGING HABITAT IN THE SALISH SEAPROJECT PERIOD: 8/1/22-9/30/24THIS AGREEMENT WILL ALLOW USGS SCIENTISTS TO WORK WITH COOPERATORS ON A MULTI-YEAR STUDY IN WHICH THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL USE A COMBINATION OF FINE-SCALE GLOBAL POSITIONING SYSTEM TRACKING AND DEMOGRAPHIC MODELING TO IDENTIFY AND CHARACTERIZE CRITICAL FORAGING SITES FOR PIGEON GUILLEMOTS AND RHINOCEROS AUKLETS NESTING AT PROTECTION ISLAND, WASHINGTON AND TO CHARACTERIZE LINKAGES BETWEEN FORAGING HABITAT AND BREEDING OUTCOMES. THIS WILL HELP US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE PREPARE FOR INCREASING THREATS TO FORAGING HABITAT IMPACTING SEABIRDS IN THE SALISH SEA. THE FUNDING UNDER THIS RESEARCH WORK ORDER WILL SUPPORT DATA COLLECTION IN 2023, THE SECOND YEAR OF THIS MULTI-YEAR PROJECT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -ACTIVITY 1: IDENTIFY SPECIFIC CRITICAL FORAGING SITES USED BY PIGEON GUILLEMOTS AND RHINOCEROS AUKLETS NESTING AT PROTECTION ISLAND, WASHINGTON, AND DETERMINE THE CHARACTERISTICS OF FORAGING HABITAT THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF FORAGING HABITAT RESOURCE SELECTION FUNCTIONS FOR EACH SPECIES. THIS WILL INVOLVE GPS TAGGING INDIVIDUALS OF THESE TWO SPECIES TO IDENTIFY AREAS USED DURING FORAGING AND USING THIS INFORMATION TO BUILD RESOURCE SELECTION FUNCTIONS FOR EACH BASED ON ENVIRONMENTAL COVARIATES.ACTIVITY 2: IDENTIFY RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN FORAGING CONDITIONS AND DEMOGRAPHY. THIS WILL INVOLVE MONITORING NESTING OUTCOMES FOR THE TWO FOCAL SPECIES AND LINKING BREEDING SUCCESS WITH ASPECTS OF FORAGING HABITAT SELECTED BY INDIVIDUALS. THIS WILL ALLOW EXPLORATION OF THOSE HABITAT FEATURES THAT ARE MOST CRITICAL FOR SUCCESSFUL REPRODUCTION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -DELIVERABLES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE AN INTERIM REPORT (NOVEMBER 2023) AS WELL AS A FINAL REPORT (NOVEMBER 2024) THAT OUTLINES METHODS AND RESULTS. THE FINAL REPORT WILL IDENTIFY KEY FORAGING AREAS FOR TWO SEABIRDS IN THE SALISH SEA, THE PIGEON GUILLEMOT AND THE RHINOCEROS AUKLET. US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WILL USE THIS INFORMATION TO INFORM CONSERVATION PLANNING GIVEN INCREASING RISKS TO FORAGING HABITAT FOR THESE SPECIES. INFORMATION WILL ALSO BE PRESENTED TO THE BROADER SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY VIA A MANUSCRIPT FOR PUBLICATION IN A JOURNAL AND PRESENTATIONS AT SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES, INCLUDING THE SALISH SEA ECOSYSTEM CONFERENCE AND THE PACIFIC SEABIRD GROUP CONFERENCE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) - US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

PROJECT TITLE CHARACTERIZING CHINOOK SALMON GENOMIC DIVERSITY IN SUPPORT OF CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENTPROJECT PERIOD  9 19 22 9 30 27SUMMARY  THE PURPOSE OF THE AWARD IS TO STUDY THE GENETIC BASIS IN CHINOOK SALMON FOR TRAITS SUCH AS AGE STRUCTURE, BODY SIZE, AND JUVENILE LIFE HISTORY  THE APPROACH INVOLVES GENOME SEQUENCING AND A VARIETY OF GENOME WIDE ASSOCIATION STUDIES  THE GOALS ARE TO, 1  CHARACTERIZE GENETIC RESOURCES AVAILABLE FOR CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OF US WEST COAST CHINOOK SALMON POPULATIONS  FOCUS ON PUGET SOUND POPULATIONS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT , AND 2  IDENTIFY GENETIC MARKERS FOR TRAITS AND CHARACTERIZE THEIR DISTRIBUTIONS IN HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY POPULATIONS AND FISHERY SAMPLES ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  THE AWARDEE WILL USE EXTENSIVE DNA SEQUENCE DATA SETS, INCLUDING RESTRICTION SITE ASSOCIATED DNA SEQUENCE AND WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCES ACROSS LINEAGES, POPULATIONS, AND CHINOOK SALMON FAMILIES  BIOINFORMATICS, STATISTICAL GENOMICS, AND EVOLUTIONARY THEORY WILL BE USED TO ADDRESS A WIDE RANGE OF CONSERVATION RELATED PROBLEMS, FROM MAPPING QUANTITATIVE TRAIT LOCI TO HISTORICAL BIOGEOGRAPHY AND DEMOGRAPHICS  CREATIVITY IS EXPECTED IN APPLYING ADVANCED MATHEMATICAL AND COMPUTATIONAL METHODS TO DISTINGUISH AMONG EVOLUTIONARY MODELS, ESPECIALLY IN THE PRESENCE OF POTENTIALLY CONFOUNDING FORCES OF MIGRATION, MUTATION, AND DEMOGRAPHY DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO RESULT IN THE IDENTIFICATION OF GENETIC MARKERS ASSOCIATED WITH SPECIFIC PHENOTYPIC TRAITS THAT ARE RELEVANT TO POPULATION PRODUCTIVITY AND PERSISTENCE  THOSE MARKERS WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO EXISTING AMPLICON PANELS FOR ROUTINE RESEARCH, MONITORING, AND EVALUATION OF FISHERY HARVEST AND BYCATCH IMPACTS  APPLIED TO HISTORICAL SCALE SAMPLES, THESE MARKERS WILL ALLOW A MORE COMPLETE UNDERSTANDING OF EVOLUTIONARY CHANGE IN THE FREQUENCY DISTRIBUTION OF ALLELES ASSOCIATED WITH SPECIFIC PHENOTYPES  DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE REPORTS ON THE RESULTS OF FISHERY IMPACTS TO NOAA WEST COAST REGION, PACIFIC FISHERY MANAGEMENT COUNCIL, CONSERVATION GROUPS, AND INDUSTRY, AS WELL AS PUBLICATIONS IN THE PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE INTENDED BENEFICIARY IES  GENOMIC INFORMATION CAN PROVIDE AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE EVOLUTIONARY TRAJECTORY AND POTENTIAL RANGE OF EXPRESSION OF PHENOTYPIC TRAITS WITHIN AND AMONG POPULATIONS  THE VALUE OF GENOMIC DATA IS FURTHER COMPOUNDED WHEN APPLIED TO PEDIGREES IN HATCHERY AND WILD POPULATIONS  THIS INFORMATION IS CURRENTLY SOUGHT BY NOAA FOR STOCK SPECIFIC RESTORATION POTENTIAL IN PUGET SOUND AND ELSEWHERE  TRIBAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL FISHERY CO MANAGERS WILL BENEFIT FROM A MORE GRANULAR VIEW OF HARVEST AND BYCATCH IMPACTS ON CHINOOK SALMON PROTECTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  INDUSTRY AND THE PUBLIC BENEFIT WHEN INCREASED INFORMATION ALLOWS MANAGERS TO RELAX PRECAUTIONARY REGULATIONS THAT ARE REQUIRED WHEN THOSE IMPACTS ARE UNCERTAIN

PROJECT TITLE:NATIONAL HORIZON SCAN OF POTENTIAL AQUATIC PLANT HITCH HIKERSPROJECT PERIOD: 8/1/2022-6/29/2024ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THIS PROJECT'S GOAL IS TO CONDUCT A CONDUCT A GLOBAL HORIZON SCAN TO HELP IDENTIFY ALIEN HITCHHIKERS SPECIES THAT ARE MOVED ON AQUATIC PLANTS IN THE ORGANISMS IN TRADE PATHWAY. THESE HITCHHIKERS COULD BE PLANT OR ANIMAL IN NATURE AND COULD REPRESENT A RISK TO THE ECOLOGY AND ECONOMY OF U.S. DRAINAGES. THE PARTNERSHIP IS SPECIFICALLY GEARED TO ADVANCE THE VALUE OF THE ANALYSIS OF THE CURRENT MANAGEMENT AND PREVENTION OF AIS. ONCE AN AIS BECOMES ESTABLISHED, IT IS RARELY POSSIBLE TO ERADICATE. THE BEST WAY TO AVOID THE NEGATIVE IMPACTS THAT INVASIVE SPECIES CAN CAUSE TO A WATERSHED'S ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION, ECONOMIC VALUE, OR CITIZENS' HEALTH IS TO PREVENT THEIR INITIAL ENTRY. BY IDENTIFYING WHICH IMPORTED AQUATIC PLANTS CARRY HITCHHIKER ORGANISMS AND BY EVALUATING THE RISK OF THOSE ORGANISMS, FUTURE INVASIONS COULD BE PREVENTED.THE UNIVERSITY AND U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY RESEARCH TEAMS WILL CONDUCT A GLOBAL HORIZON SCAN OF PLANTS AND ASSOCIATED ORGANISMS. THE TEAM WILL DISCUSS THE OBJECTIVES FROM A STRATEGIC PERSPECTIVE AND DEVELOP A LINE OF ATTACK TO ADDRESS THOSE OBJECTIVES. WE ANTICIPATE THE WORK WILL EVOLVE OVER TIME AS NEEDED THROUGH A COLLABORATIVE PROCESS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: -NUMEROUS AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PATHWAYS ARE MANAGED THROUGH VARIOUS FEDERAL AND STATE AUTHORITIES. AN OFTEN OVERLOOKED COMPONENT IS THE IMPORTATION OF ORGANISMS ON PLANTS IN TRADE. A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW IS NEEDED TO EFFECTIVELY DOCUMENT AND PREDICT ORGANISMS MOST LIKELY TO HARBOR THESE HITCHHIKERS AND COORDINATE AND MANAGE THOSE PATHWAYS AND PREVENT FUTURE INTRODUCTIONS THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THIS INFORMATION BY CRITICALLY REVIEWING CASE STUDIES OF IMPORTED ORGANISMS AND AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES.RESULTS OBTAINED THROUGH THE WORK WILL BE DISSEMINATED THROUGH ORAL PRESENTATIONS, JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS, AND FINAL REPORT TO U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. DISSEMINATION OF DATA AND RESEARCH RESULTS WILL FOLLOW USGS GUIDELINES FOR DATA MANAGEMENT AND PEER REVIEW AND WILL BE DONE IN A COLLABORATIVE MANNER FOR MUTUAL BENEFIT.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

PROJECT TITLE:DEVELOPMENT OF WEST COAST REGION SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH PERMITTING DATA VISUALIZATION TOOLSPROJECT PERIOD: 8/1/22-9/30/23THE NATIONAL MARINE FISHERIES SERVICE WEST COAST REGION ISSUES PERMITS FOR SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH THAT MAY RESULT IN THE TAKE OF THREATENED OR ENDANGERED FISH UNDER SPECIFIC SECTIONS OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA). AS PART OF THIS PROCESS NOAA IS REQUIRED TO ANALYZE THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS RESEARCH MAY HAVE ON ANY ESA-LISTED SPECIES AFFECTED. THE CURRENT SYSTEM DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM DOES NOT PROVIDE A WAY TO EASILY SUMMARIZE AMOUNTS OF TAKE REQUESTED AND AUTHORIZED SPATIALLY AT A SCALE THAT IS RELEVANT TO RESEARCH PROJECTS. IT ALSO DOES NOT CURRENTLY PROVIDE A WAY FOR RESEARCHERS, CO-MANAGERS, OR THE PUBLIC TO SEE RESEARCH PERMITS SUMMARIZED ACROSS THE REGION ON THE BASIS OF SPECIES, STATE, OR PERMITTING AUTHORITY. THIS CAN MAKE IT DIFFICULT FOR APPLICANTS TO UNDERSTAND NOAA'S PERMITTING DECISIONS, SUCH AS WHO MAY BE PERMITTED UNDER DIFFERENT AUTHORITIES AND IN DIFFERENT LOCATIONS, OR WHY SOME REQUESTS FOR RESEARCH PERMITS MAY BE MODIFIED OR DENIED. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A TOOL TO VISUALLY SUMMARIZE TAKE ASSOCIATED WITH SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH AUTHORIZED ACROSS THE WEST COAST REGION. THIS TOOL WOULD BENEFIT NOAA STAFF IN ANALYZING OF EFFECTS OF ISSUING RESEARCH PERMITS, AND THE POTENTIAL CUMULATIVE IMPACTS ON ESA-LISTED SPECIES, AND PROVIDE GREATER TRANSPARENCY IN COMMUNICATING PERMITTING INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC.- ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PRODUCE VISUAL SUMMARIES OF LISTED SPECIES IMPACTS ASSOCIATED WITH SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH AUTHORIZED ACROSS THE WEST COAST REGION. UNDER THIS TASK, A UW GRADUATE STUDENT TEAM ADVISED BY DR. ANNE BEAUDREAU (SCHOOL OF MARINE AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS) WILL QUANTITATIVELY SUMMARIZE TAKE ASSOCIATED WITH NOAA'S VARIOUS ESA AUTHORITIES FOR PERMITTING THREATENED AND ENDANGERED FISH SPECIES TAKE FOR SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH. THESE SUMMARIES WILL BE SPATIALLY-EXPLICIT AT A SCALE THAT IS RELEVANT TO ESA SPECIES MANAGEMENT (E.G., STATE, WATER BODY, OR WATERSHED-LEVEL) AND PARSED BY SPECIES ATTRIBUTES CRITICAL TO ANALYSIS OF EFFECTS (I.E., AGE CLASS AND HATCHERY VERSUS NATURAL-ORIGIN). THE UW GRADUATE STUDENTS WILL ALSO INCLUDE A SUMMARY OF METADATA CRITICAL FOR INTERPRETATION OF THE DATA THEY ANALYZE. THE DATA SUMMARIES WILL BE DELIVERED TO NOAA STAFF IN A MEDIUM THAT ALLOWS VISUALIZATIONS TO BE UPDATED BY NOAA IN THE FUTURE USING NEW INPUT DATA, AND ALSO ALLOWS THE SUMMARY FORMAT OR PLATFORM TO BE EDITED.- DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -NO LATER THAN SEPTEMBER 30, 2023 THE USGS SHALL PROVIDE A SUMMARY REPORT DESCRIBING PROGRESS MADE DURING THE PROJECT PERIOD, INTERIM COPIES OF DATA VISUALIZATION PRODUCTS AND THE FILES USED TO GENERATE THEM, AND DRAFT METADATA DOCUMENTATION.- INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -THE FUNDS WILL BE PROVIDED TO UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON AND TO GRADUATE STUDENT RESEARCH ASSISTANTS.

PROJECT TITLE:LEVERAGING HABITAT SUITABILITY MODELING TO INFORM MANAGEMENT OF NONNATIVE FISHES IN A CHANGING CLIMATEPROJECT PERIOD: 8/1/2022-12/31/2024CLIMATE CHANGE IS A KEY PROCESS INFLUENCING THE DISTRIBUTION AND SOCIETAL EFFECTS OF AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES, PARTICULARLY NONNATIVE FISHES. AS AQUATIC THERMAL REGIMES CHANGE WORLDWIDE, THERE ARE SERIOUS IMPLICATIONS FOR NONNATIVE FISH DISTRIBUTION BECAUSE WATER TEMPERATURE IS A "MASTER VARIABLE" AFFECTING FISH BIOENERGETICS, INDIVIDUAL GROWTH, AND POPULATION AND COMMUNITY STRUCTURE. AS SUCH, UNDERSTANDING WATER TEMPERATURE VARIABILITY (E.G., DAILY, SEASONAL, ANNUAL) AND THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON AQUATIC THERMAL REGIMES IS IMPORTANT FOR MANAGING NONNATIVE FISHES. HOWEVER, COORDINATED EFFORTS TO MONITOR AQUATIC THERMAL REGIMES ARE UNCOMMON AND SPATIALLY RESTRICTED IN THE SOUTHEAST COMPARED TO OTHER U.S. REGIONS. THE STATE OF FLORIDA HAS 431 NONNATIVE AQUATIC SPECIES AND MORE THAN 200 NONNATIVE FISHES, BUT AQUATIC THERMAL REGIMES REMAIN POORLY UNDERSTOOD IN SEVERAL WAYS: (1) IN KEY WATER BODIES THAT ARE PRONE TO NONNATIVE FISH OCCURRENCE, PARTICULARLY FLORIDA RIVERS AND CANALS IN SOUTH FLORIDA; (2) AT SUFFICIENT SPATIOTEMPORAL AND ONTOGENETIC RESOLUTION FOR PREDICTING WHEN AND WHERE NONNATIVE FISHES ARE LIKELY TO OCCUR ACROSS THEIR LIFE HISTORY; AND (3) IN THE CONTEXT OF CLIMATE CHANGE, PARTICULARLY SHIFTING AIR TEMPERATURE, PRECIPITATION, AND GROUNDWATER REGIMES. TO ADDRESS THESE UNCERTAINTIES, WE ARE BUILDING A MULTIAGENCY TEAM TO MONITOR WATER TEMPERATURES AND THERMAL DYNAMICS AND MODEL NONNATIVE FISH SURVIVAL, REPRODUCTION, RECRUITMENT, AND DISPERSAL IN RIVERS, CANALS, AND SELECT LAKES ACROSS THE STATE OF FLORIDA UNDER DIFFERENT CLIMATE CHANGE SCENARIOS IN 2022-2072. WILL MEASURE HOURLY WATER TEMPERATURES IN FLORIDA RIVERS AND CANALS IN 75 LOCATIONS OVER THE PROJECT DURATION. WILL SUMMARIZE WATER TEMPERATURES USING THERMAL METRICS REPRESENTING FACETS OF NONNATIVE FISH LIFE HISTORY. THEN, WILL MODEL THESE THERMAL FACETS AS A FUNCTION OF RIVER NETWORK, LANDSCAPE, AND CLIMATE ATTRIBUTES USING GEOSTATISTICAL MODELS THAT EXPLICITLY CONSIDER RIVER NETWORK GEOMETRY AND CONNECTIVITY AND THEREBY INCREASE MODEL ACCURACY. RIVER NETWORK, LANDSCAPE, AND CLIMATE DATA FOR THERMAL FACET MODELS WILL BE OBTAINED FROM DATABASES SUCH AS NHDPLUS VERSION 2 AND THE FLORIDA CLIMATE CENTER, AND MODELS WILL BE COMPARED USING INFORMATION-THEORETIC MODEL SELECTION PROCEDURES AS DESCRIBED IN PREVIOUS PAPERS. WILL USE THERMAL FACET MODELS (OBJECTIVE 1) TO PROJECT WHEN AND WHERE PRIORITY NONNATIVE FISHES (IDENTIFIED IN COLLABORATION WITH FLORIDA FISHERIES MANAGERS) ARE LIKELY TO SURVIVE, REPRODUCE, AND DISPERSE IN FLORIDA RIVERS AND CANALS IN 2022-2072. WE WILL MAKE THESE PROJECTIONS UNDER DIFFERENT SCENARIOS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, INCLUDING AIR TEMPERATURE, PRECIPITATION, AND GROUNDWATER REGIMES. AS DESCRIBED FULLY IN OUR PREVIOUS PAPERS, WILL INTEGRATE MULTIPLE GLOBAL CLIMATE MODELS INTO AIR TEMPERATURE WARMING INCREMENTS AND MODEL THE EFFECTS OF PRECIPITATION AND GROUNDWATER DYNAMICS ON WATER TEMPERATURE IN EACH WARMING SCENARIO. IN ADDITION, MODELS WILL EXPLICITLY ACCOUNT FOR EXPECTED INCREASES IN THERMAL SENSITIVITY. TO ASSIST FISHERIES MANAGERS IN USING RESULTS, WILL CREATE USER-FRIENDLY, INTERACTIVE MAPS THAT DEPICT: (1) SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL PATTERNS IN THERMAL HABITAT SUITABILITY FOR EGG EMERGENCE, JUVENILE REARING, ADULT DISPERSAL, AND SPAWNING OF NONNATIVE FISHES; (2) TIME PERIODS AND LOCATIONS WHEN AND WHERE NONNATIVE-NATIVE SPECIES INTERACTIONS ARE LIKELY TO OCCUR; AND (3) HIGH-PRIORITY AREAS FOR NONNATIVE FISH MANAGEMENT EFFORTS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS AND A FINAL REPORT. BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE FISHERIES/AQUATIC RESOURCE SCIENTISTS, MANAGERS, BIOLOGISTS, AND THE PUBLIC.
