PROJECT TITLE: NOVEL METHODS FOR STUDYING HUMAN-WOLF INTERACTIONS IN WASHINGTONPROJECT PERIOD: 7/15/22-7/31/24AS GRAY WOLVES (CANIS LUPUS) RECOLONIZE WASHINGTON STATE, THEY PROVOKE STRONG, POLARIZED RESPONSES AMONG THE STATE'S DIVERSE HUMAN COMMUNITIES. WHILE NUMEROUS STUDIES HAVE INVESTIGATED THE UNIQUE REACTION OF PEOPLE TO WOLVES AND WOLF MANAGEMENT, MANAGING WOLVES AND HUMAN-WOLF INTERACTIONS REMAINS CHALLENGING, AND NEW METHODS IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL SOCIAL SCIENCES OFFER GREAT PROMISE IN REVEALING PATTERNS AND SUPPORTING MANAGEMENT. IN THIS STUDY, WE WILL WORK WITH THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE IN THREE NEW METHODOLOGICAL DOMAINS THAT HAVE BEEN URGENTLY CALLED FOR BUT RARELY APPLIED IN THE SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE. THESE DOMAINS ARE 1) LONGITUDINAL (I.E., REPEATED OVER TIME) STUDIES OF ATTITUDES AND PERSPECTIVES OVER TIME IN AN AREA EXPERIENCING RECOLONIZATION; 2) MAPPING SOCIAL PHENOMENA TO COMPLEMENT ECOLOGICAL UNDERSTANDINGS OF HABITAT SUITABILITY AND CONNECTIVITY; AND 3) INCLUDING ROBUST UNDERSTANDINGS OF ATTITUDES AND VALUES IN SCIENCE COMMUNICATION. TAKEN TOGETHER, THESE METHODS CAN OFFER INSIGHTS AT LOCAL AND BROAD SCALES AND HELP IDENTIFY SYSTEMS UNDER STRESS AND PRIORITIZE MANAGEMENT. THE SUPPORT PROVIDED BY THIS FUNDING WILL TRAIN A GRADUATE STUDENT INVESTIGATOR IN THIS IMPORTANT BUT UNDERSTUDIED RESEARCH DOMAIN AND WILL DIRECTLY LEAD TO THE PRODUCTION OF A DISSERTATION CHAPTER.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:THE RESEARCH WILL INCLUDE THREE FOCAL AREAS: 1) CONDUCTING LONGITUDINAL ASSESSMENTS ABOUT ATTITUDES AND PERCEPTIONS TOWARD WOLVES OVER TIME, ESPECIALLY IN AREAS WHERE RECOLONIZATION HAS YET TO OCCUR BUT IS HIGHLY LIKELY; 2) MAPPING TOLERANCE OF WOLVES TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTAND OF HABITAT SUITABILITY, CONNECTIVITY, AND CONFLICT; AND 3) EXAMINING HOW TARGETED EDUCATION AND OUTREACH CAN EMPLOY UNDERSTANDING OF CONFLICTING AND SHARED VALUES TO SUPPORT MANAGEMENT.DELIVERABLES:THIS FUNDING WILL PRODUCE 2 PROGRESS REPORTS, A FINAL REPORT, AND 1-2 DISSERTATION CHAPTERSINTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES):THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT AN INCOMING PHD STUDENT RESEARCHER

PROJECT TITLE:SURVEY EVALUATING EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ASSOCIATED WITH THE ROCKFISH RECOVERY PLANPROJECT PERIOD: 6/15/22-9/30/23THREE SPECIES OF ROCKFISHES (SEBASTES SPP.) IN PUGET SOUND, WASHINGTON, WERE LISTED FOR PROTECTION UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 2010 (ONE HAS SINCE BEEN DELISTED). IN RESPONSE TO THIS LISTING, THE WASHINGTON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (WDFW) IMPLEMENTED A RETENTION BAN ON ALL ROCKFISH WITHIN THE REGION, LIMITED TARGETING OF ALL BOTTOMFISH TO 120 FEET DEEP, AND REQUIRED ANGLERS TO HAVE A DESCENDING DEVICE RIGGED AND READY WHEN TARGETING BOTTOMFISH. IN 2012, A SURVEY OF FISHERY PARTICIPANTS DEMONSTRATED THAT MANY ANGLERS LIKELY TO ENCOUNTER THESE LISTED SPECIES WERE UNABLE TO EFFECTIVELY DISTINGUISH THEM FROM OTHER SPECIES COMMONLY ENCOUNTERED IN RECREATIONAL FISHERIES. THIS FINDING LED THE WDFW, NMFS, AND OTHER PARTNERS TO EXPEND SIGNIFICANT RESOURCES ON DIVERSE FORMS OF ANGLER OUTREACH TO INCREASE ROCKFISH IDENTIFICATION ABILITY AND FAMILIARITY WITH FISHING REGULATIONS FROM 2013-2021. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS THE EFFECTIVENESS OF NEARLY A DECADE OF ROCKFISH-RELATED OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT EFFORTS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -THIS PROJECT ENTAILS TWO PHASES. PHASE ONE WILL EVALUATE THE ROLE OF AGENCY EDUCATION AND OUTREACH EFFORTS IN INCREASING ANGLERS' KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ROCKFISHES AND BOTTOMFISHING REGULATIONS, THOUGH THE ANALYSIS OF DATA FROM AN ONLINE SURVEY CONDUCTED BY WDFW. PHASE TWO WILL EXPLORE STAKEHOLDER AND AGENCY PERCEPTIONS REGARDING ROCKFISH-RELATED OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT OVER THE LAST DECADE AND ATTITUDES TOWARDS / KNOWLEDGE OF ROCKFISHES TO COMPARE WITH PREVIOUS RESEARCH. THE UW WILL ASSIST WITH ANALYSIS OF PHASE ONE SURVEY RESULTS (THE SURVEY IS BEING ADMINISTERED BY WDFW) AND WILL IMPLEMENT PHASE TWO OF THE STUDY, WHICH WILL PRIMARILY INVOLVE PARTICIPATION IN EXISTING PUBLIC MEETINGS (E.G., FISHING ASSOCIATION MEETINGS) THAT ARE NOT STRUCTURED AS A SURVEY OR FOCUS GROUP MECHANISM, TO OBSERVE AND DISCUSS AGENCY OUTREACH EFFORTS WITH STAKEHOLDERS. THE TEAM MAY ALSO HAVE A SMALL NUMBER OF IN-DEPTH CONVERSATIONS WITH LONG-TIME FISHERS WHO HAVE KNOWLEDGE OF ROCKFISH (9 OR FEWER INDIVIDUALS PER YEAR) AND NOAA AGENCY STAFF.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -THE UW WILL INTEGRATE RESULTS OF BOTH PHASES INTO A REPORT EVALUATING THE EFFICACY OF RECENT OUTREACH AND EDUCATION EFFORTS WITH REGARD TO ANGLER KNOWLEDGE OF ROCKFISH IDENTIFICATION AND BOTTOMFISH FISHING REGULATIONS IN PUGET SOUND. THE REPORT WILL PROVIDE TARGETED RECOMMENDATIONS TO IMPROVE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF OUTREACH EFFORTS AS DATA ALLOW.- A PROGRESS REPORT WILL BE PROVIDED BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2022.- A FINAL REPORT/SURVEY EVALUATION WILL BE PROVIDED BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2023.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -THE FUNDS WILL BE PROVIDED TO DR. ANNE BEAUDREAU, ASSOCIATE PROFESSOR, SCHOOL OF MARINE AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS, UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON AND TO GRADUATE STUDENT RESEARCH ASSISTANTS ADVISED BY DR. BEAUDREAU.

PROJECT TITLED:ASSESSING AQUATIC MACROINVERTEBRATE COMMUNITIES IN EPHEMERAL PONDSPROJECT PERIOD: 7/18/22-12/31/24PONDS OF VARIOUS SIZES ARE FOUND ACROSS THE COUNTRY AND OFTEN VARY IN THE AMOUNT OF TIME THEY HOLD WATER. WHEN PONDS DO NOT HOLD WATER MOST OF THE YEAR, THEY ALSO DO NOT ALLOW FOR FISH, BUT THESE PONDS MAY BE IMPORTANT FOR OTHER ANIMALS LIKE AMPHIBIANS AND INSECTS. IN THESE SITUATIONS, THE INSECTS THAT USE THE PONDS MAY BE QUITE DIFFERENT FROM INSECTS THAT OCCUR IN PONDS THAT HAVE FISH YEAR-ROUND. IN THIS STUDY, WILL SAMPLE FOR AQUATIC INSECTS IN A SERIES OF RESEARCH PONDS AT OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY WHERE CAN CONTROL HOW LONG THEY HOLD WATER AND WHETHER THEY HAVE FISH. IN THE FIELD, WILL USE PONDS LOCATED ON THE OSAGE NATION RANCH, LOCATED IN OSAGE COUNTY, OKLAHOMA, AND SAMPLE FOR INSECTS AND FISH. WITH THESE PIECES OF INFORMATION, CAN EXAMINE HOW FISH MIGHT AFFECT WHICH KIND OF INSECTS OCCUR IN THESE SYSTEMS AND HOW FISHLESS PONDS CAN CONTRIBUTE TO OVERALL BIODIVERSITY OF INSECTS. A GRADUATE STUDENT WILL CONDUCT THE RESEARCH AND PRODUCE A THESIS, WHICH WILL ALSO BE DELIVERED TO THE OSAGE NATION TO HELP THEM MANAGE THEIR RESOURCES LOCATED IN THEIR 45,000 ACRE RANCH.

PROJECT TITLE:IMPROVING DOCUMENTATION OF CRITICALLY IMPERILED LUDWIGIA RAVENII (ONAGRACEAE) THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF A TAXONOMIC KEY TO HYBRIDS WITH OTHER MEMBERS OF SECT. ISNARDIA BASED ON CONTROLLED CROSSESPROJECT PERIOD: 6/1/22-6/30/27RAVEN'S SEEDBOX (LUDWIGIA RAVENII, ONAGRACEAE) IS A CRITICALLY IMPERILED, TETRAPLOID FORB KNOWN HISTORICALLY FROM FLORIDA TO VIRGINIA. THE SPECIES IS AN OBLIGATE OF WETLANDS, WHICH ARE CRITICAL FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT. IDENTIFICATION CAN BE A CHALLENGE, AS THE SPECIES SHARES SOME MORPHOLOGICAL FEATURES WITH MORE WIDESPREAD SPECIES, SUCH AS L. PILOSA AND L. SPHAEROCARPA. CONFOUNDING THE PROBLEM IS THE EXISTENCE OF HYBRIDS THAT CANNOT BE RELIABLY KEYED AND AT A GLANCE COULD BE MISTAKEN FOR THE IMPERILED TAXON. CONSEQUENTLY, OUR FIRST OBJECTIVE IS TO DEVELOP A PHOTOGRAPHIC KEY TO THE HYBRIDS OF L. RAVENII AND OTHER MEMBERS OF SECT. ISNARDIA FOUND WITHIN THE RANGE OF THE FORMER, BASED ON CONTROLLED CROSSES. OUR SECOND OBJECTIVE IS TO CONTRIBUTE TO A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HABITAT OF L. RAVENII THROUGH QUANTITATIVE ANALYSIS OF VEGETATION AND SOILS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - INTEND TO COLLECT SEEDS OF AT LEAST FIVE INDIVIDUALS OF EACH OF SEVENTEEN SPECIES IN THE SAME TAXONOMIC SECTION AND CROSS PLANTS RAISED FROM THESE SEEDS WITH L. RAVENII. CROSSES WILL BE REPLICATED USING MULTIPLE INDIVIDUALS. EACH SPECIES WILL SERVE AS BOTH POLLEN DONOR AND SEED PARENT. BOTH SOURCE POPULATIONS AND REPRESENTATIVE INDIVIDUALS IN OUR CROSSES WILL BE DOCUMENTED WITH HERBARIUM VOUCHER SPECIMENS. CYTOLOGY WILL BE USED TO VALIDATE CHROMOSOME NUMBER. PLANTS RAISED FROM CROSSES WILL BE PHOTOGRAPHED USING MACRO-PHOTOGRAPHY. THE MORPHOLOGY OF EACH HYBRID WILL BE ANALYZED AND A REVISED TAXONOMIC KEY WILL BE DEVELOPED. TO FACILITATE BASELINE ANALYSES OF COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND HABITAT, WILL USE 1 M2 PLOTS TO QUANTITATIVELY SURVEY THE VEGETATION OF: (1) AT LEAST SIX OF THE EIGHT EXTANT POPULATIONS OF L. RAVENII (1 NC, 2 SC, 3 VA), (2) ALL SITES OF OTHER SPECIES OF LUDWIGIA FROM WHICH WE COLLECT SEEDS, AND (3) NEARBY HABITAT IN ALL AFOREMENTIONED LOCALITIES BUT IN WHICH TARGET SPECIES OF LUDWIGIA DO NOT OCCUR. SOIL SAMPLES WILL BE TAKEN AT EACH SAMPLE LOCALITY AND SUBMITTED TO THE NC DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND CONSUMER SERVICES AGRONOMIC DIVISION FOR COMPONENT ANALYSIS. DATA WILL BE ANALYZED USING STANDARD METHODS IN PLANT COMMUNITY ECOLOGY. UNDER THE MENTORSHIP OF THE PI, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO IMPROVE SKILLS IN TAXONOMY, RARE SPECIES SURVEY, VEGETATION SAMPLING, EX SITU SPECIES PROPAGATION, AND EXPERIMENTAL BIOLOGY. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES - RESULTS WILL BE PUBLISHED IN PEER-REVIEWED JOURNALS, INCORPORATED INTO A REVISION OF THE WEB APP WANTED ALIVE: RAVEN'S SEEDBOX, AND COMMUNICATED AT APPROPRIATE CONFERENCES.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) - NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, AGENCY BIOLOGISTS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONSULTANTS, SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, PUBLIC-AT-LARGE.

PROJECT TITLE:PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY FOR RANGE DISTURBANCE IMPACTS ON THE NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT AND INDIANA BAT AT FORT A.P. HILL PHASE EIGHT AND IMPOUNDMENT MONITORINGPROJECT PERIOD: 07/01/2022-6/30/2023THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND BAT MONITORING AND SURVEILLANCE EFFORTS AT FORT A.P. HILL, VIRGINIA WITH EMPHASIS ON THE ENDANGERED INDIANA BAT (MYOTIS SODALIS) AND THREATENED NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT (MYOTIS SEPTENTRIONALIS). AN ADDITIONAL COMPONENT OF ASSESSING THE HYDROLOGY OF INSTALLATION MILLPONDS AND WETLAND, IMPORTANT BAT FORAGING HABITAT AND ALSO HABITAT FOR THE ENDANGERED SWAMP PINK (HELONIAS BULLATA) IS INCLUDED. FORT A.P. HILL IS NOTABLE AS THE ONLY KNOWN LOCATION IN VIRGINIA WHERE A REPRODUCING MATERNITY COLONY OF THE INDIANA BAT OCCURS, AND IS ONE OF ONLY 2 KNOWN FOR THE MID-ATLANTIC EAST OF THE APPALACHIAN MOUNTAINS. LISTED AS ENDANGERED PRIOR TO THE ADVENT OF WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME, POPULATIONS OF INDIANA BATS HAVE DECREASE > 60% GENERALLY SINCE, AND > 90% IN THE MID-ATLANTIC. AS SUCH, FORT A.P. HILL IS NOW AN IMPORTANT CONSERVATION AREA FOR THE SPECIES. DATA COLLECTED FROM ACOUSTIC MONITORING AND RADIO-TAGGING CAUGHT BATS ARE IMPORTANT FOR DETERMINING FORAGING AND DAY-ROOSTING HABITAT REQUIREMENTS IN THESE MIXED PINE-HARDWOOD FORESTS THAT OCCUR ALONG THE FALL LINE. THESE DATA, IN TURN, CONTRIBUTE TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF MEANINGFUL REGION-SPECIFIC SPECIES DISTRIBUTION MODELS AND MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES THAT CAN INFORM MANAGEMENT THROUGHOUT. FOR EXAMPLE, AT FORT A.P. HILL, INDIANA BATS, APPEAR TO CHOOSE DECADENT LOBLOLLY PINE (PINUS TAEDA) STANDS WITH LOW FIRE-RETURN INTERVALS IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO MILLPOND AND WETLAND HABITATS. THESE CONDITIONS CAN BE REPLICATED AND MAINTAINED ON A SHIFTING MOSAIC PATTERN THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THE REGION THEREBY POTENTIALLY CONSERVING AND INCREASING EXTANT POPULATIONS - AN OUTCOME NECESSARY FOR SPECIES SURVIVAL. STILL, MANY FACETS OF THE SPECIES' BIOLOGY AND HABITAT USE REMAIN POORLY UNDERSTOOD IN THIS REGION AND WILL REQUIRE CONTINUED MONITORING AND DATA COLLECTION. ALTHOUGH THE THREATENED NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT HAS NOT YET BEEN OBSERVED EITHER ACOUSTICALLY OR VIA MIST-NET CAPTURE AT FORT A.P. HILL, OCCURRENCE OF THIS SPECIES IS KNOWN IMMEDIATELY TO THE NORTH AT MARINE CORPS BASE-QUANTICO AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE PRINCE WILLIAM FOREST PARK AND TO THE SOUTH AT FORT PICKETT AND BIG WOODS WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA. DUE TO PAST CONCENTRATION OF WORK ON INDIANA BATS, MUCH OF THE INSTALLATION WHERE SUITABLE NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT HABITAT OCCURS, I.E., CLOSED CANOPY, MATURE UPLAND HARDWOOD FORESTS, HAS NOT YET BEEN UNDERTAKEN. UNFORTUNATELY, PRESENCE OF THE INDIANA BAT ENTAILS CLOSE REGULATORY SCRUTINY FOR ACTIVITIES THAT MIGHT IMPACT THE SPECIES' NEEDED FOREST STRUCTURE CONDITION TO SUPPORT DAY-ROOSTS, I.E., FOREST HARVESTING, PRESCRIBED FIRE, AND IN THE CASE OF FORT A.P. HILL TRAINING ACTIVITIES. AS SUCH, RESEARCH AND MONITORING EFFORTS BY THE VIRGINIA UNIT ALSO ARE USED TO HELP BOTH INSTALLATION MANAGERS AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE CRAFT TEMPORALLY AND SPATIALLY APPROPRIATE STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES THAT ALLOW THE U.S. ARMY TO UTILIZE RANGES FOR TRAINING WHILE ALSO ADHERING TO THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. RESEARCHERS FROM THE VIRGINIA UNIT WILL CONTINUE TO CONDUCT BROAD LANDSCAPE-LEVEL ACOUSTIC SURVEYS TO DETERMINE INDIANA BAT AND NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT SEASONALITY OF PRESENCE AND HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS AND MIST-NET TO CAPTURE AND RADIO-TAG INDIVIDUALS TO TRACK BACK TO FOREST STANDS CONTAINING MATERNITY COLONIES. THE INTENDED DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK ARE THE U.S. ARMY, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE RESOURCE.

PROJECT TITLE:EFFECTS OF WATER MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ON WATER QUALITY, HABITAT, AND FISH ASSEMBLAGE IN THE BUFFALO COVE WATER MANAGEMENT UNIT IN THE ATCHAFALAYA RIVER BASINPROJECT PERIOD: 5/31/2022-12/31/2022AWARD PURPOSE:THIS AWARD WILL SUPPORT DATA SYNTHESIS AND SUMMARIZATION, DATA ANALYSIS, AND REPORT PREPARATION ACTIVITIES FOR THE BUFFALO COVE WATER MANAGEMENT PROJECT FUNDED BY THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS OVER THE LAST 17 YEARS. OUR MONITORING ACTIVITIES HAVE COLLECTED DATA ON WATER QUALITY, FLOW, HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS, AND FISH ASSEMBLAGE COMPOSITION BEFORE, DURING, AND AFTER INITIATION AND COMPLETION OF THIS PROJECT, WHICH WAS DESIGNED TO IMPROVE WATER CIRCULATION AND WATER QUALITY IN THE BUFFALO COVE WATER MANAGEMENT UNIT DURING AND AFTER THE ANNUAL FLOOD PULSE. ANALYSES OF PROJECT IMPACT ARE COMPLICATED BY ANNUAL VARIATION IN THE MAGNITUDE AND DURATION OF THE FLOOD PULSE, AS WELL AS ANNUAL VARIATION IN TEMPERATURES, WHICH INTERACT WITH FLOODPLAIN INUNDATION AND CAUSE WIDESPREAD HYPOXIA ABOVE 20 C. WE HAVE DEVELOPED SEVERAL APPROACHES TO ANALYZING AND MODELING THESE DATASETS TO EXPLORE FLOODPLAIN FUNCTION, AS WELL AS POTENTIAL EFFECTS ON WATER QUALITY RELATED TO WATER MANAGEMENT PROJECTS CONSTRUCTED DURING THE PROJECT.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:ACTIVITIES PERFORMED UNDER THIS AWARD WILL BE DATA VERIFICATION, DATABASE CONSTRUCTION, DATA ANALYSES, AND REPORT PREPARATION, INCLUDING SYNTHESIS OF TABLES AND FIGURES FOR DATA PRESENTATION, AND SUPPLEMENTARY APPENDIX DATA TABLES. THOUSANDS OF LINES OF DATA NEED TO BE CHECKED AND VERIFIED WITH FIELD NOTES, AND SEVERAL SEQUENTIAL DATA ANALYSES WILL BE CONDUCTED ON THE VARIOUS PHYSICOCHEMICAL AND BIOTIC DATA SETS TO EXAMINE TRENDS THROUGH TIME, AS WELL AS THE EFFECTS OF VARIOUS ENVIRONMENTAL VARIABLES (E.G., RIVER STAGE, TEMPERATURE, FLOW) ON ABIOTIC AND BIOTIC RESPONSE VARIABLES. THE REPORT WILL EXAMINE EACH OF THE DATASETS AS THEY FLUCTUATE THROUGH TIME, PARTICULARLY AS THEY RELATE TO ALTERATION OF FLOW INPUTS AND FLOW ROUTING IN THE BUFFALO COVE WATER MANAGEMENT UNIT FROM ELEMENTS CONSTRUCTED DURING THE PROJECT. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE DELIVERABLE FROM THE AWARD WILL BE A FINAL REPORT TO THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS ON THE FUNCTION OF THE BUFFALO COVE WATER MANAGEMENT UNIT, THE INFLUENCE OF THE ANNUAL FLOOD PULSE ON PHYSICOCHEMICAL AND BIOTIC CHARACTERISTICS OF THE UNIT, AND THE EFFECTS OF CONSTRUCTED WATER MANAGEMENT ELEMENTS ON THE ABIOTIC AND BIOTIC STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION WITHIN THE UNIT. ALL DATA HAS BEEN FORWARDED TO THE CORPS DURING THE COURSE OF THE PROJECT, BUT WILL ALSO BE INCLUDED IN SUPPLEMENTARY TABLES IN THE FINAL REPORT. THE REPORT WILL ALSO INCLUDE AN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY HIGHLIGHTING RESULTS OF THE ANALYSES AND MODELING ACTIVITIES AS THEY RELATE TO THE GOALS OF THE BUFFALO COVE PROJECT.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): THE PROXIMATE BENEFICIARY OF THIS AWARD WILL BE THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS, AS THEY ARE MOST INTERESTED IN THE EFFECTS OF THE WATER MANAGEMENT PROJECT ON THE ECOLOGY OF BUFFALO COVE. ULTIMATELY, HOWEVER, IT IS HOPED THE ATCHAFALAYA BASIN ECOSYSTEM, ITS RESOURCES, AND THE PEOPLE WHO USE THE BASIN FOR COMMERCIAL AND RECREATIONAL PURPOSES, WILL BENEFIT FROM IMPROVED ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS AND BASIN PRODUCTIVITY.

PROJECT TITLE: IN SITU EVALUATION OF CONTAMINANT STRESSORS TO ENDANGERED AND AT-RISK FRESHWATER MUSSEL HEALTH IN THE CONASAUGA RIVER BASIN, GAPROJECT PERIOD: 06/06/2022-12/31/2024THE CONASAUGA RIVER IS A BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOT FOR FISHES AND FRESHWATER MUSSELS. SOME OF THESE SPECIES ARE RARE, AT-RISK, OR LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. ADDITIONALLY, TWO SPECIES OF MUSSELS HAVE BEEN CHARACTERIZED AS EXTINCT FROM THE BASIN. WE PROPOSE A COLLABORATIVE MULTIYEAR RESEARCH STUDY TO EVALUATE THE THREAT OF CONTAMINANTS ON FRESHWATER MUSSELS IN THE CONASAUGA RIVER. WE INTEND TO COLLECT INFORMATION THAT WILL HELP THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE'S GEORGIA ECOLOGICAL SERVICES FIELD OFFICE PRIORITIZE CONSERVATION OR MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO SUPPORT FRESHWATER MUSSELS. FURTHER, DATA COLLECTED ON THE EFFECTS OF CONTAMINANTS ON MUSSEL GROWTH AND SURVIVAL COULD BE USED IN POPULATION MODELS TO FURTHER EVALUATE POPULATION-LEVEL EFFECTS IN CONTAMINATED VS NON-CONTAMINATED SITES.- ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - WE HAVE TWO PRIMARY OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT.EXPERIMENTAL OBJECTIVE 1: EVALUATE DISTRIBUTION AND EFFECTS OF CONTAMINATED SEDIMENTS IN THE UPPER CONASAUGA RIVER TO THE PERSISTENCE OF FEDERALLY LISTED AND AT-RISK FRESHWATER MUSSEL SPECIES.SEDIMENTS WILL BE COLLECTED FROM MAINSTEM OR TRIBUTARY SITES OF VARYING AGRICULTURAL, INDUSTRIAL, AND MUNICIPAL INFLUENCE. JUVENILE FRESHWATER MUSSELS WILL BE CULTURED OR OBTAINED FROM ANOTHER FACILITY AND EXPOSED TO EXPERIMENTAL SEDIMENTS FOR 30 DAYS WITH AN AUTOMATED WATER RENEWAL AND FEEDING SYSTEM.EXPERIMENTAL OBJECTIVE 2: EVALUATE IN SITU WATER EXPOSURES IN THE WATERSHED TO PERSISTENCE OF FEDERALLY LISTED AND AT-RISK FRESHWATER MUSSEL SPECIES.JUVENILE MUSSELS OF A NON-LISTED SURROGATE SPECIES NATIVE TO THE BASIN WILL BE DEPLOYED IN CONCRETE CAGES (I.E., SILOS. WE WILL TARGET 20-50 MUSSELS PER SILO (DEPENDING ON MUSSEL SIZE AND AVAILABILITY), AND 3-5 REPLICATE SILOS AT SITES SELECTED BY THE PARTNER TEAM. DEPLOYMENT WILL OCCUR DURING LOW FLOW AND LAST APPROXIMATELY 60-90 DAYS TO ASSESS JUVENILE MUSSEL GROWTH AND SURVIVAL. WE PLAN TO TAKE MEASUREMENTS OF DEPLOYED MUSSELS AT 2-WEEK INTERVALS THROUGHOUT THE EXPERIMENT, AS WELL AS COLLECT WATER SAMPLES FOR CHEMICAL ANALYSIS.- DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES BOTH LOCAL AND REGIONAL CONSERVATION ISSUES. ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE:ANNUAL PROJECT UPDATES, INCLUDING COORDINATION MEETINGS WITH US FWS AND GA DNR A MS THESIS A DATASET OF SEDIMENT AND WATER COLLECTION LOCATIONS PREPARATION OF 1-2 ARTICLES TO BE SUBMITTED TO JOURNALS - INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE; GA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES; FRESHWATER MUSSEL RESEARCH COMMUNITY

PROJECT TITLE:MOVEMENT AND DISTRIBUTION OF LAKE STURGEON IN THE COOSA RIVERPROJECT PERIOD: 3/1/2022-9/30/2024EFFORTS TO RESTORE LAKE STURGEON TO NORTHWEST GEORGIA BEGAN NEARLY 20 YEARS AGO. THESE LARGE PREHISTORIC FISH WERE HISTORICALLY PRESENT IN THE COOSA RIVER BASIN BUT WERE THOUGHT TO BE EXTIRPATED BY THE LATE 1970S DUE TO OVERFISHING AND DEGRADED WATER QUALITY. FOLLOWING IMPROVEMENTS IN WATER QUALITY VIA THE CLEAN WATER ACT OF 1972, THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES COMMENCED A LAKE STURGEON REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM THAT INCLUDED ANNUAL STOCKING OF FISH WITH THE GOAL OF PRODUCING A SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATION. THE INITIAL COHORTS HAVE THEORETICALLY REACHED SEXUAL MATURITY.THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO DETERMINE SEASONAL HABITAT USE AND MOVEMENT OF LAKE STURGEON IN THE COOSA RIVER BASIN. NEW INFORMATION ABOUT REPRODUCTIVE STATUS AND BEHAVIORS, MOVEMENT, AND HABITAT USE WILL AID IN RECOVERY EFFORTS AND INFORM MANAGERS ON THE STATUS OF THE POPULATION.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - THIS PROJECT WILL USE RADIO TELEMETRY TO TRACK LAKE STURGEON MOVEMENTS. WE ANTICIPATE TARGETING 40 LAKE STURGEON FOR TAGGING. WILL MEASURE IMPORTANT HABITAT FEATURES SUCH AS WATER TEMPERATURE. WILL ALSO ATTEMPT TO ASSESS SEX AND REPRODUCTIVE STATUS (SEXUAL MATURITY) OF LARGE (? 800 MM) LAKE STURGEON CAPTURED DURING SPRING COLLECTIONS FOR TELEMETRY TAG IMPLANTATION.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES - THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES BOTH LOCAL AND REGIONAL CONSERVATION ISSUES. ENDEMIC POPULATIONS OF LAKE STURGEON IN THE SOUTHEAST ARE PARTICULARLY AT RISK BECAUSE OF POTENTIAL THREATS FROM GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE AND CONTINUED ANTHROPOGENIC MODIFICATIONS TO RIVER FLOW AND FUNCTION. THIS SPECIFIC RESEARCH WILL ADDRESS CONSERVATION CONCERNS AT THE LOCAL LEVEL IN GEORGIA BUT PROVIDE IMPORTANT IMPLICATIONS FOR LAKE STURGEON MANAGEMENT ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST. ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE:ANNUAL PROJECT UPDATES, INCLUDING REVIEW OF FIELD SEASONS A MS THESIS A DATASET OF LAKE STURGEON LOCATIONS PREPARATION OF 1-2 ARTICLES TO BE SUBMITTED TO JOURNALSINTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) - U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE; GA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES; LAKE STURGEON RESEARCH COMMUNITY

PROJECT TITLE:BURROWING OWL POPULATION MONITORING AND MITIGATION ON NAS LEMOOREPROJECT PERIOD: 5/18/2022-9/30/2023BURROWING OWLS (ATHENE CUNICULARIA) WERE ONCE A COMMON BREEDER IN GRASSLANDS AND DESERTS THROUGHOUT THE WESTERN U.S. AND CANADA. BURROWING OWL POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED, AND THE SPECIES HAS BEEN EXTIRPATED FROM AREAS ON THE WESTERN, NORTHERN, AND EASTERN PERIPHERY OF THEIR BREEDING RANGE. BURROWING OWLS ARE NOW FEDERALLY ENDANGERED IN CANADA, AND ARE LISTED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AS A SPECIES OF NATIONAL CONSERVATION CONCERN IN THE UNITED STATES. BURROWING OWLS ARE ALSO LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN MINNESOTA AND IOWA, AND ARE BEING CONSIDERED OR HAVE BEEN PETITIONED FOR STATE LISTING IN CALIFORNIA AND WASHINGTON. POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED IN OTHER STATES INCLUDING ARIZONA, COLORADO, KANSAS, NEBRASKA, NEVADA, NEW MEXICO, AND UTAH. HENCE, BURROWING OWLS ARE LISTED AS A HIGH PRIORITY SPECIES IN STATE PARTNERS-IN-FLIGHT CONSERVATION PLANS. BURROWING OWLS OCCUPY AREAS DOMINATED BY GRASSLAND, SHRUB-STEPPE, DESERT, AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION. THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE (DOD) HAS MANAGEMENT RESPONSIBILITY FOR A SUBSTANTIAL PROPORTION OF REMAINING BURROWING OWL POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITAT, AND BURROWING OWLS ARE COMMONLY ASSOCIATED WITH DOD AIRFIELDS. FURTHERMORE, WILDLIFE POPULATIONS ON DOD INSTALLATIONS ARE FACING INCREASING PRESSURES BECAUSE LANDS ADJACENT TO MANY DOD INSTALLATIONS HAVE ACCELERATING LAND USE CHANGE (E.G., URBANIZATION AND CONVERSION OF NATIVE GRASSLANDS TO AGRICULTURE). THE DOD PARTNERS IN FLIGHT (PIF) PROGRAM SEEKS TO ENSURE THE ONGOING SUCCESS OF THE MILITARY MISSION BY MAINTAINING THE BIOTIC INTEGRITY AND SUSTAINABILITY OF DOD TESTING AND TRAINING LANDS THROUGH LAND STEWARDSHIP, POPULATION MONITORING, RESEARCH, COMMUNICATION, EDUCATION, AND COOPERATION WITH OTHER AGENCIES AND STAKE-HOLDERS. THE DOD PIF HAVE IDENTIFIED THE BURROWING OWL AS A MISSION SENSITIVE PRIORITY SPECIES (DOD NATURAL RESOURCE PROGRAM 2014). IMPROVED MONITORING, RESEARCH, AND PRO-ACTIVE MANAGEMENT OF BURROWING OWLS ON DOD LANDS IS VITAL TO SUPPORTING THE MILITARY MISSION WHILE ALSO ENSURING PERSISTENCE OF BURROWING OWL POPULATIONS. THESE ACTIONS WILL HELP IDENTIFY THE MANAGEMENT ROLE OF DOD FOR CONSERVING BURROWING OWLS NESTING IN THE REGION, POTENTIALLY HELP PREVENT FURTHER LISTING EFFORTS, AND PROVIDE INFORMATION ON RISK AND FREQUENCY OF BIRD STRIKE HAZARDS. AS A DECLINING SPECIES ON NAS LEMOORE, EXAMINING THE STATUS, DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, BREEDING SUCCESS, RECRUITMENT, AND HEALTH OF BURROWING OWLS WILL FACILITATE SUCCESSFUL MITIGATION AND RELOCATION EFFORTS THAT MAY BE NEEDED TO BALANCE NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT WITH MILITARY READINESS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - WILL USE ESTABLISHED SURVEY PROTOCOLS TO SURVEY FOR THE PRESENCE OF BURROWING OWLS IN SUITABLE HABITAT THROUGHOUT THE INSTALLATION. WHEN >1 OWL IS OBSERVED FROM A SINGLE SURVEY POINT, THE SURVEYOR WILL USE BEHAVIORAL AND MORPHOLOGICAL (I.E., PLUMAGE-BASED) CUES TO ESTIMATE THE NUMBER OF DISTINCT NEST SITES PRESENT. WE WILL OPPORTUNISTICALLY SEARCH FOR OWLS THROUGHOUT SUITABLE HABITAT ON THE BASE AS WE TRAVEL TO AND FROM FORMALIZED SURVEY ROUTES AND ANY OTHER TIME WE ARE TRAVELING THROUGH THE INSTALLATION. WE WILL ALSO FOLLOW UP ON ALL REPORTED BURROWING OWL SIGHTINGS REPORTED BY DOD STAFF, CONTRACTORS, OTHER PERSONNEL, AND BY THE PUBLIC. COMBINING FORMALIZED REPEATABLE SURVEY PROTOCOLS WITH INFORMAL METHODS TO DETECT OWLS WILL PROVIDE THE FOUNDATION OF A LONG-TERM MONITORING EFFORT THAT CAN BE REPLICATED IN FUTURE YEARS TO RIGOROUSLY ESTIMATE TRENDS IN OWL NEST DENSITY WHILE MAXIMIZING DETECTIONS OF OWL NESTS. WILL WORK, IN COORDINATION WITH THE NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAM MANAGER, TO INSTALL APPROPRIATE SIGNAGE OR PHYSICAL BARRIERS, WHEN APPROPRIATE, TO LIMIT HUMAN DISTURBANCE TO NESTING BURROWING OWLS.

PROJECT TITLE: EVALUATING RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLEBEE CONSERVATION EFFORTS TO INFORM SITE-SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT ACTIONSPROJECT PERIOD: 05/10/2022-12/31/2024THE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINUS) IS AN ENDANGERED SPECIES THAT WAS ONCE WIDELY DISTRIBUTED ACROSS MUCH OF THE MIDWEST. THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IS INTERESTED IN LEARNING MORE ABOUT THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION AND HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS OF EXISTING POPULATIONS IN IOWA TO INFORM RECOVERY PLANNING AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT CONDUCTED VIA THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE THE LOCAL AND LANDSCAPE HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS THAT AS ASSOCIATED WITH BEE OCCUPANCY AND INDIVIDUAL HEALTH INDICATORS. TO ACHIEVE THIS OBJECTIVE, WILL CONDUCT TWO TYPES OF SURVEYS IN THE SUMMERS OF 2022 AND 2023. RAPID, NONINVASIVE SURVEYS WILL BE USED IN AN OCCUPANCY ANALYSIS TO ESTIMATE THE HABITAT FEATURES THAT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH BEE PRESENCE. INTENSIVE SURVEYS IN WHICH BEES ARE CAPTURED AND RELEASED WILL ALSO BE CONDUCTED AT A SUBSET OF SITES TO MEASURE A SUITE OF INDIVIDUAL HEALTH INDICATORS. THIS WORK WILL INFORM HABITAT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR THE PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM AS WELL AS TARGETS FOR B. AFFINIS RECOVERY PLANNING.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE CONDUCTING SYSTEMATIC, TIMED SURVEYS WITH SWEEP NETS TO IDENTIFY THE PRESENCE OF RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEES AND AMERICAN BUMBLE BEES (BOMBUS PENSYLVANICUS) AS WELL AS INTENSIVE SURVEYS IN WHICH INDIVIDUALS WILL BE CAPTURED AND RELEASED AFTER MEASUREMENT AND NONDESTRUCTIVE TISSUE SAMPLING.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES - TWO M.S. THESES AND AT LEAST ON PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATION, AS WELL AS ANNUAL STATUS REPORTS TO THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) - U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES.

PROJECT TITLE:WINTERING WATERFOWL FORAGING HABITAT IN SOUTH ATLANTIC COASTAL INLAND WETLANDS AND IMPLICATIONS FOR WETLANDS CONVERSATION AMID SEA LEVEL RISEPROJECT PERIOD: 05/18/2022-12/31/2024ABSTRACT: SOUTH ATLANTIC REGIONAL STATES OF NORTH CAROLINA, SOUTH CAROLINA, GEORGIA, AND FLORIDA CONTAIN VAST COASTAL WETLANDS, WHICH INCLUDE MANAGED AND NON-MANAGED TIDAL-FRESH, BRACKISH, AND SALT MARSHES THAT ARE USED EXTENSIVELY BY MIGRATING AND WINTERING WATERFOWL AND OTHER WATERBIRDS. HYDROLOGICALLY MANAGED TIDAL IMPOUNDMENTS IN THIS REGION ARE AMONG THE MOST IMPORTANT AQUATIC RESOURCES FOR MIGRATING AND WINTERING WATERFOWL IN THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY. HOWEVER, RECENT STUDIES HAVE EXPOSED INFORMATION VOIDS REGARDING MTIS AND OTHER WETLAND TYPES IN THE SOUTH ATLANTIC, SUCH AS ESTIMATES OF FORAGE AVAILABILITY FOR WATERFOWL. THE PURPOSE OF OUR STUDY IS TO OBTAIN WATERFOWL FOOD ABUNDANCE ESTIMATES AND EVALUATE ASSUMPTIONS FOR BIOENERGETICS MODELING IN THE SOUTH ATLANTIC REGION USED IN CONSERVATION PLANNING BY THE ATLANTIC COAST JOINT VENTURE AND ITS PARTNERS TO MEET POPULATION-BASED HABITAT OBJECTIVES SET BY THE NORTH AMERICAN WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT PLAN. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL AID WATERFOWL CONSERVATION PLANNING AMID SEA LEVEL RISE ACROSS THE SOUTH ATLANTIC STATES (PRIMARILY NORTH CAROLINA, SOUTH CAROLINA, AND GEORGIA) AND PROVIDE A CONTEMPORARY UNDERSTANDING OF THE FOOD HABITS OF MOTTLED DUCKS AND OTHER WATERFOWL SPECIES USING PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS IN THE REGION.THE THREE OBJECTIVES OF OUR STUDY ARE TO 1) ESTIMATE FREQUENCY OF OCCURRENCE AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF FOOD ITEMS IN THE DIET IF DUCKS COLLECTED FROM WETLANDS COMMONLY USED BY WATERFOWL, 2) ESTIMATE ENERGY DENSITY OF WATERFOWL FORAGE IN COASTAL AND INLAND WETLANDS, AND 3) IMPROVE THE WETLANDS INVENTORY USED IN THE BIOENERGETICS MODEL CREATED BY THE ACJV AND PARTNERS BY LOCATING AND DIGITIZING PRIVATE IMPOUNDMENTS MANAGED FOR WATERFOWL IN THE SOUTH ATLANTIC REGION. FOR INVESTIGATING WATERFOWL DIETS, WE WILL COLLECT FECES FROM HUNTER-HARVESTED DUCKS, THEN EXTRACT AND SEQUENCE DNA FROM THE FECES TO IDENTIFY PREY ITEMS CONSUMED. WILL ALSO LETHALLY COLLECT A SUBSET OF ACTIVELY FORAGING DUCKS TO EVALUATE DIFFERENCES IN DNA METHODOLOGIES AND TRADITIONAL DISSECTION TECHNIQUES. THE DIET DATA WILL ALSO IMPROVE ENERGETIC DENSITY ESTIMATES BY INFORMING US OF WHAT POTENTIAL FORAGE ITEMS ARE SELDOM CONSUMED BY WATERFOWL IN THE REGION AND THUS, CAN BE EXCLUDED FROM ESTIMATES. TO ESTIMATE ENERGETIC DENSITY OF FOCAL WETLANDS, WILL USE A VARIETY OF SAMPLING METHODS TO ESTIMATE BIOMASS OF FORAGE PRODUCED AND CONVERT BIOMASS TO ENERGETIC DENSITY (KCAL/HECTARE) USING PUBLISH TRUE METABOLIZABLE ENERGY VALUES. THE FOCAL WETLANDS IN WHICH PLAN TO SAMPLE INCLUDE THOSE MANAGED FOR SUBMERSED AQUATIC VEGETATION, MOIST-SOIL PLANT SPECIES, AND AGRICULTURAL CROPS, ALONG WITH UNMANAGED NATURAL MARSH. TO LOCATE AND DIGITIZE IMPOUNDMENTS, WILL USE REMOTELY SENSED DATA (E.G., LANDSAT AND LIDAR) AND MANUALLY DIGITIZE IMPOUNDMENTS IN ARCGIS. FROM DATA, WILL PROVIDE A SHAPEFILE OF ALL DIGITIZED MANAGED WATERFOWL IMPOUNDMENTS, WHICH WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATED ENERGETIC CARRYING CAPACITY ACROSS THE REGION. WILL ALSO PROVIDE ANALYSES OF WATERFOWL DIETS AND FORAGE PRODUCTION IN FOCAL WETLAND TYPES AND PUBLICATIONS INCORPORATING ELEMENTS FROM ALL THREE OBJECTIVES. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE BENEFICIAL TO THE ATLANTIC COAST JOINT VENTURE, THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, MULTIPLE SOUTHEASTERN STATE AGENCIES, AND ALL OTHER PARTNERS INTERESTED IN WATERFOWL AND WETLANDS CONSERVATION IN THE SOUTH ATLANTIC. OVERALL, HOPE THAT THIS INFORMATION WILL LEAD TO AN IMPROVEMENT IN THE ACCURACY OF HABITAT CARRYING CAPACITY MODELS IN THE SOUTH ATLANTIC, GUIDE CONSERVATION PLANNING IN THE REGION, AND PROVIDE POTENTIAL MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR HABITAT MANAGERS.

PROJECT TITLE:EFFECTIVENESS OF FOREST RESTORATION TREATMENTS FOR RECOVERY OF NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL POPULATIONSPROJECT PERIOD: 5/11/2022-5/1/2023FIRE SUPPRESSION HAS CAUSED A BUILD-UP OF FUELS IN CONIFEROUS FORESTS IN THE WESTERN U.S. FUELS TREATMENTS ARE BEING IMPLEMENTED IN MANY AREAS BY USFS AND OTHER LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES TO REDUCE THE RISK OF LARGE, STAND-REPLACEMENT FIRES. IMPLEMENTING THESE FUELS TREATMENTS IS PARTICULARLY CHALLENGING IN FORESTS THAT HARBOR SPECIES LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES MUST ENSURE THAT TREATMENT PRESCRIPTIONS WILL NOT ADVERSELY AFFECT THE LISTED SPECIES, AND THE NECESSARY DATA ON THE EFFECTS OF ALTERNATIVE FUELS TREATMENTS ON FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES ARE OFTEN NOT AVAILABLE. THIS LACK OF INFORMATION CAN STYMIE FUEL REDUCTION EFFORTS. SOME FUELS TREATMENTS LIKELY BENEFIT SOME FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES BUT DATA ARE OFTEN NOT AVAILABLE TO DEMONSTRATE THE COMPATIBILITY OF FUELS TREATMENTS AND SPECIES RECOVERY EFFORTS. SUCH IS THE CASE WITH THE NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL (UROCITELLUS BRUNNEUS). FIRE SUPPRESSION AND THE RESULTING CHANGES IN HABITAT ARE THOUGHT TO BE THE MOST LIKELY CAUSE OF PAST POPULATION DECLINES AND ESA LISTING, BUT MANAGEMENT AGENCIES NEED RESEARCH TO SUPPORT THE HYPOTHESIS THAT PRESCRIBED FIRE CAN SIMULTANEOUSLY REDUCE FUELS AND BENEFIT RECOVERY OF NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRRELS. WE HAVE IMPLEMENTED A FIELD EXPERIMENT TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF DIFFERENT FOREST RESTORATION ACTIONS REGARDING THEIR ABILITY TO RESTORE NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL HABITAT AND INCREASE POPULATION SIZE OF THE THREATENED GROUND SQUIRREL. THE PROJECT ADDRESSES A PRIMARY RESEARCH NEED IDENTIFIED IN THE GROUND SQUIRREL'S RECOVERY PLAN AND WILL HELP DETERMINE WHETHER SPECIFIC FOREST RESTORATION TREATMENTS CAN BE IMPLEMENTED TO PROVIDE ESSENTIAL HABITAT FOR THIS RARE SPECIES. NUMEROUS AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS HAVE WORKED TOGETHER FOR THE PAST 9 YEARS TO MEASURE DEMOGRAPHIC TRAITS OF NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRRELS ON PLOTS PRIOR TO AND FOLLOWING RESTORATION TREATMENTS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - WILL CAPTURE AND ATTACH TRANSMITTERS AND GEOLOCATORS TO GROUND SQUIRRELS IN ONGOING EXPERIMENTAL PLOTS TO EVALUATE HOW HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS AFFECT DEMOGRAPHIC TRAITS OF A FEDERALLY THREATENED GROUND SQUIRREL. WE WILL USE DATA FROM THE TRANSMITTERS TO LOCATE HIBERNACULA. WE WILL USE CAPTURE AND RECAPTURE DATA TO ESTIMATE SURVIVAL, DENSITY, AND COLONY AREA. WE WILL CHEEK SWAB AND FECAL SAMPLES FROM EACH ANIMAL TO DOCUMENT DIET AND ADAPTIVE GENETIC VARIATION AMONG POPULATIONS.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES - ANNUAL REPORTS, A FINAL REPORT, A MS THESIS, AND SEVERAL PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONSINTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) - USFWS, USFS, IDAHO DEPT OF FISH AND GAME.

PROJECT TITLE:BAT ACOUSTIC SURVEYS AND WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME MONITORING ON THE NAVAJO NATIONPROJECT PERIOD: 5/11/2022-7/1/2024THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND BAT MONITORING AND SURVEILLANCE EFFORTS ON THE NAVAJO NATION IN ARIZONA. THE SOUTHWESTERN PORTION OF THE UNITED STATES CONTAINS SOME OF THE HIGHEST BAT SPECIES DIVERSITY IN THE NATION, YET MOST ASPECTS OF BAT COMMUNITY COMPOSITION, BAT DISTRIBUTION AND BAT HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS ARE UNKNOWN. ACQUISITION OF THESE DATA ARE CRITICAL BEFORE WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME BECOMES ENDEMIC TO THE AREA WHEREBY MANAGERS CAN ASSESS POPULATION AND DISTRIBUTION CHANGES (IF THEY OCCUR) AND PROACTIVELY ENGAGE IN HABITAT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS THAT BENEFIT BATS. TO ACHIEVE THIS, RESEARCHERS FROM THE VIRGINIA UNIT WILL CONDUCT BROAD LANDSCAPE-LEVEL ACOUSTIC SURVEYS YEAR-ROUND TO DETERMINE BY INDIVIDUAL BAT SPECIES, SEASONALITY AND HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS, AS WELL AS PROVIDE A BASELINE PER SPECIES OF PRE-DISEASE "NORMAL" ACTIVITY. SECONDLY, HARP-TRAP AND MIST-NETTING SURVEYS WILL BE USED IN THE SPRING EMERGENCE SEASON AROUND CAVES AND MINES TO CAPTURE BATS AND TEST THEM FOR THE PRESENCE OF PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS FUNGUS THAT CAUSES WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME. BOTH ACOUSTIC AND CAVE-NETTING DATA WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED TO NABAT SO THAT NATIONWIDE-DISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION LEVEL MONITORING CAN INCORPORATE THIS REGION. IT IS EXPECTED THAT BAT DISTRIBUTION AND HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS WITH DIFFER BY SPECIES, SEASONS AND HABITAT CONFIGURATIONS, I.E., PROXIMITY TO RIPARIAN HABITATS, FORESTS, DESERT AND ALPINE COMMUNITIES. SPATIALLY EXPLICIT DATA LAYERS OF OCCUPIED AND PREDICTED HABITAT SUITABILITY BY INDIVIDUAL BAT SPECIES WILL BE GENERATED THAT WILL HAVE UTILITY FOR NATURAL RESOURCE PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE NAVAJO NATION, THE BUREAU OF INDIAN AFFAIRS, THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE AND ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT. NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ARE ANTICIPATED. SEASONAL TECHNICIANS FROM THE NAVAJO NATION WILL BE TERM VIRGINIA TECH EMPLOYEES.

PROJECT TITLE:SELENIUM CONCENTRATIONS IN YUMA RIDGWAY'S RAILS AND THEIR PREYPROJECT PERIOD: 04/15/2022 - 12/31/2024YUMA RIDGWAY'S RAILS (RALLUS OBSOLETUS YUMANENSIS) ARE LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN THE U.S. AND THEY RELY ON EMERGENT MARSHES THROUGHOUT THE LOWER COLORADO RIVER BASIN AND AROUND THE SALTON SEA IN CALIFORNIA. RECENT MARSH RESTORATION EFFORTS BY HAVE CREATED ADDITIONAL HABITAT OVER THE PAST DECADE, BUT UNMANAGED MARSHES HAVE APPEARED AT AGRICULTURAL DRAINAGE OUTLETS AROUND THE SALTON SEA AND ARE BECOMING MORE COMMON AS SEA LEVELS RECEDE. THESE NEW UNMANAGED MARSHES RECEIVE AGRICULTURAL DRAINAGE WATER WITH VARYING CONCENTRATIONS OF SELENIUM. UNNATURALLY HIGH ACCUMULATION OF SELENIUM IN PREY AND SUBSTRATES AFFECTS REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS (E.G., EMBRYO DEVELOPMENT) OF BIRDS, BUT WE KNOW RELATIVELY LITTLE ABOUT THE THREAT OF SELENIUM ACCUMULATION TO YUMA RIDGWAY'S RAILS AT SALTON SEA. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP EVALUATE THE HABITAT SUITABILITY OF UNMANAGED MARSHES FOR YUMA RIDGWAY'S RAILS AND ASSESS THE SELENIUM RISK THAT THESE UNMANAGED MARSHES MAY POSE TO YUMA RIDGWAY'S RAILS. SUCH INFORMATION WILL HELP GUIDE CONSERVATION EFFORTS BOTH LOCALLY AND THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE RANGE OF THIS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED RAIL.                                             ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -WILL CAPTURE AND ATTACH SATELLITE GPS TRANSMITTERS TO RAILS, INCLUDING MARSHES REPRESENTING DIFFERENT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND CONDITIONS SO THAT CAN EVALUATE HOW HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES INFLUENCE RAIL DEMOGRAPHICS AND SELENIUM CONCENTRATIONS. WILL USE GPS DATA FROM THE TRANSMITTERS TO LOCATE NEST SITES, INFER NESTING BEHAVIOR, AND DETERMINE WHEN NESTING IS COMPLETE. WILL APPROACH NESTS AFTER THE NESTING PERIOD TO COLLECT EGGSHELLS AND ANY UNHATCHED EGGS TO ELUCIDATE THE REPRODUCTIVE RISKS OF SELENIUM IN THE MANAGED AND UNMANAGED MARSHES. WILL COLLECT BLOOD, FEATHER, AND FECAL SAMPLES FROM EACH CAPTURED YUMA RIDGWAY'S RAIL TO DOCUMENT SELENIUM BURDENS IN BREEDING YUMA RIDGWAY'S RAILS AROUND THE SALTON SEA. FINALLY, WE WILL COLLECT SAMPLES OF CRAYFISH (PROCAMBARUS CLARKIA), MOSQUITOFISH (GAMBUSIA AFFINIS), AND OTHER PREY SPECIES FOR SELENIUM ANALYSES TO EVALUATE DIFFERENCES IN SELENIUM CONCENTRATIONS IN RAIL PREY ITEMS BETWEEN MANAGED AND UNMANAGED MARSHES AROUND THE SALTON SEA. WILL ALSO CONDUCT STOMACH FLUSHING OF CAPTURED RAILS TO DOCUMENT DIET COMPOSITION AND SAMPLE ANY OTHER PREY ITEMS THAT WE DETECT IN THOSE STOMACH SAMPLES.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -ANNUAL REPORTS, A FINAL REPORT, A MS THESIS, AND SEVERAL PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -USFWS, BOR, CALIFORNIA DEPT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, LOCAL IRRIGATION DISTRICTS.

PROJECT TITLE:USING A BAYESIAN BELIEF NETWORK TO STRUCTURE SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS OF DATA-DEFICIENT SPECIES: A CASE STUDY WITH PIEBALD MADTOM (NOTURUS GLADIATOR)PROJECT PERIOD: 04/11/2022 - 08/31/2026THIS AWARD IS FOR SALARY AND OTHER EXPENSES TO SUPPORT A POST-MASTER'S RESEARCH ASSOCIATE AT MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY, WHO WILL PROVIDE ANALYTICAL SUPPORT FOR THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. THE RESEARCH ASSOCIATE WILL CONDUCT ANALYSES AND ORGANIZE ELICITATION SESSIONS WITH SPECIES EXPERTS TO QUANTIFY THE RISK OF IMPERILMENT OF A SPECIES (PIEBALD MADTOM) PETITIONED FOR REVIEW UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME IS A SCIENTIFICALLY DEFENSIBLE ASSESSMENT OF SPECIES IMPERILMENT RISK. SPECIFIC DELIVERABLES ARE REPRODUCIBLE ANALYSES IN THE FORM OF A BAYESIAN BELIEF NETWORK MODEL, DOCUMENTED MATERIALS FOR PERFORMING ELICITATIONS WITH SPECIES EXPERTS, MAP PRODUCTS, ORGANIZED DATA, AND A FINAL REPORT. THE SPECIFIC BENEFICIARY IS THE MISSISSIPPI FIELD OFFICE OF THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, WHICH IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT OF PIEBALD MADTOM. THERE IS NO SUBRECIPIENT ASSOCIATED WITH THIS AWARD.

PROJECT TITLE:A RAPID MAPPING TOOL FOR QUANTIFYING GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT OUTCOMESPROJECT PERIOD: 6/1/2022 - 8/30/2024OF ALL NORTH AMERICAN ECOSYSTEM, GRASSLANDS HAVE LOST THE MOST SPECIES DIVERSITY, PREDOMINATELY DUE TO HABITAT LOSS AND DEGRADATION. THUS, DOCUMENTATION OF SUCCESSFUL RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT IS IMPERATIVE FOR BUILDING LARGE-SCALE RESTORATION PROGRAMS. HOWEVER, QUANTIFYING OUTCOMES FROM GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS IS MADE DIFFICULT BY THE LACK OF TOOLS TO RAPIDLY MAP AND TRACK CORE GRASSLAND HABITATS AND GRASSLAND BIODIVERSITY RESPONSES TO MANAGEMENT. HERE, OUR OVERALL GOAL IS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A RAPID MAPPING TOOL TO QUANTIFY GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT OUTCOMES ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -WILL UNDERTAKE TWO OBJECTIVES TO ACCOMPLISH OUR GOAL. 1) DEVELOP A TOOL TO IDENTIFY AND MAP GRASSLAND HABITAT, AND 2) USE THIS TOOL TO QUANTIFY GRASSLAND HABITAT AND GRASSLAND BIRD COMMUNITY RESPONSES TO MANAGEMENT IN AND SURROUNDING THREE USFWS ARKANSAS REFUGES. A GRADUATE STUDENT WILL LEAD ALL BIRD AND VEGETATION SURVEY FIELD WORK AND ASSOCIATED RESEARCH.DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE:- RAPID MAPPING TOOL TO IDENTIFY CORE GRASSLANDS, DETERMINE CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN CORES, AND QUANTIFY MANAGEMENT OUTCOMES.- AUTOMATED AND ANNUALLY UPDATED GRASSLAND HABITAT MAPS FOR ARKANSAS USFWS REFUGES AND SURROUNDING LANDSCAPES.- GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT HISTORY DATABASE.- SCIENTIFIC ARTICLES AND SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS.PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL FACILITATE GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES IN THE ARKANSAS FWS REFUGES, PROVIDE INDICATORS OF GRASSLAND BIRD COMMUNITY HEALTH, AND DETERMINE THE APPLICABILITY OF OUR APPROACH FOR GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST.INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -US FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE, ARKANSAS GAME & FISH COMMISSION, USDA NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION SERVICE, QUAIL FOREVER, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS

PROJECT TITLE: CONDUCTING A GAP ANALYSIS FOR INVASIVE SPECIES PATHWAYS TO DETERMINE WHERE PREVENTION  MEASURES MAY BE LACKING.PROJECT PERIOD 3/31/2022 - 9/30/22ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED:  THIS PROJECT'S GOAL IS TO CONDUCT A GAP ANALYSIS TO EXAMINE HOW RECENT AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  INTRODUCTIONS OR SPREAD MAY HAVE BEEN PREVENTED IF AGENCY PREVENTION MEASURES HAD NOT BEEN  LACKING, INEFFECTIVE, OR RESULTED FROM GAPS IN AUTHORITY. THE END PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE ANALYSIS OF  THE CURRENT STATE OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PREVENTION, POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS AND NEW  MEASURES TO FILL ANY "GAPS" IN PREVENTION MEASURES, A REVIEW OF CURRENT PREVENTION TOOLS, AND A  SET OF METRICS TO MEASURE FUTURE EFFECTIVENESS.  THE UNIVERSITY AND U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY RESEARCH TEAMS WILL CONDUCT A SYSTEMIC REVIEW OF  RECENT AIS INTRODUCTIONS FROM DATA FROM THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY NONINDIGENOUS AQUATIC  SPECIES DATABASE. A SET OF CASE STUDIES WILL BE SELECTED FROM THE REVIEW TO CONDUCT THE GAP  ANALYSIS AND WILL INCLUDE: (1) ANALYZE THE CURRENT STATE OF PREVENTION MEASURES, (2) ESTABLISH THE  IDEAL FUTURE STATE OF PREVENTION MEASURES, (3) COMPARE THE CURRENT STATE WITH THE IDEAL STATE, (4)  DESCRIBE THE GAP AND QUANTIFY THE DIFFERENCE. THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL EVALUATE WHETHER OTHER  PREVENTION MEASURES OR POLICIES ARE POSSIBLE. WITH A FOCUS ON PRIMARY INTRODUCTION AND A REVIEW  OF SECONDARY SPREAD IN THE U.S. FROM TRANSPORTATION, THE ORGANISM IN TRADE PATHWAYS, AND  PERSPECTIVE OF NEW PATHWAYS. U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY WILL SHARE THE DRAFT RECOMMENDATIONS WITH  THE BROADER FEDERAL AGENCY INVASIVE SPECIES GROUPS FOR COMMENT.  DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:  NUMEROUS AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES PATHWAYS ARE MANAGED THROUGH VARIOUS FEDERAL AND STATE  AUTHORITIES. A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW IS NEEDED TO EFFECTIVELY COORDINATE AND MANAGE THOSE  PATHWAYS AND PREVENT FUTURE INTRODUCTIONS THROUGH CURRENT GAPS IN PREVENTION. BY COMPARING THE  CURRENT STATE OF PREVENTION MEASURES WITH THE IDEAL STATE (NO NEW INTRODUCTIONS, ONLY LOW IMPACT  INTRODUCTIONS, ETC.), U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND OTHER MANAGEMENT AGENCIES CAN  DETERMINE WHAT THEY NEED TO IMPROVE THEIR PERFORMANCE OR RESULTS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE THIS  INFORMATION BY CRITICALLY REVIEWING CASE STUDIES OF FAILED PREVENTIONS OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES  AND CONDUCTING A GAP ANALYSIS.  THIS RESEARCH TEAM WILL ALSO PRODUCE A COMPREHENSIVE REPORT ON THE AVAILABLE PREVENTION TOOLS  THAT WILL HIGHLIGHT THEIR USES AND THE RESEARCH TEAM'S ASSESSMENT OF THEIR EFFECTIVENESS. TIME,  MONEY, AND EFFORT CAN BE SAVED IF U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE UTILIZES OR ENHANCES CURRENTLY  AVAILABLE EFFECTIVE TOOLS AND PROJECTS RELATED TO PREVENTION. LASTLY, THE RESEARCH TEAM WILL LOOK TO  CREATE NEW PERFORMANCE METRICS RELATED TO THE PREVENTION GAP ANALYSIS RESULTS. THESE SUGGESTED  NEW METRICS WILL IMPROVE PREVENTION MANAGEMENT AND EFFECTIVENESS; BY PROVIDING MEASURABLE  OUTCOMES TO USE IN EVALUATING RESULTS.  INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES): U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE

PROJECT TITLE: DETERMINING IDEAL GEAR CONFIGURATIONS TO REDUCE FLYBACK OF WEIGHTS AND MINIMIZE INJURIES DURING FALSE KILLER WHALE INTERACTIONS IN US LONGLINE FISHERIESPROJECT PERIOD: 4/15/2022 - 10/31/2022 BYCATCH MITIGATION REGULATIONS FOR PELAGIC LONGLINE FISHERIES AROUND THE WORLD OFTEN INVOLVE MODIFICATIONS TO FISHING GEAR TO REDUCE, MINIMIZE OR PREVENT INTERACTIONS. IN HAWAII, LONGLINE FISHERIES HAVE HIGH INTERACTION RATES WITH MARINE MAMMALS, IN PARTICULAR FALSE KILLER WHALES (PSEUDORCA CRASSIDENS) WHICH ARE OF HIGH CONSERVATION CONCERN AND PROTECTED UNDER FEDERAL LAW (ESA). BYCATCH MEASURES INTRODUCED TO REDUCE INCIDENTAL MORTALITIES AND SERIOUS INJURIES OF P.CRASSIDENS IN HAWAIIAN COMMERCIAL FISHERIES INCLUDE REQUIRING A VESSEL TO 'BACK-DOWN' FROM A HOOKED P. CRASSIDENS BY REVERSING AWAY FROM THE INDIVIDUAL IN ORDER TO STRAIGHTEN THE HOOK AND RELEASE IT FROM THE JAW. HOWEVER, THE CONVENTIONAL LEADED SWIVELS CAN BE DANGEROUS FOR FISHERMEN AND THERE HAVE BEEN MANY ACCOUNTS OF CREWMEMBERS BEING INJURED, AND IN RARE CASES, KILLED, WHEN THE SWIVELS FLY-BACK AT THE VESSEL AFTER A BITE-OFF OR GEAR REMOVAL. THEREFORE, THIS STUDY WILL USE THEORETICAL AND PRACTICAL MODELLING TO QUANTIFY FLYBACK TRAJECTORY AND VELOCITY OF DIFFERENT GEAR CONFIGURATIONS IN ORDER TO DETERMINE AN IDEAL CONFIGURATION THAT WILL REDUCE THE RISK OF FLYBACK HARM TO CREW AND MINIMIZE JAW DAMAGE TO P. CRASSIDENS.THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE DOI PRIORITY FOR CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP BY PROVIDING INFORMATION TO DOI AND PARTNERS AGENCY DECISION-MAKERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS THAT WILL IMPROVE THEIR ABILITY TO PROTECT THREATENED AND ENDANGERED MARINE MAMMAL POPULATIONS FROM INTERACTIONS WITH COMMERCIAL FISHERIES, AS WELL AS ENAHNCING THE SAFETY OF CREWMEMBERS OF VESSELS PARTICIPATING IN THESE FISHERIES THEREBY SERVING TO PROTECT THE PUBLIC. MANAGEMENT OF AT-RISK SPECIES AND CONSERVATION TO PREVENT LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IS A CORE PRIORITY FOR DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR OVERALL, AS WELL FOR U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY.

THEBLACK-CAPPED PETRELIS GLOBALLY ENDANGERED WITH A BREEDING POPULATION ESTIMATED AT ~1,000 PAIRS. THE ONLY CONFIRMED BREEDING AREAS ARE LOCATED ONHISPANIOLA INMOUNTAINOUS AREAS 1,500-2,000M ABOVE SEA LEVEL.PETRELS NEST IN THETHICK AND MESICUNDERSTORY AND EXCAVATE BURROWS. THREATS INCLUDE HABITAT DISRUPTION DRIVEN BY ANTHROPOGENIC ACTIVITIES.THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE PREDICTED THAT THE TWO MAJOR BREEDING AREAS ON HISPANIOLA ARE LIKELY TO FACE EXTIRPATION BY 2070 AND, IF NO ADDITIONAL NEST SITES ARE FOUND, THIS WOULD REPRESENT A POTENTIAL LOSS OF UP TO 85-95% OF THE CURRENTLY KNOWN BREEDING POPULATION.TWO RECENT EVENTS APPEAR TO HAVE SUBSTANTIALLY IMPACTED NESTING ACTIVITY AND BREEDING SUCCESS - A FOREST FIRE AND PREDATION AT NEST SITES BY FERAL DOGS.THE INTERNATIONAL BLACK-CAPPED PETREL CONSERVATION GROUP IS BUILDING AND INSTALLING ARTIFICIAL BURROWS TO BETTER PROTECT EGG, CHICKS, AND ADULTS. WE PROPOSE TO ASSESS THE NESTING STATUS OF PETRELS FOLLOWING THE AFOREMENTIONED PREDATION AND FIRE EVENTS, AND THE DEPLOYMENT OF ARTIFICIAL BURROWS.THE OBJECTIVE IS TO DETERMINE IF THE PETREL POPULATION IS RESILIENT TO THREAT EVENTS AND IF BREEDING BIRDS USE ARTIFICIAL BURROWS. SUCH AN ASSESSMENT IS CONSISTENT WITH CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES FOR THE SPECIES AS DEVELOPED BY AN INTERNATIONAL WORKING GROUP OF EXPERTS.THE STUDY AREA INCLUDES THE BLACK-CAPPED PETREL NESTING AREA OF LOMA DEL TORO (18.3-N, 71.7-W), ON THE SIERRA DE BAHORUCO RIDGE, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC.TO ASSESS THE RECOVERY OF THE LOMA DEL TORO POPULATION AFFECTED BY THREAT EVENTS, WE WILL COMPARE TWO SITES WITHIN THE NESTING AREA. A TREATMENT SITE (N=10 MONITORED NESTS) WILL BE LOCATED ON A HIGHER RIDGE IN THE AREA. HERE, MOST BURROWS ARE EXCAVATED IN A THICK LAYER OF TOPSOIL OR UNDER ROTTING LOGS. ARTIFICIAL BURROWS WILL BE PLACED IN THIS AREA. A CONTROL SITE (N=9 MONITORED NESTS) WILL BE LOCATED LOWER ON THE RIDGE. AT THIS SITE, THE LAYER OF TOPSOIL IS VERY THIN AND MOST BURROWS MAKE USE OF CREVASSES IN ROCK BOULDERS. IT WOULD NOT BE POSSIBLE TO DIG INTO THE GROUND AND NO ARTIFICIAL BURROWS WILL BE PLACED AT THIS SITE. AT BOTH SITES, WILL MEASURE THE FACTORS AND) AND KEY ECOLOGICAL ATTRIBUTES OF IMPORTANCE TO THE BREEDING SUCCESS OF THE SPECIES.THE PRIMARY OUTCOME WILL BE AN ASSESSMENT OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE USE OF ARTIFICIAL BURROWS AS A MEANS TO ENHANCE REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS FOR THIS SPECIES.THE PRIMARY DELIVERABLE IS A FINAL REPORT THAT WILL INCLUDE SUMMARY DATA AND ANALYSIS OF MONITORING DATA WITH MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS REGARDING THE EFFICACY OR NEED FOR FURTHER TESTING OF ARTIFICIAL BURROWS.THE REPORT WILL DOCUMENT FINDINGS AND SUPPORTIVE DATA PERTINENT TO THE STATUS ASSESSMENT OF THIS SPECIES AS WELL ONGOING EFFORTS IN HAITI AND THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC TO CONSERVE THE SPECIES. THE CONCLUSIONS WILL ALSO INFORM EFFORTS TO PROTECT AND PROMOTE BREEDING IN BLACK-CAPPED PETRELS SHOULD THEY BE EVENTUALLY CONFIRMED TO BREED IN DOMINICA OR ELSEWHERE IN THE CARIBBEAN. THE INTERNATIONAL BLACK-CAPPED PETREL WORKING GROUP WILL SERVE AS A FACILITATING FORUM FOR DISTRIBUTION, AWARENESS AND USE OF THE PROJECT FINDINGS AMONG DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL INTERESTS IN THE US AND CARIBBEAN. A SUBRECIPIENT WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE QUICK RESPONSE EFFORT (GRUPO JARAGUA, ERNST RUPP, ERNST.RUPP@GRUPOJARAGUA.ORG.DO).

PROJECT TITLE:IDENTIFYING ENVIRONMENTAL AND DEMOGRAPHIC DRIVERS OF AMERICAN KESTREL POPULATION DECLINES TO INFORM CONSERVATION ACTIONSPROJECT PERIOD: 03/31/2022 - 06/30/2024IDENTIFYING ENVIRONMENTAL AND DEMOGRAPHIC DRIVERS OF AMERICAN KESTREL POPULATION DECLINES TO INFORM CONSERVATION ACTIONS. USGS PI: DR. ABIGAIL LAWSON, ASSISTANT UNIT LEADER OF WILDLIFE, U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY NEW MEXICO COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT. AMERICAN KESTRELS (HEREAFTER KESTREL) HAVE BEEN DECLINING ACROSS MOST OF THEIR NORTH AMERICAN RANGE AT A STEADY RATE OF APPROXIMATELY -1.4% PER YEAR FOR SEVERAL DECADES. ALTHOUGH LOSS OF HABITAT IS ONE HYPOTHESIZED FACTOR IN THE DECLINE OF GRASSLAND BIRDS, THE CAUSE OF THE KESTREL DECLINE REMAINS UNKNOWN DESPITE SEVERAL LOCAL STUDIES AND TWO BROAD REVIEWS OF AVAILABLE DATA. GIVEN THE STEADY AND WIDESPREAD DOWNWARD TREND IN KESTREL NUMBERS, A FAILURE TO IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS THE FACTORS DRIVING THE DECLINE WILL PREDICTABLY LEAD TO A NEED TO LIST THE SPECIES AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. IDENTIFYING AND INITIATING CORRECTIVE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS NOW, BEFORE LISTING IS NECESSARY AND IS MORE LIKELY TO RESULT IN A SUCCESSFUL OUTCOME WITHOUT THE NEED FOR EXPENSIVE AND RISKY REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS. OUR STUDY WILL DRAW ON EXISTING DATA SOURCES TO ELUCIDATE THE DRIVERS OF KESTREL DECLINES AT CONTINENTAL, AND REGIONAL SCALES USING POPULATION MODELS. SHORTLY AFTER STUDY INITIATION, WE WILL HOLD A WORKSHOP WITH SPECIES EXPERTS AND USFWS DECISION MAKERS. AT THE WORKSHOP, THE CONTINENTAL-SCALE RESULTS WILL BE USED AS THE BASIS FOR DEVELOPING REGIONAL-SCALE HYPOTHESES THAT CAN BE TESTED THROUGH MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AND EXISTING MONITORING PROGRAMS. THE HYPOTHESES DEVELOPED FROM THE WORKSHOP, WILL BE USED TO IDENTIFY IMPORTANT DRIVERS OF DECLINE THAT WILL BE USED IN REGIONAL-SCALE POPULATION MODELS THAT CAN PREDICT POPULATION OUTCOME. FUTURE MONITORING DATA CAN BE COMPARED AGAINST MODEL PREDICTIONS TO GAUGE RELATIVE SUPPORT AMONG HYPOTHESES, AND IDENTIFY THE MOST EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO CONSERVE KESTRELS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED. CREATE A CONTINENTAL-SCALE POPULATION MODEL TO COMPARE KESTREL DEMOGRAPHIC RATES ACROSS DIFFERENT REGIONS; HOLD A WORKSHOP WITH SPECIES EXPERTS AND USFWS DECISION MAKERS AND ELICIT REGION-SPECIFIC HYPOTHESES RELATED TO KESTREL DECLINES. WITHIN EACH REGION, THE HYPOTHESES WILL BE PRIORITIZED FOR TESTING USING DECISION ANALYSIS TOOLS; DEVELOP REGION (FLYWAY) SPECIFIC KESTREL POPULATION MODELS THAT CAN BE UPDATED WITH FUTURE MONITORING DATA. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES. THE CONTINENTAL-SCALE MODEL AND THE RESULTS WILL BE WRITTEN UP IN THE FORM OF A PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATION. REPORT DETAILING THE WORKSHOP ACTIVITIES INCLUDING THE REGION-SPECIFIC HYPOTHESES AND PLANS FOR MONITORING AND COLLECTING DATA, AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. REGION-SPECIFIC PREDICTIVE POPULATION MODELS THAT CAN BE UPDATED WITH ADDITIONAL MONITORING DATA, THAT WILL BE USED BY USFWS TO FORECAST KESTREL ABUNDANCE. ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL BE DETAILED IN A FINAL REPORT DUE TO USFWS, THE PROJECT SPONSOR. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES). USFWS: MIGRATORY BIRD MANAGEMENT (ALL REGIONS AND THE NATIONAL RAPTOR PROGRAM), SCIENCE APPLICATIONS, REFUGES - INVENTORY AND MONITORING. STATE AGENCIES TASKED WITH MANAGING OR CONSERVING KESTREL POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITAT. NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS FOCUSED ON RAPTOR (THE KESTREL IS A TYPE OF RAPTOR) CONSERVATION (E.G., HAWK MOUNTAIN, GOLDEN GATE RAPTOR OBSERVATORY, HAWK WATCH, ETC.).

TITLE. ASSESSING WILD PIG IMPACTS TO ECOSYSTEM SERVICES: A CASE STUDY ON DIET, DENSITY, AND SPACE USE OF WILD PIGS ON THE SOUTH ARKANSAS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX. WILD PIGS ARE ONE OF THE MOST DESTRUCTIVE INVASIVE SPECIES IN THE UNITED STATES. MANAGEMENT OF PIGS REQUIRES A BASIC UNDERSTANDING OF HOW MANY PIGS OCCUPY AND AREA AND THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS THEY ARE HAVING ON OTHER SPECIES. HERE, WILL USE WILDLIFE CAMERAS AND A NEW MODELING APPROACH TO ESTIMATE THE ABUNDANCE OF PIGS AT A WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX IN SOUTH ARKANSAS. ALSO WILL LOOK AT THE EFFECTS OF PIGS ON SONGBIRDS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED. WILL UNDERTAKE TWO OBJECTIVES TO ACCOMPLISH OUR GOALS: 1) WILL USE WILDLIFE CAMERAS TO ESTIMATE THE ABUNDANCE OF PIGS OCCURRING IN THE WILDLIFE REFUGE AND 2) WILL RELATE THE SONGBIRD COMMUNITIES PRESENT AT DIFFERENT PARTS OF THE REFUGE COMPLEX WITH THE RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF PIGS AND THE MEASURABLE DISTURBANCE OF PIGS AT THAT SITE. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE. AN ABUNDANCE ESTIMATE OF PIGS PRESENT ON THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. SCIENTIFIC ARTICLE DESCRIBING IMPACTS OF PIGS ON SONGBIRDS. SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS. PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL FACILITATE WILD PIG MANAGEMENT ON SOUTHEASTERN INSTALLATIONS. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES). SEVERE ACUTE RESPIRATORY SYNDROME CORONAVIRUS 2 (SARS-COV-2), THE ETIOLOGICAL AGENT OF CORONAVIRUS DISEASE 2019 (COVID-19), WAS FIRST DETECTED IN THE WUHAN REGION OF CHINA IN DECEMBER 2019. SINCE THE INITIAL OUTBREAK, SARS-COV-2 HAS SPREAD WORLD-WIDE INFECTING OVER 370M PEOPLE THAT HAS RESULTED IN APPROXIMATELY 5.6M DEATHS. CURRENT VACCINES HAVE BEEN SUCCESSFUL BUT ALTERNATIVE ANTIGEN TESTS ARE STILL NEEDED FOR TRACKING AND CONTAINING THE SPREAD OF SARS-COV-2 VARIANTS. IMPORTANTLY, IT IS BECOMING CLEAR THAT SPECIFIC WILDLIFE SPECIES ARE ALSO SUSCEPTIBLE TO SARS-COV-2. THEREFORE, PREDICTIVE TOOLS FOR IDENTIFYING POTENTIALLY SUSCEPTIBLE SPECIES ARE NEEDED TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE IMPACT(S) OF COVID-19 FOR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED. IDENTIFY SINGLE CHAIN ANTIBODY-LIKE PROTEINS THAT CAN BIND SARS-COV-2 PROTEINS WITH HIGH AFFINITY. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE SCREENING SINGLE CHAIN LIBRARIES AND IMPLEMENTING THE USAGE OF THESE REAGENTS FOR DETECTING SARS-COV-2 FOR HUMAN AND WILDLIFE HEALTH, AND USE HIGH THROUGHPUT GENOMIC APPROACHES THAT CAN PREDICT SPECIES SUSCEPTIBILITY BASED UPON SINGLE NUCLEOTIDE POLYMORPHISMS WITHIN IMMUNE GENES OF WILDLIFE SPECIES. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES. IDENTIFICATION OF SINGLE CHAIN, ANTIBODY-LIKE PROTEINS THAT BIND SPECIFICALLY BIND SARS-COV-2. TEST THE USAGE OF THE SARS-COV-2 BINDERS FOR ELISA AND WESTERN BLOT AGAINST SARS-COV-2. GENOMIC TOOL THAT ASSESSES THE PRESENCE AND ABSENCE OF SPECIFIC GENES AND SINGLE NUCLEOTIDE POLYMORPHISMS (SNPS) FOR WILDLIFE AS A PREDICTIVE TOOL FOR SPECIES SUSCEPTIBILITY TO SARS-COV-2. INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES). THIS IS A ONE-HEALTH APPROACH THAT BENEFITS THE ENVIRONMENT, PEOPLE AND WILDLIFE.

ARCTIC-BREEDING SHOREBIRDS HAVE EXPERIENCED LARGE POPULATION DECLINES IN THE PAST SEVERAL DECADES, WHICH HAVE BEEN LARGELY ATTRIBUTED TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN THE ARCTIC. CLIMATE CHANGE HAS LED TO CHANGES IN VEGETATION STRUCTURE, THE TIMING OF INSECT PREY AVAILABILITY, AND THE DENSITY OF NEST PREDATORS. HOWEVER, IT HAS ALSO BEEN SUGGESTED THAT INCREASED NEST PREDATION OBSERVED OVER THE PAST 20 YEARS COULD BE EXPLAINED BY RESEARCH METHODS THAT INVOLVE FREQUENT VISITS TO ACTIVE NESTS. UNDERSTANDING THE EFFECT OF HUMAN DISTURBANCE ON NEST SUCCESS IS CRITICAL FOR INTERPRETING THE RESULTS OF MANY STUDIES AND IDENTIFYING THE KEY DRIVERS OF NEST FAILURE AND THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE ON ARCTIC-BREEDING SHOREBIRDS. THIS STUDY WILL USE GPS TAGS DEPLOYED ON DUNLIN (CALIDRIS ALPINA) TO UNDERSTAND MOVEMENTS AND BEHAVIORS OF BREEDING BIRDS AND TO ESTIMATE NEST SUCCESS WITHOUT HUMAN DISTURBANCE AT THE NEST. SPECIFICALLY, OUR OBJECTIVES ARE:- TO OBTAIN THE FIRST TRUE ESTIMATES OF NEST SURVIVAL IN A SHOREBIRD SPECIES;- TO ASSESS HOW CONVENTIONAL, HUMAN INTENSIVE MONITORING TECHNIQUES AFFECT NEST SURVIVAL UNDER DIFFERENT ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS;- TO DEVELOP A BEST PRACTICE GUIDE FOR ACCOUNTING FOR HUMAN DISTURBANCE EFFECTS ON SHOREBIRD NEST SURVIVAL; AND- TO EVALUATE HOW ADULT BEHAVIOR PRIOR TO AND DURING NESTING VARIES WITH ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS.- ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED - ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE TRAPPING DUNLIN TO ATTACH GPS TAGS AND COLLECTING LOCATION DATA DURING THE SUMMERS OF 2022 AND 2023. LOCATION DATA WILL BE ANALYZED TO ADDRESS THE OBJECTIVES OUTLINED ABOVE. THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT SALARY AND TUITION FOR ONE MS STUDENT IN ADDITION TO COSTS FOR GPS TAGS.- DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES -ONE MS THESIS AND AT LEAST ONE PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATION, AS WELL AS ANNUAL STATUS REPORTS TO THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE.- INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) -U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME, BIRD WATCHING COMMUNITY- SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD-

THE DEGRADATION OF PRAIRIE STREAM AND RIPARIAN ECOSYSTEMS ARE A RESULT OF CHANGES TO HYDROLOGY (RESERVOIRS), HEAVY GRAZING, AND LOSS OF ECOSYSTEM ENGINEERS SUCH AS THE NORTH AMERICAN BEAVER. THESE DISTURBANCES AND YEARS OF DROUGHT HAVE COMPROMISED PRAIRIE STREAMS AND RIPARIAN ZONES, MANY OF WHICH ARE NOW SEVERELY DEGRADED. CONSERVATION AND REINTRODUCTION OF BEAVER AND INSTALLATION OF BEAVER DAM ANALOGS THAT MIMIC BEAVER PONDS ARE INCREASINGLY BEING USED AS HABITAT RESTORATION AND DROUGHT REMEDIATION TOOLS IN THE WESTERN USA. HOWEVER, THE PRACTICE OF BEAVER-BASED RESTORATION HAS OUTPACED THE SCIENCE, AND IN MANY CASES, COSTLY RESTORATION METHODS OR REINTRODUCTIONS OF BEAVER ARE BEING DONE WITH LITTLE KNOWLEDGE OF THE POTENTIAL BENEFITS OF SUCH ACTIONS. IF AWARDED, THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON PROVIDING INFORMATION TO GUIDE BEAVER-BASED RESTORATION EFFORTS IN THE NORTHERN PLAINS. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL MEASURE THE RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF BEAVER PONDS IN PRODUCING INSECTS, PROVIDING HABITAT FOR AMPHIBIANS, AND HOW BEAVER PONDS AFFECT ACTIVITY PATTERNS (E.G., NUMBER OF VOCALIZATIONS PER NIGHT, DISTRIBUTION OF DIFFERENT BAT SPECIES).- ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED -WE PLAN TO SAMPLE FLYING INSECTS WITH STICKY TRAPS ATTACHED TO POLES NEAR THE WATER'S EDGE. INSECTS GET STUCK TO THE TRAPS, ALLOWING US TO ESTIMATE THEIR ABUNDANCE AS WELL AS PATTERNS OF SPECIES RICHNESS. AMPHIBIANS AND BATS WILL BE DETECTED WITH ACOUSTIC RECORDERS ATTACHED TO POLES NEAR THE WATER'S EDGE. WE WILL USE STANDARD SOFTWARE (E.G., KALEIDOSCOPE BY WILDLIFE ACOUSTICS) TO DETERMINE CALLING ACTIVITY AND SPECIES RICHNESS OF AMPHIBIANS AND BATS.- DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES - USING STANDARDIZED SAMPLING AND ANALYSIS METHODS, WE WILL ESTIMATE (1) INSECT PRODUCTION, (2) BAT FORAGING ACTIVITY, AND (3) SPECIES RICHNESS OF BATS AND AMPHIBIANS AT BEAVER SITES, BDA SITES, OTHER AVAILABLE WATER BODIES (HUMAN-MADE PONDS/RESERVOIRS/WETLANDS), AS WELL AS CORRESPONDING CONTROL SITES IN STREAMS. WE WILL COMMUNICATE RESULTS TO BLM VIA PRESENTATIONS AND ANNUAL REPORTS, AND DATA WILL BE SHARED AS SPREADSHEETS.THERE HAS BEEN VERY LITTLE WORK DONE ON THE ECOSYSTEM EFFECTS OF BEAVER IN NORTHERN PLAINS SYSTEMS, AND EVEN LESS ON THEIR POTENTIAL BENEFITS TO NON-AQUATIC SPECIES SUCH AS BATS. BECAUSE NATURAL WATERBODIES ARE SCARCE IN THE PROPOSED STUDY AREA, WE EXPECT BEAVER PONDS WILL INCREASE LOCAL INSECT PRODUCTION AND INCREASE ABUNDANCE AND SPECIES RICHNESS OF AMPHIBIANS AND BATS.- INTENDED BENEFICIARY(IES) - THE PLANNED WORK IS ON BLM LANDS. WE WILL COMMUNICATE RESULTS WITH THE BLM AS WELL AS WITH STATE AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTNERS.- SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES, IF KNOWN OR SPECIFIED AT THE TIME OF AWARD - NONE KNOWN.

THIS WORK IS BEING CONDUCTED UNDER THE AUTHORITY OF DOI SECRETARIAL ORDER 3362, WHICH CALLED ON THE US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) TO ASSIST WESTERN STATES IN MAPPING UNGULATE MIGRATION CORRIDORS AND DEVELOP NEW MAPPING TOOLS. A GENERAL FRAMEWORK THAT ANALYZES GPS LOCATION DATA FROM PREVIOUS OR ONGOING MULE DEER STUDIES IN OREGON USING METHODS DEVELOPED BY THE WYOMING COOPERATIVE FISH AND WILDLIFE RESEARCH UNIT (WYCFWRU) AND COLLABORATORS (BROWNIAN BRIDGE MOVEMENT MODEL (BBMM); KAUFFMAN ET AL. 2020) WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO THE LARGE-SCALE MOVEMENTS OF MULE DEER IN OREGON. IDENTIFICATION AND PRIORITIZATION OF MIGRATION CORRIDORS FOR MULE DEER THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE IN OREGON WOULD ADDRESS A CRITICAL DATA GAP FOR THE STATE AND FACILITATE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THESE POPULATIONS. THIS INFORMATION ALSO WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE LARGER EFFORT OCCURRING ACROSS THE WEST. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED (1) COMPILE RECENT AVAILABLE GPS COLLAR DATA ON MIGRATORY AND NON-MIGRATORY MULE DEER. (2) APPLY BROWNIAN BRIDGE MOVEMENT MODEL ANALYSIS TO MULE DEER GPS DATA FROM EASTERN OREGON FOR DEVELOPMENT OF SEASONAL RANGES AND MIGRATION CORRIDORS. RESULTING POLYGONS WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE FOR USE IN AGENCY MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS AND ONLINE APPLICATIONS. (3) CREATE CARTOGRAPHIC MAP PRODUCTS OF MIGRATION CORRIDORS, AND SEASONAL RANGES FOR MULE DEER IN OREGON. ASSOCIATED RANGE AND CORRIDOR POLYGON MAP FILES WILL BE AVAILABLE IN PRINT IN THE USGS WESTER MIGRATION REPORT SERIES AND TO LAND AND RESOURCE MANAGERS DIGITALLY VIA THE MIGRATION ROUTE VIEWER. (4) ASSIST OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW) WITH DEVELOPMENT OF CARTOGRAPHIC AND INFOGRAPHIC PRODUCTS THAT COMMUNICATE KEY MIGRATION ISSUES, THREATS, AND CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITIES WITHIN THE STATE.
